headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's confer
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Kevin Berry. Sir, you may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO. Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO. Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a more detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, February 2, 2016. For reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in Form 8-K with the SEC and available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will cover the following main topics: a recap of our fourth quarter activities, followed by our observations of retail environment during the holiday season
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will cover the following main topics: a recap of our fourth quarter activities, followed by our observations of retail environment during the holiday season and update of our redevelopment activities in urban assets and finally, an outlook for 2016. 
When we first begin by addressing a topic that I believe is on top of everybody's mind, which is  a recent high volume of trading in our stock in certain days. As a matter of policy, we don't comment on rumors in the marketplace and don't intend to do this morning or in the future. But I will do remind our investors of our corporate governance guidelines that we put in place when GGP was recapitalized and recommend investors review this information, which is on file with the SEC and available on our websites. The management team and the members of the GGP board take fiduciary responsibilities seriously and recognize that it's public company we would always act in the best interest of our shareholders. This represents the extent of my comments and any questions during our Q&A session related to market rumors will not be answered as it would be irresponsible and inappropriate to do so. 
Now turning to our results for the fourth quarter. Same-store NOI increased 6.7% followed by 6.5% increase in EBITDA. FFO per share increased nearly 14% to $0.43, the top end of our guidance range. For the full year, same-store NOI increased 4.8% followed by a 5.4% increase in EBITDA. FFO per share increased nearly 9% to $1.44 which is near the top end of our guidance range. 
Please that 2015 commences were nearly 11% and spread for 2016 commencements continue to be healthy. The same portfolio was nearly 97% leased at year-end and over 92% permanently occupied. Looking into 2016. Our goal is to lease approximately 9 million square feet. To date, we have leased over 60% of our goals. We raised our guidance for 2016 by $0.01 at the midpoint primarily to account for the accelerated rent commencement base at 730 Fifth Avenue and other, representing nearly a 7% per share growth and also declared our first quarter dividend. Comparable rent sales were up 3% on a square-foot basis. A point to be noted is if you back out Apple sales, growth includes 4.5% for sales of retailers less than 10,000 square feet and almost 4% for all retailers, excluding department stores. portfolio by quality grade, we experienced sales increases throughout the country. Nearly every major retail category was up, with the exception of electronics, primarily due to Apple. Shopper classic in our centers has been strong. Looking back over the past several years from our estimates, we've experienced positive trends in each year. In 2012, traffic was up over 4%; in 2013, 3%; flat in 2014; and up 2% in 2015. 
During the holiday season, I had opportunity to visit several of our malls. During the Thanksgiving weekend, I was at several of our malls between 11:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. and I noticed that the parking lots were full and the most interesting thing to me was the shoppers were generally Millennials. We are regularly comparing the productivity of our portfolio to the national average. We look at overall trends, category trends, not the specific retailers trends. The overriding premise and what we have set as our mission is that the high-quality retail should outperform over the long term. I'd like to share some of our observations with you this morning. 
To set the stage though, it is important to put retail sales in perspective. In 2015, retail and food service accounted for about 30% of the U.S. GDP and e-commerce accounted for about 2%. Since 2010, total retail sales in the U.S. have grown nearly 13%, and it should be noted that our portfolio has grown over the same period 23%. 
We see is that all sales productivity but also the lack of vacancy within the mall and the pent-up demand for space. The mall continues to evolve in step with consumer demand and interest, and we see it occurring throughout our portfolio. For example, e-commerce retailers like Parker, Franklin, Sonoma should know are scaling up operations by opening stores. Grocers like and Kroger's are coming into the malls. Personal services like and drive bar are important elements on the outside of our malls. And of course, entertainment venues and restaurants. 
Expansion to new store openings by existing brick-and-mortar retailers this past year include: H&M adding 220,000 square feet in 10 stores; house Furniture with 45,000 square feet in 3 stores; Pink with 40,000 square feet in 9 stores; Uniqlo with 40,000 square feet in 4 stores; House of and Footlucker concept now opening their own bricks-and-mortar stores with 39,000 square feet in 5 stores and the list goes on. It should be noted that at that one of the first e-commerce retailers to open the store opened 6 stores within our portfolio in the past year. 
As it is known, new retail square footage on the horizon, new concepts are going into the B plus malls. As mentioned in our release yesterday, we closed on and several property transactions recently as we continued to prove the lower-tier noncore assets in the portfolio. We sold our strip shopping in New York during the fourth quarter. In January, we closed on a number of construction, including the following: We sold our interest in Malls through our JV partner, [indiscernible]; we sold Mall in San Jose California; we sold our interest Town Center in Kroger, Utah; and finally, we sold our minority interest in 522 Fifth Avenue in New York City. 
In stark contrast to the other end of the party spectrum and evidenced by a number of transactions recently, the valuations prescribed to A malls continues to be very strong, diversions from current public market valuations. A malls are irreplaceable assets in high demand by tenant, highly desired by consumers and very attractive to institutional investors. Looking globally, it is clear that the U.S. overreaches compared to other developed countries. greenfield to rarity in the mall space and given the negligible new supply expected over the foreseeable future, and the likely reduction of overall retail GLA due to the imminent closure of lower-quality retail assets, including malls, the fortification of A malls within the 3 areas will continue. Our top 100 malls account for 94% of our NOI and boast sales over $600 per square foot. Our 70 for A malls account for 75% of our NOI and post nearly $700 per square-foot. On the redevelopment front, we were very pleased to open several major projects during the fourth quarter on time and on budget, including: the extension of Ala Moana, with the return of 11%; the expansion of a Mall with the return of 9%; the completion -- the complete renovation of Plaza with the return of 9%; the grand opening of Nordstrom and Ridgedale with the return of 8%; and the grand opening of Nordstrom and Mall, with the return of 8%. A number of other redevelopment products are across the portfolio. 
As we look to 2016, we will get started on stock and mall expansion and renovation, the relocation of Nordstrom and Ala Moana and the various redevelopment opportunities within our joint venture with [indiscernible], 2 of which have just begun at Coronado Center Mall, and we anticipate another 4 to commence at least by year-end. And lastly, later this year, we will start Connecticut, a new mall anchored by Nordstrom and Bloomingdale's, contingent upon final approvals by city and state officials. 
On the urban retail update, we have entered into a lease for 23,374 square feet with Coach Inc. to open a global flagship for the Coach brand and a steward Wiseman at 685 Fifth Avenue. At 730 Fifth Avenue, we renewed the lease of Bulgari and as I mentioned earlier, we sold our 10% interest in 522 Fifth Avenue, which we acquired in 2014. The IRR on this investment is almost 50%. Our improved outlook for 2016 continues to be based on our key growth drivers: Improved occupancy, positive leasing spreads and incremental income from our redevelopment activity. These organic sources of growth and GDP's irreplaceable portfolio are the basis of our outlook this year and beyond. 
Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to recognize our teams located at our Eastern properties I that hit the middle over week ago. Due to the severity of the storm, a number of our properties closed early so people could get home safely and remain closed until it was safe to reopen. Our teams worked together tirelessly over the weekend to measure the storm's impact and to determine when to reopen. You know we you are and I sincerely thank each of you for your dedication to GGP. What I'd like to do -- with that, I'd like to turn it over to Michael to review financial results in more detail and expand upon our expectations for 2016.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. First, turning for the fourth quarter. As you know FFO per share came in at $0.43, putting us at the high-end of our guidance range. The $10 million ahead was approximately $5 million from debt and expected
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. First, turning for the fourth quarter. As you know FFO per share came in at $0.43, putting us at the high-end of our guidance range. The $10 million ahead was approximately $5 million from debt and expected same-store NOI, $4 million of which is related better-than-expected net real estate tax recoveries and we had about a $1 million higher-than-expected lease-term fees. The remaining $5 million came from a small land sale and somewhat better-than-expected interest expense. are developing projects contributed $9 million of growth in the first quarter, which was consistent with our prior quarter. 
Turning to our plan for 2016, please remember, my remarks are intended to point in range. We are increasing or FFO per share guidance range to $1.52 to $1.56 for midpoint of a $1.54 or about 7% growth. The increase, as Sandeep noted, some of which comes from leasing activity that occurred in late December an additional expense savings across various line items. These offset an additional $8.5 million and interest expense that we will have on our variable rate then. I think it's helpful to review our 2016 guidance model given that the 2015 numbers are now final. The numbers at our model reflect the recent sale at Eastridge Center, and 522 Fifth Avenue. The. 
We continue to expect same-store NOI growth of 4% to 5% on a base of approximately $2.24 billion. Development projects are expected to contribute approximately $40 million to same-store NOI growth in 2016, consistent with what we said in last quarter's prior -- previously stated guidance. We expect EBITDA growth of 8% to 9% on a base of approximately $2.1 billion. We previously said about 8% EBITDA growth and the incremental up in guidance adds to the EBITDA growth rate of about 50 basis points. Expected EBITDA growth would be about 4.5% to 5.5% without the condo development we mentioned last quarter, and we expect FFO to be around $1.475 billion with a share count expected of around $960 million. The previous guidance was about $10 million less. 
For the first quarter of 2016, our expectations are same-store NOI of around 4% growth for approximately $555 million. We expect development to contribute around $9 million of same-store NOI for the first quarter. We expect EBITDA of approximately $525 million or growth of 6.5% to 7%, and we expect FFO in the range of $325 million to $345 million or FFO per share of $0.34 to $0.36 representing growth of approximately 8.7% per share at the midpoint. And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: So, Steve, one is you're actually right, I won't comment on the rent per square foot on the transaction. And as I've -- as we've maintained -- we buy these assets and we stabilize them to a 5% to 6% yield, and it did come in as performer. We will deliver the space to Coach by May of this year, then we will evaluate how we should handle the transaction going forward, whether hold or sell. It is our job to allocate capital, it's also our job to make sure that we asset in new recycle capital, so we would give enemy that later in the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When we move away from A and really top B+ malls, everybody that group to move more together is 1 giant pot. Our view is every assets has its own business plan, its own stor
componenttext: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When we move away from A and really top B+ malls, everybody that group to move more together is 1 giant pot. Our view is every assets has its own business plan, its own story, its own leverage requirements. We did 3B malls in the fourth quarter and got what we thought were pretty good deals considering the volatility in the marketplace. We have a couple of B malls that we have coming due this year, and we would expect to be able to address them successfully. The market has got more volatile in terms of dealers permitting spreads for treasuries have come down. You haven't really seen a lot of change in the overall interest rates that you're being quoted.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we've maintained that in our last quarterly call that we have held a credit reserve because we anticipated at the time, several large bankruptcies to occur in 2016. And the jury is out whether they will occur in 2016. And I think usually, we will w
componenttext: Again, we've maintained that in our last quarterly call that we have held a credit reserve because we anticipated at the time, several large bankruptcies to occur in 2016. And the jury is out whether they will occur in 2016. And I think usually, we will wait to the end in the first quarter because that is a time when you start to see the telltale signs whether someone's going to file, and so this will maintain our course and hold our conservative reserve credit reserve.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention fees and all that dealing with new regulations. So as you
componenttext: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention fees and all that dealing with new regulations. So as you guys look at your financing platform and strategy, is there any view to potentially shift away or broaden away from the mortgage, whether it's life or CMBS are you guys view that the issues that the mortgage market you're dealing with right now will eventually be worked through before you guys get to the more meaningful maturities in '17, '18, '19?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I think, we're going to mortgage markets primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers old paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces and that is forcing the market
componenttext: You know, I think, we're going to mortgage markets primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers old paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces and that is forcing the market to kind of deal with that element. From a long-term perspective, I actually think that's a very beneficial element. It's going to make the underwriting cleaner. It's going to make it the better properties and the better sponsors are going to benefit in an environment where there is more of a focus on quality of earnings and quality of assets. So I don't have to sell -- I'm not making a comment of the CMBS market overall, i just think that GGP, given its asset base and its history, will continue to thrive in the mortgage market.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of
componenttext: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of those assets, there's obviously a very positive impact to debt-to-EBITDA ratio and with the additional capital, again we'll evaluate to make capital allocation decisions between what we've done in the past, which is the debt paydown or reinvestments in our development pipeline. And at this level of our stock, we're not purchasers of our own stock. We've been very prudent about that, the cognizant upon leveraged issues and we only look to buy stock within sort of deep discount in what we believe is NAV. And we've been prudent and showed you our hand at what that price would be. And so we would evaluate to either pay down debt or reinvested on into further development activities that it should be.

And then just understanding that it sounds like you stock today at a significant discount, I think you're buying back sort of $25 [ph] but to the extent that you're still trading at a discount to NAV, just curious I know we've had many, many discussions about leverage and your thoughts on leverage and that kind of thing but it does seems that, that's clearly 1 thing that does way on the stock relative to some others, if the discount persist, I mean, is that something you would ever revisit in terms of the overall leverage?

componenttext: Where we already, as I mentioned to you, you ask what I would do with the capital, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio for 2016 will be in the 8 to 8.5 range, as Michael said. You asked me what I would do with the capital, I've proven that last year, we paid down $600 million of debt to the Ala Moana proceeds and if we did sell another retail assets, we would either pay down debt schedule to gain or redeploy the capital in redevelopment activities, which could use 8% or better returns, which again had the same impact, which is to increase EBITDA and reduce to EBITDA ratio.

And could you maybe talk about, I mean, obviously, most of your redevelopment capital, you're -- according to estimates your obtaining about $600 million of cash flow every year that you're planning back in your redevelopment, how are you -- as you think about the allegation to fortifying existing A asset as opposed to turning some of your B malls into potentially A malls, maybe talk about the thought process and also maybe touch upon what you think is happening at Southwest Plaza in?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls of the fortification provision of our A malls. And we haven't done much beyond as you know, this a vacation for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B,
componenttext: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls of the fortification provision of our A malls. And we haven't done much beyond as you know, this a vacation for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B, B+ access and advanced capital in them to come to mind one is Southwest Plaza as you mentioned. We were very pleased with the opening of Southwest Plaza. The food hall at the retailer productivity has gone up dramatically. We see that mall, which is probably a 300 [indiscernible] mall with a 50% occupancy, 60% occupancy due fly into 90% by year-end and sales productivity to be well over $400 a square-foot. The traffic was very good during the holiday season so it seems that, that investment will pay out handsomely. The return on our investment was almost for 9% there. So we deployed whatever $70 million to $80 million and got a 9% return. So we would like to be so far successful period. And again, we were able to do that because the demographics justify the expenditure. We did do that with the in mall in the Norfolk market for we invested, I don't know, $40-ish million or so, and I think, that mall now almost $500-dollars-plus [ph] mall. And so again, when the demographics are prevalent investing in the B, B plus assets, you do get an opportunity to upgrade the asset to a high quality asset. So 70% to 80% of our capital gets deployed into what we would call A malls.

componenttext: As, Rich, as we said consistently, our job is to one, keep pruning the lower quality assets. headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's confer
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. I would now like to introduce your host for today's conference, Mr. Kevin Berry. Sir, you may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO. Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO. Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a more detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, February 2, 2016. For reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in Form 8-K with the SEC and available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will cover the following main topics: a recap of our fourth quarter activities; followed by our observations of retail environment during this past holiday s
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will cover the following main topics: a recap of our fourth quarter activities; followed by our observations of retail environment during this past holiday season; an update of our redevelopment activities in urban assets; and finally, an outlook for 2016. 
And we first begin by addressing a topic that I believe is on top of everybody's mind, which is the recent high volume of trading in our stock on certain days. As a matter of policy, we don't comment on rumors in the marketplace and don't intend to do this morning or in the future. What I will do is remind our investors of our corporate governance guidelines that we put in place when GGP was recapitalized and recommend investors review this information, which is on file with the SEC and available on our websites. The management team and the members of the GGP board take our fiduciary responsibilities seriously and recognize that as stewards of this public company, we would always act in the best interest of our shareholders. This represents the extent of my comments and any questions during our Q&A session related to market rumors will not be answered as it would be irresponsible and inappropriate to do so. 
Now turning to our results for the fourth quarter. Same-store NOI increased 6.7% followed by 6.5% increase in EBITDA. FFO per share increased nearly 14% to $0.43, the top end of our guidance range. For the full year, same-store NOI increased 4.8% followed by a 5.4% increase in EBITDA. FFO per share increased nearly 9% to $1.44, which is near the top end of our guidance range. 
The lease spreads for 2015 commencements were nearly 11% and spreads for 2016 commencements continue to be healthy. The same-store portfolio was nearly 97% leased at year end and over 92% permanently occupied. 
Looking into 2016. Our goal is to lease approximately 9 million square feet. To date, we have leased over 60% of our goal. We raised our guidance for 2016 by $0.01 at the midpoint primarily to account for the accelerated rent commencement date at 730 Fifth Avenue and other mix and match, representing nearly a 7% per share growth and also declared our first quarter dividend. Comparable rent sales were up 3% on a square-foot basis. A point to be noted is if you back out Apple sales, growth includes 4.5% for sales of retailers less than 10,000 square feet and almost 4% for all retailers, excluding department stores. Passing the portfolio by quality grade, we experienced sales increases throughout the country. Nearly every major retail category was up, with the exception of electronics, primarily due to Apple. Shopper classic in our centers has been strong. Looking back over the past several years from our estimates, we've experienced positive trends in each year. In 2012, traffic was up over 4%; in 2013, 3%; flat in 2014; and up 2% in 2015. 
During the holiday season, I had opportunity to visit several of our malls. During the Thanksgiving weekend, I was at several of our malls between 11:00 p.m. and 2:00 a.m. and I noticed that the parking lots were full, and the most interesting thing to me was the shoppers were generally Millennials. We are regularly comparing the productivity of our portfolio to the national average. We look at overall trends, category trends, down to specific retailer trends. The overriding premise and what we have set as our mission is that the high-quality retail should outperform over the long term. I'd like to share some of our observations with you this morning. 
To set the stage though, it is important to put retail sales in perspective. In 2015, retail and food service accounted for about 30% of the U.S. GDP, and e-commerce accounted for about 2%. Since 2010, total retail sales in the U.S. have grown nearly 13%. And it should be noted that our portfolio has grown over the same period 23%. 
We see this not only in sales productivity but also the lack of vacancy within the mall and the pent-up demand for space. The mall continues to evolve in step with consumer demand and interest, and we see it occurring throughout our portfolio. For example, e-commerce retailers like Warby Parker, Frank & Oak, Bonobos, Shinola, Birchbox and Athleta are scaling up operations by opening stores. Grocers like Wegmans and Kroger's are coming into the malls. Personal services like SoulCycle and Drybar are important elements on the outsides of our malls. And of course, entertainment venues and restaurants. 
Expansions in new store openings by existing brick-and-mortar retailers this past year include: H&M adding 220,000 square feet in 10 stores; Our House furniture with 45,000 square feet in 3 stores; Pink with 40,000 square feet in 9 stores; Uniqlo with 40,000 square feet in 4 stores; House of Hoops at Foot Locker concept now opening their own bricks-and-mortar stores with 39,000 square feet in 5 stores and the list goes on. It should be noted that Athleta, one of the first e-commerce retailers to open the store opened 6 stores within our portfolio in the past year. 
As there is no new retail square footage on the horizon, new concepts are going into the B+ or better malls. As mentioned in our release yesterday, we closed on several property transactions recently as we continued to prune the lower-tier noncore assets on the portfolio. We sold our remaining strip shopping center in Lockport, New York during the fourth quarter. In January, we closed on a number of transactions, including the following: We sold our interest in Owings Mills malls through our JV partner, Kimco; we sold Eastridge Mall in San Jose California; we sold our interest in Provo Towne Centre in Provo, Utah; and finally, we sold our minority interest in 522 Fifth Avenue in New York City. 
In stark contrast to the other end of the quality spectrum and evidenced by a number of transactions recently, the valuations prescribed to A malls continues to be very strong, a diversion from current public market valuations. A malls are irreplaceable assets in high demand by tenants, highly desired by consumers and very attractive to institutional investors. Looking globally, it is clear that the U.S. is over-retailed compared to other developed countries. New greenfield is a rarity in the mall space. And given the negligible new supply expected over the foreseeable future and the likely reduction of overall retail GLA due to the imminent closure of lower-quality retail assets, including malls, the fortification of A malls within the clear areas will continue. Our top 100 malls account for 94% of our NOI and boast sales over $600 per square foot. Our 70 for A malls account for 75% of our NOI and post nearly $700 per square foot. 
On the redevelopment front, we were very pleased to open several major projects during the fourth quarter on time and on budget, including: the extension of Ala Moana, with a return of 11%; the expansion of Baybrook Mall with the return of 9%; the completion -- the complete renovation of Southwest Plaza with the return of 9%; the grand opening of Nordstrom at Ridgedale with a return of 8%; and the grand opening of Nordstrom at Mayfair Mall with the return of 8%. A number of other redevelopment products are across the portfolio. 
As we look to 2016, we will get started on Staten Island Mall's expansion and renovation, the relocation of Nordstrom and Ala Moana and the various redevelopment opportunities within our joint venture with Seritage, 2 of which have just begun at Coronado Center and Staten Island Mall, and we anticipate another 4 to commence at least by year end. 
And lastly, later this year, we will start Norwalk, Connecticut, a new mall anchored by Nordstrom's and Bloomingdale's, contingent upon final approvals by city and state officials. 
On the urban retail update, we have entered into a lease for 23,374 square feet with Coach Inc. to open a global flagship for the Coach brand and at Stuart Weitzman at 685 Fifth Avenue. At 730 Fifth Avenue, we renewed the lease of Bulgari. And as I mentioned earlier, we sold our 10% interest in 522 Fifth Avenue, which we acquired in 2014. The IRR on this investment is almost 50%. Our improved outlook for 2016 continues to be based on our key growth drivers: improved occupancy, positive leasing spreads and incremental income from our redevelopment activity. These organic sources of growth and GDP's irreplaceable portfolio are the basis of our outlook this year and beyond. 
Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to recognize our teams located at our Eastern Seaboard properties for literal weathering the storm that hit a little over a week ago. Due to the severity of the storm, a number of our properties closed early so people could get home safely and remain closed until it was safe to reopen. Our teams worked together tirelessly over the weekend to measure the storm's impact and to determine when to reopen. You know who you are, and I sincerely thank each of you for your dedication to GGP. 
What I'd like to do -- with that, I'd like to turn over to Michael to review financial results in more detail and expand upon our expectations for 2016.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. First, turning to the fourth quarter. As you know FFO per share came in at $0.43, putting us at the high end of our guidance range. The $10 million ahead was approximately $5 million from debt and expected s
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. First, turning to the fourth quarter. As you know FFO per share came in at $0.43, putting us at the high end of our guidance range. The $10 million ahead was approximately $5 million from debt and expected same-store NOI, $4 million of which is related better-than-expected net real estate tax recoveries. And we had about a $1 million higher-than-expected lease-term fees. The remaining $5 million came from a small land sale and somewhat better-than-expected interest expense. Our development projects contributed $9 million of growth in the fourth quarter, which was consistent with our prior forecast. 
Turning to our plan for 2016, please remember, my remarks are intended to be point on a range. We are increasing our FFO guidance range to $1.52 to $1.56 for midpoint of a $1.54 or about 7% growth. The increase, as Sandeep noted, some of which comes from leasing activity that occurred in late December an additional expense savings across various line items. These offset an additional $8.5 million in interest expense that we will have on our variable rate debt. 
I think it's helpful to review our 2016 guidance model given that the 2015 numbers are now final. The numbers in our model reflect the recent sale at Eastridge, Provo Towne Centre, Owings Mills and 522 Fifth Avenue.
We continue to expect same-store NOI growth of 4% to 5% on a base of approximately $2.24 billion. Development projects are expected to contribute approximately $40 million for same-store NOI growth in 2016, consistent with what we said in last quarter's prior -- previously stated guidance. We expect EBITDA growth of 8% to 9% on a base of approximately $2.1 billion. We previously said about 8% EBITDA growth and the incremental up in guidance adds to the EBITDA growth rate of about 50 basis points. Expected EBITDA growth would be about 4.5% to 5.5% without the condo development we mentioned last quarter. And we expect FFO to be around $1.475 billion with a share count expected of around $960 million. The previous guidance was about $10 million less. 
For the first quarter of 2016, our expectations are same-store NOI of around 4% growth or approximately $555 million. We expect development to contribute around $9 million of same-store NOI for the first quarter. We expect EBITDA of approximately $525 million or growth of 6.5% to 7%. And we expect FFO in the range of $325 million to $345 million or FFO per share of $0.34 to $0.36 representing growth of approximately 8.7% per share at the midpoint. And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: So Steve, one is you're absolutely right, I won't comment on the rent per square foot on the transaction. And as I've -- as we've maintained -- we buy these assets and we stabilize them to a 5% to 6% yield. And it did come in as performer. We will deliver the space to Coach by May of this year. And we will evaluate how we should handle the transaction going forward, whether we hold or sell. It is our job to allocate capital. It's also our job to make sure that we prune assets and we recycle capital, so we will evaluate that later in the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, we actually do believe that this year will be better than last year. And we mentioned in several meetings at NAREIT. We've always had concern over a couple of tenants. I think the jury is still out on those tenants. And so we are not in a rush t
componenttext: So again, we actually do believe that this year will be better than last year. And we mentioned in several meetings at NAREIT. We've always had concern over a couple of tenants. I think the jury is still out on those tenants. And so we are not in a rush to change our guidance, which as we've mentioned, we had reflected a -- we were conservative in holding back a reserve for bankruptcies. I think we have to see how the first quarter goes before we can reverse any of those expectations.

componenttext: So, Michael, you're Canadian, you should ask that question. It's not on the Canadian thing to do. So as we've maintained consistently our -- and as I give my original comments, the board is always prepared. This is not the first time we've had this experience, so we've had it with Ackman in the past. We've had it with other companies in the past, so our board has always been prepared. We have corporate guidelines listed, which sort of allows us to understand just likely different, I think, than in the case of Rouse. And so we are prudent, and we will do what's right for the shareholder. We always have to maintain that.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When you move away from A and really top B+ malls, everybody wants the group that more together is 1 giant pot. Our view is every assets has its own business plan, its own s
componenttext: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When you move away from A and really top B+ malls, everybody wants the group that more together is 1 giant pot. Our view is every assets has its own business plan, its own story, its own leverage requirements. We did 3B malls in the fourth quarter and got what we thought were pretty good deals considering the volatility in the marketplace. We have a couple of B malls that we have coming due this year, and we would expect to be able to address them successfully. The market has gotten more volatile in terms of dealers committing spreads. The treasuries have come down. You haven't really seen a lot of change in the overall interest rates that you're being quoted.

componenttext: Again, we've maintained that in our last quarterly call that we have held a credit reserve because we anticipated at the time, several large bankruptcies to occur in 2016. And the jury is out whether they will occur in 2016. And so this will spend this moment in time. We're going to  maintain our course and hold our conservative credit reserve.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Alex Goldfarb from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question is on the Street retail, Sandeep, you sort of mentioned the potential to sell assets as you lease them up, stabilize them. Previously, I thought that you guys have spoken about wanting to develop a portfolio, sort of akin to a mall-type squ
componenttext: First question is on the Street retail, Sandeep, you sort of mentioned the potential to sell assets as you lease them up, stabilize them. Previously, I thought that you guys have spoken about wanting to develop a portfolio, sort of akin to a mall-type square footage and Street retail. So can you just sort of walk-through the differences? Maybe there is a difference between certain properties where what's done is done and therefore, the best opportunity is to sell versus the Street retail assets that you would keep to maintain over time?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, what I did say was I said we would evaluate like we evaluate all our assets and determine based upon the growth rates, based upon our partnership interest, which ones we would hold long term and which ones we would sell. At this moment in time, our
componenttext: Again, what I did say was I said we would evaluate like we evaluate all our assets and determine based upon the growth rates, based upon our partnership interest, which ones we would hold long term and which ones we would sell. At this moment in time, our intent is to hold the assets that we have at 685 and 730 Fifth Avenue. But we will make that decision as the year goes on. I think 730 Fifth Avenue, you can assume will be a long-term hold. And the others, we will evaluate based upon our partnership interest with our partners.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Does that have anything to do with recent sort of changes or softness in Street retailer? Or that's -- it seems to be a little bit of a shift, so just sort of curious.
componenttext: Does that have anything to do with recent sort of changes or softness in Street retailer? Or that's -- it seems to be a little bit of a shift, so just sort of curious.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, it will be a little bit in the reverse because it's huge demand institutional and private wealth demand at very aggressive cap rates, I would say, 2 to 3 cap for New York City real estate. And we've been able to achieve our pro forma rents, s
componenttext: So actually, it will be a little bit in the reverse because it's huge demand institutional and private wealth demand at very aggressive cap rates, I would say, 2 to 3 cap for New York City real estate. And we've been able to achieve our pro forma rents, so if anything, it may be prudent to take advantage of the major disconnect in private and public pricing. And we will evaluate that, like I said, as the year goes on.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications, articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention fees and all that, dealing with new regulations. So as y
componenttext: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications, articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention fees and all that, dealing with new regulations. So as you guys look at your financing platform and strategy, is there any view to potentially shift away or broaden away from the mortgage, whether it's life or CMBS? Or do you guys view that the issues that the mortgage market you're dealing with right now will eventually be worked through before you guys get to the more meaningful maturities in '17, '18, '19?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, I think we're going to stick with the mortgage markets as our primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers of paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces. And that i
componenttext: You know, I think we're going to stick with the mortgage markets as our primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers of paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces. And that is forcing the market to kind of deal with that element. From a long-term perspective, I actually think that's a very beneficial element. It's going to make the underwriting cleaner. It's going to make it the better properties. And the better sponsors are going to benefit in an environment where there is more of a focus on quality of earnings and quality of assets. So I don't have to sell -- I'm not making a comment of the CMBS market overall, i just think that GGP, given its asset base and its history, will continue to thrive in the mortgage market.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum from UBS.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ross Nussbaum from UBS.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. Just one quick one, Mike, I was wondering if you can talk about the same-store results this quarter? What particular drove kind of the big uplift? Was it just redevelopments or was there some earlier-than-expected condo gains, ma
componenttext: Jeremy Metz on with Ross. Just one quick one, Mike, I was wondering if you can talk about the same-store results this quarter? What particular drove kind of the big uplift? Was it just redevelopments or was there some earlier-than-expected condo gains, maybe from Ala Moana starting to creep in there?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The Ala Moana condo gains don't hit us until approximately the second quarter. And again, it depends on the construction process, the -- anything that was onetime that we knew about, we had already put into the guidance. It was really, as I said, it was a
componenttext: The Ala Moana condo gains don't hit us until approximately the second quarter. And again, it depends on the construction process, the -- anything that was onetime that we knew about, we had already put into the guidance. It was really, as I said, it was a helpful net tax recovery, which is not unusual at the end of the year. We got a little bit more in lease termination income so $5 million in a particular quarter is almost 1% on the same-store NOI growth.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just turning to redevelopment, just in terms of Miami and Staten Island. I guess first, maybe Staten Island costs went up again. I don't know if that's -- you had mentioned the Seritage box you just started working on. But obviously, yields
componenttext: Okay. And then just turning to redevelopment, just in terms of Miami and Staten Island. I guess first, maybe Staten Island costs went up again. I don't know if that's -- you had mentioned the Seritage box you just started working on. But obviously, yields were unchanged. I'm guessing you'll be able to recover them on rents. And then in terms of Miami, it looks like you took your ownership up just a little a bit in the design. So I was just wondering who was selling on the other side there and if there's an opportunity, I guess, desire to increase that further in 2016?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, in the case of Staten Island as we refine our costs, which are now finalized because we brought out the trade and that's based upon the final approval that we've gotten. And again, we've done a fair amount of the leasing, so it has no impact on
componenttext: So again, in the case of Staten Island as we refine our costs, which are now finalized because we brought out the trade and that's based upon the final approval that we've gotten. And again, we've done a fair amount of the leasing, so it has no impact on the yield. So the yields are the same, if not slightly better. So I think that construction is about the Staten. And as you started in the way of thinking, it gets going in full force in about 90 days. And that's a $200 million-ish or so expansion. Miami Design District, we've always liked the asset. And it's -- even though we have a 12.5% interest, we felt that there was the ability to incrementally increase our ownership interest in the property. We had an option to increase it by 2.5%, and it came half from Dacra and half from L Capital. And I think we'll see if more comes available and if we are a player to continue to buy more of that asset. But at this moment in time, we're happy with the 15% interest that we will evaluate as the yield goes on, whether we deploy more capital into that asset.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the comments on the private discount and maybe taking advantage of the still very strong cap rates on Street retail market. I was just curious if you were to monetize those assets, if you do have some development capital to spend
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the comments on the private discount and maybe taking advantage of the still very strong cap rates on Street retail market. I was just curious if you were to monetize those assets, if you do have some development capital to spend. But just curious where you think that money would go towards? That's my first question.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of
componenttext: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of those assets, there's obviously a very positive impact to debt-to-EBITDA ratio. And with the additional capital, again we'll evaluate to make capital allocation decisions between what we've done in the past, which is the debt paydown or reinvestments in our development pipeline. And at this level of our stock, we're not purchasers of our own stock. We've been very prudent about that. We're cognizant about the leveraged issues, and we only look to buy stock within sort of deep discount in what we believe is NAV. And we've been prudent and showed you our hand at what that price would be. And so we would evaluate to either pay down debt or reinvested in further development activities that it should be.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just understanding that it sounds like you don't consider stock today at a significant discount. I think you're buying back sort of $25. But to the extent that you're still trading at a discount to NAV, just curious I know we've had many, m
componenttext: Okay. And then just understanding that it sounds like you don't consider stock today at a significant discount. I think you're buying back sort of $25. But to the extent that you're still trading at a discount to NAV, just curious I know we've had many, many discussions about leverage and your thoughts on leverage and that kind of thing. But it does seems that, that's clearly 1 thing that does weigh in on the stock relative to some others. If the discount persist, I mean is that something you would ever revisit in terms of the overall leverage?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where we already, as I mentioned to you, you ask what I would do with the capital one our debt-to-EBITDA ratio for 2016 will be in the 8 to 8.5 range, as Michael said. You asked me what I would do with the capital, I've proven that last year, we paid down
componenttext: Where we already, as I mentioned to you, you ask what I would do with the capital one our debt-to-EBITDA ratio for 2016 will be in the 8 to 8.5 range, as Michael said. You asked me what I would do with the capital, I've proven that last year, we paid down $600 million of debt to the Ala Moana proceeds. And if we did sell another retail assets, we would either pay down debt at this stage of the game or redeploy the capital in redevelopment activities, which could use 8% or better returns, which again has the same impact, which is to increase EBITDA and reduce debt-to-EBITDA ratio.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttextpreview: Paul, the answer is yes. If you look at the retail productivity in Ala Moana, it was down almost 8% to 10% in Fashion Show Mall and Vegas was down 3.5% to 4%. So we did see a fair amount of impact. If you actually take out Ala Moana and Vegas, our retail
componenttext: Paul, the answer is yes. If you look at the retail productivity in Ala Moana, it was down almost 8% to 10% in Fashion Show Mall and Vegas was down 3.5% to 4%. So we did see a fair amount of impact. If you actually take out Ala Moana and Vegas, our retail sales, which I said earlier, went up by 4.5% would have gone up well over 5%.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: And at the low end, could you perhaps provide a few sales growth metrics for malls under $450 a foot?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: They've been, honestly, at the lower end of a spectrum. However, they've been positive. The B and B+ malls have been positive, flat to up 1% or 2%. Obviously, the disparity is a lot greater in the -- to the A mall, which has grown much faster than B and B
componenttext: They've been, honestly, at the lower end of a spectrum. However, they've been positive. The B and B+ malls have been positive, flat to up 1% or 2%. Obviously, the disparity is a lot greater in the -- to the A mall, which has grown much faster than B and B+ malls. And obviously, the B and B+ malls are positive as a result of bankruptcies of tenants that come out of the equation.

componenttext: Store's closing, which I view to be a positive. We were able to obviously not renew stores that were lower productivity. We were able to replace them with higher productivity retailers. So we actually view that to be -- to be a positive.

componenttext: So we were actually pleased to be able to get that space back. It was a very low-productivity store that we were happy to be able to have the option to recapture it.

componenttext: Some of the growth came from the urban leasing, that's in our nonsame-store NOI. The rest of the increase came from items such as G&A, lower-than-expected tax provision. It wasn't that the same-store NOI per se that changed.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's supposed to be for me, it's Mike Mueller. I think the average portfolio occupancy cost is in the mid-13s for 2015. I was wondering can you talk about how that compares to where you're signing leases? Where the leases signed in 2015 were?
componenttext: It's supposed to be for me, it's Mike Mueller. I think the average portfolio occupancy cost is in the mid-13s for 2015. I was wondering can you talk about how that compares to where you're signing leases? Where the leases signed in 2015 were?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's again, been very consistent. If you're in the A mall business, you're at 15% to 17%; if you're on the B+ business, you have between 13% to 15%; and if you're B business, it is what it is. And so it's sort of -- the new leases are getting signs depend
componenttext: It's again, been very consistent. If you're in the A mall business, you're at 15% to 17%; if you're on the B+ business, you have between 13% to 15%; and if you're B business, it is what it is. And so it's sort of -- the new leases are getting signs depending on the productivity of the center. And the range, as I told you, sort of averages out to 13% again. Please appreciate, you only have 500 square feet out of 60 million square feet that rolls every year so the impact of that occupancy costs is not going to be dramatic year-over-year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttextpreview: We are hopeful buying bankruptcies to get that 92.3%-ish from an occupancy up to 93% by year end. So that's our goal, to reduce the temp down by, call it, 50 to 100 basis points.
componenttext: We are hopeful buying bankruptcies to get that 92.3%-ish from an occupancy up to 93% by year end. So that's our goal, to reduce the temp down by, call it, 50 to 100 basis points.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And could you maybe talk about, I mean, obviously, most of your redevelopment capital, you're -- according to our estimates, you were obtaining about $600 million of cash flow every year that you're planning back in your redevelopment. How a
componenttext: Great, great. And could you maybe talk about, I mean, obviously, most of your redevelopment capital, you're -- according to our estimates, you were obtaining about $600 million of cash flow every year that you're planning back in your redevelopment. How are you -- as you think about the allegation to fortifying existing A asset as opposed to turning some of your B malls into potentially A malls, maybe talk about the thought process and also maybe touch upon what you think is happening at Southwest Plaza in Littleton?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls and fortification of the A malls. And we haven't done much beyond, as you know, densification for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B, B+ assets and
componenttext: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls and fortification of the A malls. And we haven't done much beyond, as you know, densification for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B, B+ assets and invest capital in them to -- come to mind one is Southwest Plaza, as you mentioned. We were very pleased with the opening of Southwest Plaza. The food hall and the retailer productivity has gone up dramatically. We see that mall, which is probably a 300 [indiscernible] mall with a 50% occupancy, 60% occupancy to fly into 90% by year end, and sales productivity to be well over $400 a square foot. The traffic was very good during the holiday season so it seems that, that investment will pay out handsomely. The return on our investment was almost full 9% there. So we deployed whatever $70 million to $80 million and got a 9% return. So we would like to be so far successful. And again, we were able to do that because the demographics justify the expenditure. We did do that at 1 more mall, we did that in Lynnhaven Mall in the Norfolk market. But we invested, I don't know, $40-ish million or so. And I think, that mall now almost $500 plus mall. And so again, when the demographics are prevalent investing in the B, B plus assets, you do get an opportunity to upgrade the asset to a high quality asset. So 70% to 80% of our capital gets deployed into what we would call A malls.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next version comes from Rich Moore from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next version comes from Rich Moore from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're off to a pretty good start this year in terms of B mall dispositions. And I'm curious how much more of that you have in the pipeline, and maybe how aggressive you're going to be at targeting dispositions in [indiscernible]?
componenttext: You're off to a pretty good start this year in terms of B mall dispositions. And I'm curious how much more of that you have in the pipeline, and maybe how aggressive you're going to be at targeting dispositions in [indiscernible]?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we've been -- Richard, we've said consistently, our job is to one, keep pruning the lower quality assets. We are not with the B malls are not very cap-rate sensitive because our business, as I mentioned earlier, hundred of our malls, which are B+ or be
componenttext: As we've been -- Richard, we've said consistently, our job is to one, keep pruning the lower quality assets. We are not with the B malls are not very cap-rate sensitive because our business, as I mentioned earlier, hundred of our malls, which are B+ or better gives us 94% percent of our NOI. So the B malls are probably 3% or 4%, and other assets are probably 1% or 2% of the NOI. And so -- we're not cap-rate sensitive. But their market is not deep enough, and we will continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically in a disciplined manner. And so you could expect us to dispose all B malls as the year progresses.

componenttext: It's a very, it's a very thin market. You generally got the money sources to be the same people that tie up with different local entrepreneurs throughout the country. And so it's a fairly thin market. It's also conditioned upon the financing markets. And I mean the Eastridge mall was financed by Bank of China. The Provo Mall was financed by Bank of America. So there is a market at the back market, but it's obviously, not as deep as well.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, what we are seeing is that there is a move of several retailers that used to occupy space in A and B+ malls who gotten price part of the market which are mall operators, so mall tenants going into the B mall. So we are -- our occupancy is act
componenttext: So actually, what we are seeing is that there is a move of several retailers that used to occupy space in A and B+ malls who gotten price part of the market which are mall operators, so mall tenants going into the B mall. So we are -- our occupancy is actually doing quite well in the B mall sector. We've dedicated a team of professionals and leasing people to focus on the bottom, call it, 15, 18 malls to give them more focus so that we can make sure that the leasing activities stay strong. Because as I've always maintained the B malls, like their -- it's an occupancy play, not an occupancy in rate play. But the demand seems to be there. You've got tenants like Dress Barn, maurices, rue21, The Children's Place, Foot Locker, Victoria's Secret who have continued to take space in those malls. And also you've got the bigger players, the bigger users of space, the value retailers that are coming into those malls. So we actually see a healthy lease-up. Again, it's an occupancy play, not an occupancy rate play.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: So based on those comments, I think that those comments would be similar to what we may hear from the owners of the predominantly owned B malls. Is it simply the lack of financing or the perceived financing risk of that comes with these B malls and makes the markets so thin?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's 2 things. I think it's the equity backers who are skittish on long-term potential and I think, it's the debt markets. Although we've been successful in selling -- I mean we sold Provo, which was a $230 a square foot mall in the -- in January
componenttext: I think it's 2 things. I think it's the equity backers who are skittish on long-term potential and I think, it's the debt markets. Although we've been successful in selling -- I mean we sold Provo, which was a $230 a square foot mall in the -- in January a week ago. It closed a week ago. And so there is a market, it's there.

componenttext: And then maybe just 1 last question on the top of the mall quality spectrum, you have plenty of very high-end A malls that make up a good percentage of NOI or value. componenttext: As I mentioned in my comments, actually there was a disconnect between private and public market valuations in the A+ malls. And there is a tremendous demand by institutional investors. Again, the board and I view that disconnect will evaluate at what stage we decide to bring in joint venture partners for a portion of those assets if we do it all because your point's well taken, and we're in deep thought.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In light of your comments on holiday traffic, do you think you'll comment on traffic going forward? I think in the past you didn't like to discuss it because it came from external/unreliable sources, but now you're measuring in your malls?
componenttext: In light of your comments on holiday traffic, do you think you'll comment on traffic going forward? I think in the past you didn't like to discuss it because it came from external/unreliable sources, but now you're measuring in your malls?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as we continue to measure them, we will -- we're happy to give the data because the irony is that the mall traffic is actually up. One of the biggest pain points during the holiday season was lack of parking. So we, obviously, seeing people come t
componenttext: I think as we continue to measure them, we will -- we're happy to give the data because the irony is that the mall traffic is actually up. One of the biggest pain points during the holiday season was lack of parking. So we, obviously, seeing people come to the mall. We are seeing them stay longer at the mall. They're shopping a lot of fewer stores when they come into the mall, but they definitely roaming the malls and shopping. So if you've got the product, the retailer -- the consumer is redoing their research on their mobile device and coming into the mall to shop, which is why still to date, from a softer perspective, almost 95% of all stuff that we bought in the bricks-and-mortar store. And I think, the other factor that very few people really included in the equation is that the return rate on the soft goods is incredibly high. I think it's 38% of e-commerce purchases of soft goods that have bought online a return in the brick-and-mortar store. So to really get a true and proper understanding until the retailer start to show you exactly what the return rate is and how its being impacted is really hard to evaluate in this omni-channel world why one growth is bigger than the other because you have to take the return rate into account, which really no one does. And just case in point, you go to Amazon opening brick-and-mortar bookstores and their goal is to open, as I understand, 300 to 400 bookstores. And it should sort of sit back and say, the last mile is all important, which is why Bonobos is opening, brick-and-mortar stores and Warby Packer is opening brick-and-mortar stores. And Birchbox is cutting their overheads to open brick-and-mortar stores. It's a very interesting evolution because the cost of the last mile is that important. And again, the mall business, you have to appreciate, which is more focused on fashion, is very different than a stable business where you buying commodity. And so in the mall business, the impact of e-commerce is a lot less. It's actually your friend, not your enemy.

And so I would sit back and say the 90% -- I'm making that number up. But in large percent of the 20 million is allocable to the inline tenants.
