componenttext: So Steve, one is you're absolutely right, I won't comment on the rent per square foot on the transaction. And as I've -- as we've maintained -- we buy these assets and we stabilize them to a 5% to 6% yield. And it did come in as performer. We will deliver the space to Coach by May of this year. And we will evaluate how we should handle the transaction going forward, whether we hold or sell. It is our job to allocate capital. It's also our job to make sure that we prune assets and we recycle capital, so we will evaluate that later in the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess second question, just given that we're now through the holiday shopping season and we're sort of in the period where tenants may file for bankruptcy or talk about store closings, just kind of what is your expectation? How has that change
componenttext: Okay. And I guess second question, just given that we're now through the holiday shopping season and we're sort of in the period where tenants may file for bankruptcy or talk about store closings, just kind of what is your expectation? How has that changed as we kind of look forward? And has that changed at all in the way you think about your guidance for this year?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, we actually do believe that this year will be better than last year. And we mentioned in several meetings at NAREIT. We've always had concern over a couple of tenants. I think the jury is still out on those tenants. And so we are not in a rush t
componenttext: So again, we actually do believe that this year will be better than last year. And we mentioned in several meetings at NAREIT. We've always had concern over a couple of tenants. I think the jury is still out on those tenants. And so we are not in a rush to change our guidance, which as we've mentioned, we had reflected a -- we were conservative in holding back a reserve for bankruptcies. I think we have to see how the first quarter goes before we can reverse any of those expectations.

componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman here with Christy. And Sandeep, I'm not going to ask you to comment on any rumors about GGP. And I'm just curious, as you think about your role and the independent board members, when that occurred, is there any level of preparedness that you're going through either engaging bankers or lawyers so that you are well prepared in the event that they potentially do the same thing with GGP. And I understand all the shareholder agreements but I think it's helpful for investors to understand how well prepared you would be and the independent board members would be, should they make a similar approach out of the blue.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Michael, you're Canadian, you shouldn't ask that question. It's not the Canadian thing to do. So as we've maintained consistently our -- and as I gave in my original comments, the board is always prepared. This is not the first time we've had this expe
componenttext: So Michael, you're Canadian, you shouldn't ask that question. It's not the Canadian thing to do. So as we've maintained consistently our -- and as I gave in my original comments, the board is always prepared. This is not the first time we've had this experience, so we've had it with Ackman in the past. We've had it with other companies in the past, so our board has always been prepared. We have corporate guidelines listed, which sort of allows us to understand just slightly different, I think, than in the case of Rouse. And so we are prudent, and we will do what's right for the shareholder. We always have to maintain that.

componenttext: The timing of the second payment on Ala Moana is the fourth quarter, consistent with certain construction time lines. We've always expected it to be at that time. And we don't expect our debt level to be higher between now and the end of the year. Hopefully, it will start to come down. We think we're at about 8 to 8.5 debt -- net-debt-to-EBITDA number for 2016.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Michael, just given your recent financings, I'm wondering if maybe you could give us some observations around the financing market for malls around the sort of across the quality spectrum and how that may be changed in the last 3 to 6 months?
componenttext: And then, Michael, just given your recent financings, I'm wondering if maybe you could give us some observations around the financing market for malls around the sort of across the quality spectrum and how that may be changed in the last 3 to 6 months?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When you move away from the A and really top B+ malls, everybody wants to group them all together as 1 giant pot. Our view is every asset has its own business plan, its own
componenttext: A malls is never really in the discussion, very strong market, a lot of appetite. When you move away from the A and really top B+ malls, everybody wants to group them all together as 1 giant pot. Our view is every asset has its own business plan, its own story, its own leverage requirements. We did 3 B malls in the fourth quarter and got what we thought were pretty good deals considering the volatility in the marketplace. We have a couple of B malls that we have coming due this year, and we would expect to be able to address them successfully. The market has gotten more volatile in terms of dealers committing spreads. The treasuries have come down. You haven't really seen a lot of change in the overall interest rates that you're being quoted.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we've maintained that in our last quarterly call that we have held a credit reserve because we anticipated at the time, several large bankruptcies to occur in 2016. And the jury is out whether they will occur in 2016. And I think usually, we will w
componenttext: Again, we've maintained that in our last quarterly call that we have held a credit reserve because we anticipated at the time, several large bankruptcies to occur in 2016. And the jury is out whether they will occur in 2016. And I think usually, we will wait till the end of the first quarter because that is a time when you start to see the telltale signs whether someone's going to file. And so at this moment in time we're going to maintain our course and hold our conservative credit reserve.

componenttext: Again, what I did say was I said we would evaluate like we evaluate all our assets and determine based upon the growth rates, based upon our partnership interest, which ones we would hold long term and which ones we would sell. At this moment in time, our intent is to hold the assets that we have at 685 and 730 Fifth Avenue. But we will make that decision as the year goes on. I think 730 Fifth Avenue, you can assume will be a long-term hold. And the others, we will evaluate based upon our partnership interest with our partners.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Does that have anything to do with recent sort of changes or softness in Street retail? Or that's -- it seems to be a little bit of a shift, so just sort of curious.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, it will be a little bit in the reverse because it's huge demand institutional and private wealth demand at very aggressive cap rates, I would say, 2 to 3 cap for New York City real estate. And we've been able to achieve our pro forma rents, s
componenttext: So actually, it will be a little bit in the reverse because it's huge demand institutional and private wealth demand at very aggressive cap rates, I would say, 2 to 3 cap for New York City real estate. And we've been able to achieve our pro forma rents, so if anything, it may be prudent to take advantage of the major disconnect in private and public pricing. And we will evaluate that, like I said, as the year goes on.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications, articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention pieces and all that, dealing with new regulations. So as
componenttext: Okay and then the second question is for Mike. Mike, just in some of the recent CMBS trade publications, articles on volatility based on dealer inventory levels being low and issues with B retention pieces and all that, dealing with new regulations. So as you guys look at your financing platform and strategy, is there any view to potentially shift away or broaden away from the mortgage, whether it's life or CMBS? Or do you guys view that the issues that the mortgage markets you're dealing with right now will eventually be worked through before you guys get to the more meaningful maturities in '17, '18, '19?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we're going to stick with the mortgage markets as our primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers of paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces. And that is forcing
componenttext: I think we're going to stick with the mortgage markets as our primary outlet. Keep in mind that one of the big changes in the CMBS market is the requirement for issuers of paper to retain more of the, I believe, of the riskier pieces. And that is forcing the market to kind of deal with that element. From a long-term perspective, I actually think that's a very beneficial element. It's going to make the underwriting cleaner. It's going to make it the better properties. And the better sponsors are going to benefit in an environment where there is more of a focus on quality of earnings and quality of assets. So I don't necessarily -- I'm not making a comment of the CMBS market overall, I just think that GGP, given its asset base and its history, will continue to thrive in the mortgage market.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

Was it just redevelopments or was there some earlier-than-expected condo gains, maybe from Ala Moana starting to creep in there?

componenttext: The Ala Moana condo gains don't hit us until approximately the second quarter. And again, it depends on the construction process, the -- anything that was onetime that we knew about, we had already put into the guidance. It was really, as I said, it was a helpful net tax recovery, which is not unusual at the end of the year. We got a little bit more in lease termination income so $5 million in a particular quarter is almost 1% on the same-store NOI growth.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just turning to redevelopment, just in terms of Miami and Staten Island. I guess first, maybe Staten Island costs went up again. I don't know if that's -- you had mentioned the Seritage box you just started working on. But obviously, yields
componenttext: Okay. And then just turning to redevelopment, just in terms of Miami and Staten Island. I guess first, maybe Staten Island costs went up again. I don't know if that's -- you had mentioned the Seritage box you just started working on. But obviously, yields were unchanged. I'm guessing you'll be able to recover them on rents. And then in terms of Miami, it looks like you took your ownership up just a little a bit in the Design District. So I was just wondering who was selling on the other side there and if there's an opportunity, I guess, desire to increase that further in 2016?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So again, in the case of Staten Island as we refine our costs, which are now finalized because we bought out the trade and that's based upon the final approval that we've gotten. And again, we've done a fair amount of the leasing, so it has no impact on t
componenttext: So again, in the case of Staten Island as we refine our costs, which are now finalized because we bought out the trade and that's based upon the final approval that we've gotten. And again, we've done a fair amount of the leasing, so it has no impact on the yield. So the yields are the same, if not slightly better. So I think that construction is about at Staten. And as you started in the way of thinking, it gets going in full force in about 90 days. And that's a $200 million-ish or so expansion. Miami Design District, we've always liked the asset. And it's -- even though we have a 12.5% interest, we felt that there was the ability to incrementally increase our ownership interest in the property. We had an option to increase it by 2.5%, and it came half from Dacra and half from L Capital. And I think we'll see if more comes available and if we are a player to continue to buy more of that asset. But at this moment in time, we're happy with the 15% interest that we will evaluate as the yield goes on, whether we deploy more capital into that asset.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Vincent Chao from Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to go back to the comments on the private discount and maybe taking advantage of the still very strong cap rates on Street retail market. I was just curious if you were to monetize those assets, if you do have some development capital to spend
componenttext: Just wanted to go back to the comments on the private discount and maybe taking advantage of the still very strong cap rates on Street retail market. I was just curious if you were to monetize those assets, if you do have some development capital to spend. But just curious where you think that money would go towards? That's my first question.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of
componenttext: One of the interesting things, as we've said in the past, is that we bought the urban retail assets, it has impacted our debt-to-EBITDA ratio because we've taken on debt to buy those assets with no income on the other side. And so if one does sell any of those assets, there's obviously a very positive impact to debt-to-EBITDA ratio. And with the additional capital, again we'll evaluate to make capital allocation decisions between what we've done in the past, which is the debt paydown or reinvestments in our development pipeline. And at this level of our stock, we're not purchasers of our own stock. We've been very prudent about that. We're cognizant about the leveraged issues, and we only look to buy stock within sort of deep discount in what we believe is NAV. And we've been prudent and showed you our hand at what that price would be. And so we would evaluate to either pay down debt or reinvest it in further development activities that it should be.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just understanding that it sounds like you don't consider stock today at a significant discount. I think you're buying back sort of $25. But to the extent that you're still trading at a discount to NAV, just curious I know we've had many, m
componenttext: Okay. And then just understanding that it sounds like you don't consider stock today at a significant discount. I think you're buying back sort of $25. But to the extent that you're still trading at a discount to NAV, just curious I know we've had many, many discussions about leverage and your thoughts on leverage and that kind of thing. But it does seems that, that's clearly one thing that does weigh in on the stock relative to some others. If the discount persist, I mean is that something you would ever revisit in terms of the overall leverage?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Where we already, as I mentioned to you, you asked me what I would do with the capital, one, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio for 2016 will be in the 8 to 8.5 range, as Michael said. You asked me what I would do with the capital, I've proven the thesis that last
componenttext: Where we already, as I mentioned to you, you asked me what I would do with the capital, one, our debt-to-EBITDA ratio for 2016 will be in the 8 to 8.5 range, as Michael said. You asked me what I would do with the capital, I've proven the thesis that last year we paid down $600 million of debt to the Ala Moana proceeds. And if we did sell another retail asset, we would either pay down debt at this stage of the game or redeploy the capital in redevelopment activities, which could use 8% or better returns, which again has the same impact, which is to increase EBITDA and reduce debt-to-EBITDA ratio.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: On next question comes from Paul Adornato from BMO Capital Markets.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you noticed any impact from the international luxury shopper the way your peer reported last week.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, the answer is yes. If you look at the retail productivity in Ala Moana, it was down almost 8% to 10% in Fashion Show Mall and Vegas was down 3.5% to 4%. So we did see a fair amount of impact. If you actually take out Ala Moana and Vegas, our retail
componenttext: Paul, the answer is yes. If you look at the retail productivity in Ala Moana, it was down almost 8% to 10% in Fashion Show Mall and Vegas was down 3.5% to 4%. So we did see a fair amount of impact. If you actually take out Ala Moana and Vegas, our retail sales, which I said earlier went up by 4.5% would have gone up well over 5%.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And at the low end, could you perhaps provide a few sales growth metrics for malls under $450 a foot?
componenttext: And at the low end, could you perhaps provide a few sales growth metrics for malls under $450 a foot?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: They've been, honestly, at the lower end of the spectrum. However, they've been positive. The B and B+ malls have been positive, flat to up 1% or 2%. Obviously, the disparity is a lot greater in the -- to the A mall, which has grown much faster than B and
componenttext: They've been, honestly, at the lower end of the spectrum. However, they've been positive. The B and B+ malls have been positive, flat to up 1% or 2%. Obviously, the disparity is a lot greater in the -- to the A mall, which has grown much faster than B and B+ malls. And obviously, the B and B+ malls are positive as a result of bankruptcies of tenants that come out of the equation.

componenttext: Stores closing, which I view to be a positive. We were able to obviously not renew stores that were lower productivity. We were able to replace them with higher productivity retailers. So we actually view that to be -- to be a positive.

componenttext: So we were actually pleased to be able to get that space back. Again, we are working on a redevelopment plan to potentially relocate the movie theater and replace the existing movie theater with more restaurants. So it's actually going to be more entertainment. If you know the shopping center, it sits in the midpoint. It doesn't really -- it doesn't anchor either end of the mall. It was a very low-productivity store that we were happy to be able to have the option to recapture it.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Michael, you mentioned that development would add about $9 million of NOI to the first quarter and $40 million for the full year. And as a follow-up, how should we think about the yield run rate on the development assets as we exit 2016 and head into 2017?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Okay, the first one you're going to have to repeat because you went real fast. The second one, I think, that the yield on the current spend is north of 8%. And it ramps up to the end, so where we get to 9% to 10%. Can you repeat the first question a little bit slowly, please?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's supposed to be for me, it's Mike Mueller. I think the average portfolio occupancy cost is in the mid-13s for 2015. I was wondering can you talk about how that compares to where you're signing leases? Where the leases signed in 2015 were?
componenttext: I think it's supposed to be for me, it's Mike Mueller. I think the average portfolio occupancy cost is in the mid-13s for 2015. I was wondering can you talk about how that compares to where you're signing leases? Where the leases signed in 2015 were?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's again, been very consistent. If you're in the A mall business, you're at 15% to 17%; if you're in the B+ business, you have between 13% to 15%; and if you're B business, it is what it is. And so it's sort of -- the new leases are getting signed depen
componenttext: It's again, been very consistent. If you're in the A mall business, you're at 15% to 17%; if you're in the B+ business, you have between 13% to 15%; and if you're B business, it is what it is. And so it's sort of -- the new leases are getting signed depending on the productivity of the center. And the range, as I told you, sort of averages out to 13%. Again, please appreciate you only have 500 square feet out of 60 million square feet that rolls every year so the impact of that occupancy cost is not going to be dramatic year-over-year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum from Boenning.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, you guys have about 5% tenancy right now, 97% overall occupancy. Do you expect that you'll see some of that tenancy in the next 12 months be turned into potentially permanent occupancy?
componenttext: Sandeep, you guys have about 5% tenancy right now, 97% overall occupancy. Do you expect that you'll see some of that tenancy in the next 12 months be turned into potentially permanent occupancy?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We are hopeful, barring bankruptcies, to get that 92.3%-ish permanent occupancy up to 93% by year-end. So that's our goal, to reduce the temp down by, call it, 50 to 100 basis points.
componenttext: We are hopeful, barring bankruptcies, to get that 92.3%-ish permanent occupancy up to 93% by year-end. So that's our goal, to reduce the temp down by, call it, 50 to 100 basis points.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, great. And could you maybe talk about, I mean, obviously, most of your redevelopment capital, you're -- according to our estimates, you were paying about $600 million of cash flow every year, I think you're applying back in your redevelopment. How
componenttext: Great, great. And could you maybe talk about, I mean, obviously, most of your redevelopment capital, you're -- according to our estimates, you were paying about $600 million of cash flow every year, I think you're applying back in your redevelopment. How are you -- as you think about the allocation to fortifying existing A asset as opposed to turning some of your B malls into potentially A malls, maybe talk about the thought process and also maybe touch upon what you think is happening at Southwest Plaza in Littleton?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls and fortification of the A malls. And we haven't done much beyond, as you know, densification for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B, B+ assets and
componenttext: So most of our spend, almost 70% to 80% of our spend has been in the A malls and fortification of the A malls. And we haven't done much beyond, as you know, densification for retail purposes at the A malls to date. We did take a couple of B, B+ assets and invest capital in them. Two that come to mind, one is Southwest Plaza, as you mentioned. We were very pleased with the opening of Southwest Plaza. The food hall and the retailer productivity has gone up dramatically. We see that mall, which is probably a $300 mall with a 50% occupancy, 60% occupancy to climb to 90% by year-end, and sales productivity to be well over $400 a square foot. The traffic was very good during the holiday season so it seems that, that investment will pay out handsomely. The return on our investment was almost full 9% there. So we deployed whatever it was, $70 million to $80 million and got a 9% return. So we would like to be so far successful. And again, we were able to do that there because the demographics justify the expenditure. We did do that at one more mall, we did that in Lynnhaven Mall in the Norfolk market. But we invested, I don't know, $40-ish million or so. And I think that mall is now almost a $500 plus mall. And so again, when the demographics are prevalent investing in the B, B plus assets, you do get an opportunity to upgrade the asset to a high-quality asset. So 70% to 80% of our capital gets deployed into what we would call A malls.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Rich Moore from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Rich Moore from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're off to a pretty good start this year in terms of B mall dispositions. And I'm curious how much more of that you have in the pipeline, and maybe how aggressive you're going to be at targeting dispositions in C [ph]?
componenttext: You're off to a pretty good start this year in terms of B mall dispositions. And I'm curious how much more of that you have in the pipeline, and maybe how aggressive you're going to be at targeting dispositions in C [ph]?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As we've been -- Richard, we've said consistently, our job is to one, keep pruning the lower quality assets. We are not, with the B malls, are not very cap-rate sensitive because our business, as I mentioned earlier, 100 of our malls, which are B+ or bett
componenttext: As we've been -- Richard, we've said consistently, our job is to one, keep pruning the lower quality assets. We are not, with the B malls, are not very cap-rate sensitive because our business, as I mentioned earlier, 100 of our malls, which are B+ or better gives us 94% percent of our NOI. So the B malls are probably 3% or 4%, and other assets are probably 1% or 2% of the NOI. And so -- we're not cap-rate sensitive. But their market is not deep enough, and we will continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically in a disciplined manner. And so you could expect us to dispose all B malls as the year progresses.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Sandeep, what is the market like for those assets? I mean is there a lot of interest when you take one to market or is it pretty thin?
componenttext: And Sandeep, what is the market like for those assets? I mean is there a lot of interest when you take one to market or is it pretty thin?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very, our opinion, it's a very thin market. You've generally got the money sources to be the same people that tie up with different local entrepreneurs throughout the country. And so it's a fairly thin market. It's also conditioned upon the financi
componenttext: It's a very, our opinion, it's a very thin market. You've generally got the money sources to be the same people that tie up with different local entrepreneurs throughout the country. And so it's a fairly thin market. It's also conditioned upon the financing markets. And I mean the Eastridge mall was financed by Bank of China. The Provo Mall was financed by Bank of America. So there is a market at the back market, but it's obviously not as deep as well.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from DJ Busch with Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from DJ Busch with Green Street Advisors.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on Rich's question. Knowing that the bottom, call it, 2 dozen or so are not long-term holds and they're not price sensitive. But how do you go about operating those in the meantime? And then compared to the kind of the B+ malls where you
componenttext: Just a follow-up on Rich's question. Knowing that the bottom, call it, 2 dozen or so are not long-term holds and they're not price sensitive. But how do you go about operating those in the meantime? And then compared to the kind of the B+ malls where you said there is some rental demand, what is the demand for space at your B centers right now?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So actually, what we are seeing is that there is a move of several retailers that used to occupy space in A and B+ malls who have gotten priced out of the market, which are mall operators, so mall tenants going into the B mall. So we are -- our occupancy
componenttext: So actually, what we are seeing is that there is a move of several retailers that used to occupy space in A and B+ malls who have gotten priced out of the market, which are mall operators, so mall tenants going into the B mall. So we are -- our occupancy is actually doing quite well in the B mall sector. We've dedicated a team of professionals and leasing people to focus on the bottom, call it, 15, 18 malls to give them more focus so that we can make sure that the leasing activities stay strong. Because as I've always maintained the B malls sector is an occupancy play, not an occupancy in rate play. But the demand seems to be there. You've got tenants like Dress Barn, maurices, rue21, The Children's Place, Foot Locker, Victoria's Secret, who have continued to take space in those malls. And also you've got the bigger players, the bigger users of space, the value retailers that are coming into those malls. So we actually see a healthy lease-up. Again, it's an occupancy play, not an occupancy rate play.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So based on those comments, I think that those comments would be similar to what we may hear from the owners of the predominantly owned B malls. What -- it sounds like there is a demand at that level of mall quality, so what is -- what makes the market so
componenttext: So based on those comments, I think that those comments would be similar to what we may hear from the owners of the predominantly owned B malls. What -- it sounds like there is a demand at that level of mall quality, so what is -- what makes the market so thin if it's not kind of the operational prospects? Is it simply the lack of financing or the perceived financing risk that comes with these B malls and makes the markets so thin?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's 2 things. I think it's the equity backers who are skittish on long-term potential, and I think it's the debt markets. Although we've been successful in selling -- I mean we sold Provo, which was a $230 a square foot mall in the -- in January
componenttext: I think it's 2 things. I think it's the equity backers who are skittish on long-term potential, and I think it's the debt markets. Although we've been successful in selling -- I mean we sold Provo, which was a $230 a square foot mall in the -- in January a week ago. It closed a week ago. And so there is a market, it's there.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just one last question on the top of the mall quality spectrum, you have plenty of very high-end A malls that make up a good percentage of NOI or value. If you see your discount grow even further, the discount to where your stock's trading
componenttext: And then maybe just one last question on the top of the mall quality spectrum, you have plenty of very high-end A malls that make up a good percentage of NOI or value. If you see your discount grow even further, the discount to where your stock's trading relative to NAV, at what point do you start to look through the portfolio for maybe A malls that are stabilized, they don't have the redevelopment opportunities going forward? And you look to kind of close the gap by selling some of those assets as opposed to some of this retailer or lower productivity malls?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I mentioned in my comments, actually there was a disconnect between private and public market valuations in the A+ malls. And there is a tremendous demand by institutional investors. Again, the board and I view that disconnect and will evaluate at what
componenttext: As I mentioned in my comments, actually there was a disconnect between private and public market valuations in the A+ malls. And there is a tremendous demand by institutional investors. Again, the board and I view that disconnect and will evaluate at what stage we decide to bring in joint venture partners for a portion of those assets, if we do at all, because your point's well taken and we're in deep thought.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Linda Tsai from Barclays.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Linda Tsai from Barclays.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In light of your comments on holiday traffic, do you think you'll comment on traffic going forward? I think in the past you didn't like to discuss it because it came from external/unreliable sources, but now you're measuring it in your malls?
componenttext: In light of your comments on holiday traffic, do you think you'll comment on traffic going forward? I think in the past you didn't like to discuss it because it came from external/unreliable sources, but now you're measuring it in your malls?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think as we continue to measure them, we will -- we're happy to give the data because the irony is that the mall traffic is actually up. One of the biggest pain points during the holiday season was lack of parking. So we, obviously, seeing people come t
componenttext: I think as we continue to measure them, we will -- we're happy to give the data because the irony is that the mall traffic is actually up. One of the biggest pain points during the holiday season was lack of parking. So we, obviously, seeing people come to the mall. We are seeing them stay longer at the mall. They're shopping a lot of fewer stores when they come into the mall, but they definitely roaming the malls and shopping. So if you've got the product, the retailer -- the consumer is redoing their research on their mobile device and coming into the mall to shop, which is why still to date, from a soft goods perspective, almost 95% of all soft goods is bought in the bricks-and-mortar store. And I think the other factor that very few people really include into the equation is that the return rate on the soft goods is incredibly high. I think it's 38% of e-commerce purchases of soft goods that have bought online are returned in the bricks-and-mortar store. So to really get a true and proper understanding until the retailers start to show you exactly what the return rate is and how it's being impacted is really hard to evaluate in this omni-channel world why one growth is bigger than the other because you have to take the return rate into account, which really no one does. And just case in point, you go to Amazon opening brick-and-mortar bookstores and their goal is to open, as I understand, 300 to 400 bookstores. And it should sort of sit back and say that the last mile is all important, which is why Bonobos is opening brick-and-mortar stores and Warby Parker is opening brick-and-mortar stores. And Birchbox is cutting their overhead to open bricks-and-mortar stores. It's a very interesting evolution because the cost of the last mile is that important. And again, the mall business, you have to appreciate, which is more focused on fashion, is very different than a stable business where you're buying commodity. And so in the mall business, the impact of e-commerce is a lot less. It's actually your friend, not your enemy.

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen and welcome to the General Growth Properties of First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors.
Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a more detailed discussion. Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, May 3, 2016.
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in Form 8-K with the SEC and available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap the highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap the highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth came in at 5.2%, company NOI increased nearly 13.9% and EBITDA and FFO growth were each up over 20%. Michael will review our financial results in more detail during his remarks.
The mall portfolio is nearly 96% leased and approximately 85% of our leasing for 2016 is complete. Suite-to-suite spreads were 13% for leases that commenced occupancy during the past 12 months. Total tenant sales, excluding anchors, representing over 80% of the portfolio grew over 2%. Leading categories were home furnishings, followed by [ph]. Sales for tenants occupying space of less than 10,000 square feet declined 1.7%. The decline was almost entirely driven by unusual changes in sales productivity at Christiana mall. 
As a consequence of getaway sales backlog, fluctuations can have meaningful impact at Christiana mall. Excluding this property, tenant sales per square foot for those on the 10,000 square feet increased by 1% and total sales, excluding anchors, increased by 4%. 
JCP mall portfolio given its national scale and high quality posted this growth in light of negative sales comps at our malls located in tourist markets and energy-dependent markets. 
It's good to see that Hawaii is starting to rebound. [indiscernible] sales have increased double-digit year-to-date. We closed on a number of assets transactions during the quarter, including the sale of 4 properties, reach, East Ridge, Provo and 522 Fifth Avenue and acquire the remaining interest in Spokane Valley. 
We're under contract subject to normal closing conditions for the sale of One Stockton in San Francisco for over $100 million and the office components of 685 Fifth Avenue for $150 million. 
We're progressing on a number of redevelopment projects, notably the new Dick's Sporting Goods stores at each of our 5 Houston malls, a new theater and food district in Chicago, the expansion of the Dillard's Fashion Place in Salt Lake City, the expansion of Staten Island Mall and several of the location we owned with [indiscernible]
GGP is a firm believer that higher quality retail assets will not only to continue to be in demand by tenants but also continue to grow in value. We own 100 of the top 400 malls in the United States of America that accounts for 95% of our NOI. The department store closure is an opportunity. We have proven that thesis. 
GGP has nearly 430 anchor stores with only 1 vacancy, which happens to be relocated Nordstrom at Ala Moana. We are currently in lease negotiation for that space.
Our investor deck contains information regarding how we have repented over 80 boxes and the use of our [ph]. Our balance sheet is strong. Debt maturities are lathered over a long period of time. We are working to meet our make our balance sheet even stronger. The pursuit of JV interest in a couple of our malls is in process, and the primary proceeds will be used to pay down debt. 
We focus on the long-term cash flow growth potential of the business, which we believe can generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth, high single-digit FFO per share growth and a growing dividend.
To be successful in retail real estate, you must know your customer and listen to them. We recently surveyed 88,000 mall shoppers and learn from valuable insights. First, the customer wants a mall to to appropriately curated. What does this mean? It means that we have lease the mall to a variety of retailers, restaurants and entertainment vendors at that the trade area. Over the past 5 years, we had turned the tenant mix by approximately 50%. 
In addition, we're incorporating technology to make consumers aware of what is at the mall. An interesting factor, we have 739 restaurants in our portfolio, 564 service and 179 fast casual. As I mentioned, technology has 2 uses. First, awareness and the second, way finding. Consumers use their smartphones to locate stores and branded products. We want to ensure the tenants at our malls are at the top of the search list. We can never be good enough in awareness. 
The second point from our survey is customer said the biggest pain point in the mall is to find parking. Ironic that most weekends, it is hard to find parking in our malls. We're investing to solve this problem by implementing a number of initiatives, having mall employees park in designated areas or allowing customers to park closer to the entrance, ticketless services, cashless is ready when you leave the mall and information of parking space availability as we called the red light, green light open-space counters and incorporating this info into new digital model maps. Our goal is to have a customer stop search on Google and map that guides a customer to a parking spot and told us for virtually to the store.
Let me give you a little flavor of various industries as I see them over the past few years. The health care industry. We've seen that people are more fit, fitness is big business, whether it's in food, health clubs, appareled. It has grown multifold. The leaders in previous years were named Bally fitness, Jack Wayne and New York Sports Club. The leaders today includes SoulCycle, Equinox, Flywheel and Orange Dairy Fitness. And innovations like the bicycle. The fitness segment is bigger than ever. 
Let's go to Internet search, which has experienced explosive growth. At the beginning, it was AOL. Today, it's led by Google. Smartphones. Our staple of power generation. BlackBerry and Motorola was the leaders, today, it is iPhone and Galaxy. Apparel, the recent demand of dealers in the bankruptcies by [ph], which I believe have viable turnaround plan mask the explosive growth of H&M, Zara, Trimark and L Brent, just to name a few. I was recently with the H&M team in Stockholm. They're focused on expansion where they will be in 50 years making the operations sustainable. In the, the owner of Zara and other lines, may be one of the best logistics company in the world, getting the newest items to the customer when they want and L Brand, forever young and innovative.
You might ask where all this is heading? My point is bring these examples up is that they are winners and losers in every category. The highest quality malls today has evolved and provide the consumer what they want, where the want it and when they want it. Center in Chicago generated $500 per square foot 5 years ago. Today, it's over $900. It is a home of Tesla, Warby Parker, Apple, H&M, Zara, Nordstrom's and Microsoft, just to name a few. There are over 20 restaurants and a new theater opening soon. GGP is well positioned for the long-term success in the retail business. 
As CEO, my primary to reduce to allocate capital in order to generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth annually. I believe that EBITDA is an important metric to measure our performance. The sales per square foot metric needs to be viewed in light of other measures. Just as an example, we reported sales per square foot of $584 on a rolling 12-month basis. This metric doesn't take into account varying ownership interests we have in the mall, doesn't take into account a variety of NOI levels generated by the malls and certainly doesn't include all the rent in the malls. If we were to wait this metric for NOI contribution to GGP, the $584 will become $691, down slightly from $704. 
The mall industry has been here since the early 1960s. The long history of this industry also contains some insights. Looking back to GGP's shareholder letter from 1995, a couple of messages caught my eye that were highlighted by the team. The retail and shopping center industry has been overbuilt. The ratio of square feet of retail space per capita has doubled in the past 20 years. Only the fittest retailers will survive and the survivors will come out stronger and smarter. 
Department stores, many may fail but such failure will provide opportunities to replace poorly performing stores with new and exciting retailers. I want to repeat, this was the box found in 1995. My personal view of the retail real estate industry in the U.S. is that it is over retailed. This is especially evident when comparing retail square feet per capita in the U.S. to other developed countries. The primary reason retail properties have closed and will close is obsolescence. Once again, it's obsolescences, competition from other bricks and mortar retail. As a footprint of lower quality shopping center shrink, the winners will continue to be the A malls that become larger and more productive. A malls have experienced double-digit sales growth since 2012. Within the 10 most populated markets across the U.S., sales of A malls have grown 20%, while [indiscernible] 4%. This dynamic is evident in the Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, and Dallas, Houston, L.A., New York, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C. and Miami. Over the decade, over the next decade, we may, again, we may see 300 malls approximately 60 million square feet of in-line GLA accounting for about $18 billion of sales disappear. However, the densification of the top 500 malls to the tune of 50 million square feet with sales of $600 per square foot is equivalent to $25 billion of sales. The share of retail sales at high quality malls will increase. This is where we have positioned GGP. The GGP team is focused on execution. 
Michael will now review our results and outlook for the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred early in the year than we expe
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred early in the year than we expected, we came in approximately $5 million ahead of our guidance. 
Moving down the income statement, starting with same-store NOI. We came in at $561 million or growth of 5.2% and this was approximately $6 million higher than our guidance. The main driver of the variance was termination income that came in early.
EBITDA was $590 million as reported, less $40 million pretax related to the condos [indiscernible] $550 million versus our guidance number of $525 million for a positive variance of $25 million. 
Approximately $13 million of that came from the stock sale gain. We expected to sell the stock this year and took advantage of 1Q market condition. We did not have the stock sale gain in our first quarter guidance, but it was in our full year number.
Of the remaining $12 million, $6 million came from this same-store NOI I noted and the remaining $6 million is from a variety of small items. The low EBITDA we wrote off approximately $75 million of an accrued interest receivable related to our Aliansce no. And as part of the condo, we have $10 million of tax related to those.
To bring it altogether, FFO came in at $383 million or $48 million better than guidance, the $40 million of condo EBITDA is offset by $10 million in tax plus $13 million from the stock sale gain plus the $6 million  in other positive EBITDA, which is basically offset by the Aliansce write-off. Doing all the math, leaves about $5 million, which is basically attributable to the termination income.
Moving on to the second quarter. Guidance for  second quarter, company FFO $325 million to $345 million or $0.34 to $0.36 per share. Our guidance includes $13 million to $14 million of after-tax FFO related to the condos, which is the same run rate we expect for the third quarter and fourth quarter, assuming sales and cost trends remain the same. 
At the midpoint of our guidance, we expect same-store NOI of approximately $560 million, around 3.5% growth. We expect EBITDA of approximately $540 million or growth of around 7.5%.
Moving onto our balance sheet -- Im sorry, first let's go to full year 2016. Our expectations remain the same. Same-store NOI of 4% to 5% or a little over $2.3 billion. EBITDA of 8% to 9%, almost $2.3 billion. And FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.56, approximately $1.475 billion. 
Now let's move on to the balance sheet. We extended the $1.4 billion term loan that we have out 3 years to 2019 plus 2 1-year extensions. We reduced recourse on the loan from 100% to 50% and maintain pricing. As we've previously indicated, we're in the process of looking at asset sales and sales of joint venture interest. We would expect to use a significant portion of the proceeds to pay down debt. If our plan succeeds, we would take our net debt-to-EBITDA from a range of 8 to 8.5, down to 7.5 to 8x by year-end. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I say, if you say it often enough, it would be right 1 day. So that's somewhat my math. I've always maintained that over the long term, the business is 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So at a 5-year period, it's 20% growth assuming that you get
componenttext: As I say, if you say it often enough, it would be right 1 day. So that's somewhat my math. I've always maintained that over the long term, the business is 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So at a 5-year period, it's 20% growth assuming that you get annual increases of 2% to 3%. So you're getting 10% to 12.5% increases over that period of time and that's where the 8% to 10% spread comes. So if you nothing happens that is the ability grew 3% to 4% a year, you should get N% to 10% spreads consistently and that's the underwriting of the business. And that should give you the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth.

componenttext: The loan has been around for a real long time, I mean, predates the upon management team it's been renewed a number of times. The recourse was always part of that loan, so we thought it was a pretty good thing we've got the recourse down in half. We decided to extend it out because market conditions were more favorable than bank market than in the CMBS market. There's about 35% of the blown value, the value of the properties on the loans are B malls. We do have flexibility to pay off about $500 million of that loan, which is a condition previously, and we continued it on without any prepayment penalty, without any -- without more than having to pay 100% of the loan down. So we took advantage of just pushing it out. We've maintained if the committee to pay some of it done. And there are some assets that are close to stabilization what you would think about doing long-term financing. Some of those assets are up or assets in that portfolio. So it might not be easy that they've demoed so quickly, will see about that depends on how much of that we decide to pay does was really a market called just given what was going on in the CMBS market at that time.

But the second thing is why the current focus on debt reduction, on leverage reduction is you guys I'm sure although we are the snap historically, a general sort of thing to do and I think it's great. But why now for debt reduction?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in the number of meetings where he has talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to cash r
componenttext: That's -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in the number of meetings where he has talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to cash rather than continue to be aggressive on the spending front. We're evolving as a company, it's a much more stabilized portfolio. The market seems to be reacting well to the idea. It doesn't inhibit but enhances our flexibility at the margin. So 3 years from now, maybe it will be different, maybe not. But right now, the way we're running the company, given the use of proceeds, given what we could we think reducing the leverage will be the best use of proceeds. We may save some for other things. But for the most part, it will be to pay down debt.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Again, I mean, to me, 1, issuing equity just given what we think is a low priority -- but let's not forget that there are -- the assets that are being priced much stronger in the private market that they are the public market so we try to take advantage of that arbitrage. And, I think, that's -- it's a prudent thing to do right now.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books and I'm going to do t
componenttext: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books and I'm going to do this in dollars because the currency between the U.S. and the real is difficult for us to follow. But we have about USD 160 million note, over the course of the last few years, the has gotten weaker and weaker. That led to of the quarter at the beginning of the quarter, we had approximately $100 million note all due to foreign currency losses, all losses at Rancho our GAAP statements but of our company FFO. We thought it was time to impair the note. That note  -- the collateral for that note are the shares of Aliansce, on the day we impaired the note, we took it down to the value of the shares on that particular day. That resulted in the $29 million impairment loss that you see in the financials. The remaining $7.5 million that we took through income is a write-off of the accrued interest receivable that we have been receiving on that note. So the way we restructured the note was the would accrue interest for a year and then they would pay. So we had basically June through February earnings that we needed to write-off. So that's the total of the $36.5 million, it's really $29 million and $7.5 million, 2 separate pieces.

I would now like to turn the conference over to Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a more detailed discussion. 
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, May 3, 2016.  Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in a Form 8-K with the SEC and available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth c
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. 
During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth came in at 5.2%, company NOI increased nearly 13.9% and EBITDA and FFO growth were each up over 20%. Michael will review our financial results in more detail during his remarks.
The mall portfolio is nearly 96% leased, and approximately 85% of our leasing for 2016 is complete. Suite-to-suite spreads were 13% for leases that commenced occupancy during the past 12 months. Total tenant sales excluding anchors, representing over 80% of the portfolio, grew over 2%. Leading categories were home furnishings, followed by food and apparel. 
Sales for tenants occupying space less than 10,000 square feet declined 1.7%. The decline was almost entirely driven by unusual changes in sales productivity at Christiana Mall. As a consequence of Delaware sales tax floors, fluctuations can have meaningful impact at Christiana Mall. Excluding this property, tenant sales per square foot for those on the 10,000 square feet increased by 1% and total sales excluding anchors increased by 4%. JCP mall portfolio, given its national scale and high quality, posted this growth in light of negative sales comps at our malls located in tourist markets and energy-dependent markets. 
It's good to see that Hawaii is starting to rebound. LVMH sales have increased double digits year-to-date. We closed on a number of asset transactions during the quarter, including the sale of 4 properties, Owings Mills Eastridge, Provo and 522 Fifth Avenue, and acquired the remaining interest in Spokane Valley. We're under contract, subject to normal closing conditions, for the sale of 1 Stockton in San Francisco for over $100 million and the office component of 685 Fifth Avenue for $150 million. 
We are progressing on a number of redevelopment projects, notably the new Dick's Sporting Goods stores at each of our 5 Houston malls, a new theater and food district at Oakbrook Center in Chicago, the expansion of Dillard's at Fashion Place in Salt Lake City, the expansion of Staten Island Mall and several of the Sears locations we own with Seritage. GGP is a firm believer that higher-quality retail assets will not only continue to be in demand by tenants but also continue to grow in value. We own 100 of the top 400 malls in the United States of America that accounts for 95% of our NOI. 
A department store closure is an opportunity. We have proven that thesis. GGP has nearly 430 anchor stores with only 1 vacancy, which happens to be a relocated Nordstrom at Ala Moana. We are currently in lease negotiation for that space. Our investor deck contains information regarding how we have re-tenanted over 80 boxes, and the new uses are numerous. 
Our balance sheet is strong. Debt maturities are laddered  over a long period of time. We're working to make our balance sheet even stronger. The pursuit of selling JV interests in a couple of our malls is in process, and the primary proceeds will be used to pay down debt. We focus on the long-term cash flow growth potential of the business, which we believe can generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth, high single-digit FFO per share growth and a growing dividend.
To be successful in retail real estate, you must know your customer and listen to them. We recently surveyed 88,000 mall shoppers and learned from valuable insights. First, the customer wants a mall to be appropriately curated. What does this mean? It means that we have leased a mall to a variety of retailers, restaurants and entertainment vendors at best of the trade area. Over the past 5 years, we have turned the tenant mix by approximately 50%. 
In addition, we're incorporating technology to make consumers aware of what is at the mall. An interesting factoid, we have 739 restaurants in our portfolio, 564 service and 179 fast casual. As I mentioned, technology has 2 uses: first, awareness; and the second, way finding. Consumers use their smartphones to locate stores and branded products. We want to ensure the tenants at our malls are at the top of the search list. We can never be good enough on awareness. 
The second point from our survey is that customers said the biggest pain point in the mall is to find parking. Ironic that, most weekends, it is hard to find parking in our malls. We're investing to solve this problem by implementing a number of initiatives: having mall employees park in designated areas; allowing customers to park closer to the entrance; ticketless valet services, cashless, car is ready when you leave the mall; and information of parking space availability, as we call it, the red light, green light, open-space counters and incorporating this information into new digital mall maps. Our goal is to have a customer start their search on Google. That map guides the customer to a parking spot and blue dots [ph] her virtually to the store.
Let me give you a little flavor of various industries as I see them over the past few years. The health care industry. We've seen that people are more fit. Fitness is big business, whether it's in food, health clubs, apparel. It has grown multifold. The leaders in previous years were names like Bally Fitness, Jack LaLanne and New York Sports Club. The leaders today include SoulCycle, Equinox, CorePower Yoga, Flywheel and Orangetheory Fitness and innovations like the Peloton bicycle. The fitness segment is bigger than ever. 
Let's go to Internet search, which has experienced explosive growth. At the beginning, it was AOL. Today, it is led by Google. Smartphones, our staple of our generation. BlackBerry and Motorola were the leaders. Today, it is iPhone and Galaxy. 
In apparel, the recent demise of Deb Shops and Delia's and the bankruptcies by Wet Seal and PacSun, which I believe have viable turnaround plans, mask the explosive growth of H&M, Zara, Trimark and L Brands, just to name a few. I was recently with the H&M team in Stockholm. They are focused on expansion, where they will be in 50 years and making their operations sustainable. Inditex, the owner of Zara and other lines, may be one of the best logistics company in the world, getting the newest items to the customer when they want. And L Brands, forever young and innovative.
You might ask where all this is heading. My point is bringing these examples up is that there are winners and losers in every category. The highest-quality malls today has evolved and provide the consumer with what they want, where the want it and when they want it. 
Oakbrook Center in Chicago generated $500 per square foot 5 years ago. Today, it's over $900. It is the home of Tesla, Warby Parker, Apple, H&M, Zara, Nordstrom and Microsoft, just to name a few. There are over 20 restaurants and a new theater opening soon. GGP is positioned for the long-term success of the retail business. 
As CEO, my primary job is to allocate capital in order to generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth annually. I believe that EBITDA is an important metric to measure our performance. The sales per square foot metric needs to be viewed in light of other measures. Just as an example, we reported sales per square foot of $584 on a rolling 12-month basis. This metric doesn't take into account varying ownership interests we have in the mall, it doesn't take into account the variety of NOI levels generated by the malls and certainly doesn't include all the rent-paying tenants in the malls. If we were to weigh this metric for NOI contribution to GGP, the $584 will become $691, down slightly from $704. 
The mall industry has been here since the early 1960s. The long history of this industry also contains some insights. Looking back to GGP's shareholder letter from 1995, a couple of messages caught my eye that were highlighted by the team. The retail and shopping center industry has been overbuilt. The ratio of square feet of retail space per capita has doubled in the past 20 years. Only the fittest retailers will survive and the survivors will come out stronger and smarter. Department stores. Many may fail, but such failure will provide opportunities to replace poorly performing stores with new and exciting retailers. I want to repeat, this was Bucksbaums in 1995. 
My personal view of the retail real estate industry in the U.S. is that it is over-retailed. This is especially evident when comparing retail square feet per capita in the U.S. to other developed countries. The primary reason retail properties have closed and will close is obsolescence. Once again, it's obsolescence, competition from other bricks-and-mortar retail. 
As the footprint of lower-quality shopping centers shrink, then the winners will continue to be the A malls that become larger and more productive. A malls have experienced double-digit sales growth since 2012. Within the 10 most populated markets across the U.S., sales of A malls have grown 20%, while population [ph], 4%. This dynamic is evident in Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, L.A., New York, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C. and Miami. 
Over the decade -- over the next decade, we may, again, we may see 300 malls, approximately 60 million square feet of in-line GLA accounting for about $18 billion of sales disappear. However, the densification of the top 500 malls to the tune of 50 million square feet with sales of $600 per square foot is equivalent to $25 billion of sales. The share of retail sales at high-quality malls will increase. This is where we have positioned GGP. The GGP team is focused on execution. 
Michael will now review our results and outlook for the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred earlier in the year than we ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred earlier in the year than we expected, we came in approximately $5 million ahead of our guidance. 
Moving down the income statement, starting with same-store NOI. We came in at $561 million or growth of 5.2%, and this was approximately $6 million higher than our guidance. The main driver of the variance was termination income that came in early.
EBITDA was $590 million as reported. Less $40 million pretax related to the condos leaves $550 million versus our guidance number of $525 million, for a positive variance of $25 million. Approximately $13 million of that came from the stock sale gain. We expected to sell the stock this year and took advantage of 1Q market conditions. We did not have the stock sale gain in our first quarter guidance, but it was in our full year number. Of the remaining $12 million, $6 million came from the same-store NOI beat I noted, and the remaining $6 million is from a variety of small items. 
Below EBITDA, we wrote off approximately $7.5 million of an accrued interest receivable related to our Aliansce notes. And as part of the condos, we had about $10 million of tax related to those.
To bring it all together, FFO came in at $383 million or $48 million better than guidance. The $40 million of condo EBITDA is offset by $10 million in tax plus $13 million from the stock sale gains plus the $6 million  in other positive EBITDA, which is basically offset by the Aliansce write-off. Doing all that math leaves about $5 million, which is basically attributable to the termination income.
Moving on to the second quarter. Guidance for second quarter, company FFO $325 million to $345 million or $0.34 to $0.36 per share. Our guidance includes $13 million to $14 million of after-tax FFO related to the condos, which is the same run rate we expect for third quarter and fourth quarter, assuming sales and cost trends remain the same. At the midpoint of our guidance, we expect same-store NOI of approximately $560 million, around 3.5% growth. We expect EBITDA of approximately $540 million or growth of around 7.5%.
Moving on to our balance sheet -- Im sorry, first let's go through full year 2016. Our expectations remain the same: same-store NOI of 4% to 5% or a little over $2.3 billion; EBITDA of 8% to 9%, almost $2.3 billion; and FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.56, approximately $1.475 billion. 
Now let's move on to the balance sheet. We extended the $1.4 billion term loan that we have, out 3 years to 2019 plus 2 1-year extensions. We reduced recourse on the loan from 100% to 50% and maintained pricing. As we have previously indicated, we are in the process of looking at asset sales and sales of joint venture interest. We would expect to use a significant portion of the proceeds to pay down debt. If our plan succeeds, we would take our net debt-to-EBITDA from a range of 8 to 8.5, down to 7.5 to 8x by year-end. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: So just to take a step back, some of the assets that we're looking at are large in terms of the joint ventures so the dollars could be significant. Some of the assets are not that large. It's a variety. I'm not really comfortable giving out dollar proceeds because we're in the preliminary stages. The bulk of the dollars would be used to pay down debt. We have an idea of what debt we would pay down, but we're not 100% settled. It kind of depends on timing of cash inputs, which loans you want to take down, which not. None of the transactions, other than the ones that are closed, are in our guidance, so 685, Stockton not yet in our guidance.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Sandeep, you mentioned the portfolio on a proportionate share would have much higher productivity than what you report overall. Yet, if you're going to do more JVs, it's just sort of a diluting of the earnings power, the NOI power of GGP.
componenttext: Okay. And then, Sandeep, you mentioned the portfolio on a proportionate share would have much higher productivity than what you report overall. Yet, if you're going to do more JVs, it's just sort of a diluting of the earnings power, the NOI power of GGP. So can just sort of balance for us how we should think about adding complexity to the company, selling off stakes, potentially more Ala Moana-type assets versus trying to keep the sales -- the high sales productivity in the A and A+ qualities of the portfolio more towards the shareholders?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, there is a balance. And as we have said, the assets we're looking to bring in joint venture partners are those that are substantial value within our portfolio, so there's a tilt to diversification, and they're in tourist markets. When we sol
componenttext: So obviously, there is a balance. And as we have said, the assets we're looking to bring in joint venture partners are those that are substantial value within our portfolio, so there's a tilt to diversification, and they're in tourist markets. When we sold 37.5% of Ala Moana, it was because we felt an asset of $5.5 billion, $6 billion would be in a, call it, 12%, 13% , 14% of the total market cap of the company, and it was prudent to start to derisk from a specific market and having so much concentration. So we are balancing a few things, the concentration of certain tourist markets as well as the arbitrage between public and private markets. And then we think that you can use the proceeds prudently to pay down -- substantially used to pay down debt and still maintain the advantage of having an A-quality mall portfolio.

componenttext: Again, we've -- we are always recycling capital. We're always looking to find lower-quality assets or lower-growth assets and try to cull them, as we have shown you in the first quarter. We've culled  the portfolio by a few assets. It's our -- we will continue doing that, and we've been disciplined about doing that. Over the last 5 years, we've sold over 30 malls one-off besides the Rouse spin. And that will continue to be our program for the next 5 years.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Given issues with Aeropostale and PacSun, can you discuss your updated expectations for the impact of store closings and bankruptcies in 2016? And there's been some pressure about potential issues at Forever 21. Are you seeing anything unusual in terms of your receivables there? Any concerns there?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me -- I think we're at second base on understanding when the closures and bankruptcies are. As you know, 30 to 45 days ago, we all felt slightly better. And then you've seen PacSun file for bankruptcy. You've seen Sports Authority liquidating. You'
componenttext: So let me -- I think we're at second base on understanding when the closures and bankruptcies are. As you know, 30 to 45 days ago, we all felt slightly better. And then you've seen PacSun file for bankruptcy. You've seen Sports Authority liquidating. You've seen Sport Chalet, which we have none, liquidating. And of course, the rumors continue to spiral about Aeropostale. So our job is to continue to be cautious going into the second half of the year. So we are going to continue to be conservative. The aspect of Forever 21, when the New York Post article came out, I did reach out to the CEO of Forever 21, who has sent me an e-mail confirming that there are no issues in the company. It was all about -- I think they're going to issue their own press release today, I've been told. It had to do with their software change, which created some sort of a timing issue with vendor payments. We have seen 0 receivables from Forever 21. So -- and as a matter of fact, we actually see their business in our portfolio turning to the positive.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
