componenttext: Okay. And then Michael, on the Park Lane condo sales, I thought you had previously talked about $45 million to $50 million of after-tax profit, but it looks like you had $30 million in Q1. But you talked about another, I think, $40 million for the back half -- for the rest of the year, $13 million to $14 million a quarter. Did that increase from your previous expectations? And then what portion of that guidance is related to the condo gains net of tax versus the gain of sale of air rights?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for the full year -- so in the quarter, the $30 million is $22 million for the condos and $7.5 million for the air rights. So we're going to lump together those 2 things throughout the year. So when I said $13 million to $14 million for each quarter, 2
componenttext: So for the full year -- so in the quarter, the $30 million is $22 million for the condos and $7.5 million for the air rights. So we're going to lump together those 2 things throughout the year. So when I said $13 million to $14 million for each quarter, 2, 3 and 4, that's roughly $10 million FFO -- after-tax FFO on the condos and $3.5 million on the air rights. So I'm going to keep them combined, which is easier for me to track what's going on. It does so happen that the air rights flow through the other revenue line item that you see in our proportionate financial statement. And then we had to separate out specifically the condo revenues and the condo costs. There are some additional costs associated with the project. That is a small number that flow through our marketing, but it's not really all that relevant.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was the air right originally anticipated? I think you recognized about $25 million through other revenue in Q3 and Q4. Why is that marked...
componenttext: Was the air right originally anticipated? I think you recognized about $25 million through other revenue in Q3 and Q4. Why is that marked...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had to take the first $25 million as a gain upfront and then the other $25 million gets -- was deferred. As the condos come in, we take that in pro rata.
componenttext: We had to take the first $25 million as a gain upfront and then the other $25 million gets -- was deferred. As the condos come in, we take that in pro rata.

componenttext: Just going back to the Aeropostale and the PacSun discussion. It sounds like Forever 21, not seeing any receivables issues. Have you had any issues with Aeropostale? componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just maybe a question on your comment about turning over the tenant mix by 50% over the last 5 years. I'm just wondering, if you think about the next 5 years, do you think that turnover will accelerate? And then -- just given the changing sort of demands from your shoppers and the changing shopper patterns that you're seeing. And if so, how do you think this will change the sort of risk profile, the cash flows and maybe some of the CapEx spend that you might have to put up to turn over those tenants?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, we are looking at it slightly differently. this year, the retention ratio is about 70% to 75%. So we used to rotate about 50% annually. This year, it's 25%. So actually, the amount of churn has gotten less. The retention has gotten better, and I
componenttext: Actually, we are looking at it slightly differently. this year, the retention ratio is about 70% to 75%. So we used to rotate about 50% annually. This year, it's 25%. So actually, the amount of churn has gotten less. The retention has gotten better, and I think that's also a function of the tenants' productivity actually being better and their desire to stay. So we are actually looking at the churn to be a lot less, the retention ratio to be at 70% to 75%.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last question maybe on the rent spreads. I know you've kind of, in the past, talked about 8% to 10% as being a reasonable number. You have been beating that number for quite some time. It does seem like the spread, at least for 201
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last question maybe on the rent spreads. I know you've kind of, in the past, talked about 8% to 10% as being a reasonable number. You have been beating that number for quite some time. It does seem like the spread, at least for 2016, commencement have been coming down over the last couple of quarters. Do you still think 8% to 10% is the right sort of range? Or is there something going on that would suggest maybe a slightly lower or higher normalized spread?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I say, right, if you say it often enough, it would be right one day. And so here's some of my math. I've always maintained that, over the long term, the business is a 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So over a 5-year period, so sit back and say i
componenttext: As I say, right, if you say it often enough, it would be right one day. And so here's some of my math. I've always maintained that, over the long term, the business is a 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So over a 5-year period, so sit back and say it's a 20% growth. Assuming that you get annual increases of 2% to 3%, so you're getting 10% to 12.5% increases over that period of time, and that's where the 8% to 10% spread comes. So if you -- if nothing happens but you steadily grow 3% to 4% a year, you should get 8% to 10% spreads consistently, and that's really the underwriting of the business. And that should give you the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I was hoping you could talk about that $1.4 billion secured term loan amendment a little more and just discuss why you decided to do the amendment now ahead of the 2018 maturity. And why not just get closer to the maturity and start thinking about d
componenttext: Mike, I was hoping you could talk about that $1.4 billion secured term loan amendment a little more and just discuss why you decided to do the amendment now ahead of the 2018 maturity. And why not just get closer to the maturity and start thinking about doing individual refis? And I guess the related question is, why is there still any recourse on that loan?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The loan has been around for a real long time. I mean it predates the current management team. It's been renewed a number of times. The recourse was always part of that loan, so we thought it was a pretty good thing that we got the recourse down in half.
componenttext: The loan has been around for a real long time. I mean it predates the current management team. It's been renewed a number of times. The recourse was always part of that loan, so we thought it was a pretty good thing that we got the recourse down in half. We decided to extend it out because market conditions were more favorable in the bank market than in the CMBS market. There's about 35% of the loan value -- the value of the properties in the loans are B malls. We do have flexibility to pay off about $500 million of that loan, which was a condition previously, and we continued it on without any prepayment penalty, without any -- without more than having to pay 100% of the loan down. So we took advantage of just pushing it out. We've maintained the flexibility to pay some of it down. And there are some assets that are close to stabilization, when you would think about doing long-term financing. Some of those assets are core assets in that portfolio, so it might not be so easy to take them out so quickly. We'll see about that. It depends on how much of it we decide to pay down. So it's really a market call just given what was going on in the CMBS market at the time.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The related question I have relative to the asset sales is, how much prepayable debt do you have at this point that you can get rid off without penalty? I know you just mentioned the $500 million on your term loan. What else do you have at this poin
componenttext: Okay. The related question I have relative to the asset sales is, how much prepayable debt do you have at this point that you can get rid off without penalty? I know you just mentioned the $500 million on your term loan. What else do you have at this point that can be prepaid without penalty?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're asking the question in the context of "Are there high-coupon debt that we could pay off?" I'd say the answer is no. There's really nothing left along those lines. Believe me, we scoured it -- we scour it regularly. We do have, I would say, order
componenttext: If you're asking the question in the context of "Are there high-coupon debt that we could pay off?" I'd say the answer is no. There's really nothing left along those lines. Believe me, we scoured it -- we scour it regularly. We do have, I would say, order of magnitude, another $500 million to $1 billion that would be prepayable. Now some of that might be early 2017 maturity that I might pay a little of the fees in sum [ph] and get rid off in 2016. But our ability to pay down -- we have the ability to probably pay down order of magnitude of $1.5 billion of debt. We may not, but we have that ability.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess where I'm going is I think we're all trying to figure out, I think this is in relation to the first question that was asked on the call, what our expectations should be with respect to potential earnings dilution as we balance that against th
componenttext: Yes. I guess where I'm going is I think we're all trying to figure out, I think this is in relation to the first question that was asked on the call, what our expectations should be with respect to potential earnings dilution as we balance that against the deleveraging that you've talked about. And is there any type of guidance you can give us about the magnitude of the difference between the cap rates on these sales and the interest rates on the loans getting repaid?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, look, we have generally been fairly conservative in giving expectations orally on pricing, earlier -- orally on these types of plans. It's just been how we've been running this. If we are successful in the asset sales, the dilution number cou
componenttext: I would say, look, we have generally been fairly conservative in giving expectations orally on pricing, earlier -- orally on these types of plans. It's just been how we've been running this. If we are successful in the asset sales, the dilution number could be large. I hesitate to put numbers around it. It probably impacts 2017 way more than it impacts 2016, if we are successful. We got a lot on our plate. We've got a lot of moving parts. So as much as you want answers to those questions and want to have it nailed down, we would like to as well, we're just not prepared to talk about that.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, if you go through -- mall by mall and -- could you help describe what percent of the square footage of retailers is actually dragging down your overall sales productivity? And if you look at the pipeline of better retailers that can potentially m
componenttext: Sandeep, if you go through -- mall by mall and -- could you help describe what percent of the square footage of retailers is actually dragging down your overall sales productivity? And if you look at the pipeline of better retailers that can potentially move into your malls, how much of that better group of retailers is there to offset the poor performers?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I can't sort of give you the answer on a percentage basis. But I will sort of sit back and say, looking at every category, as I mentioned, all the categories were up. Home furnishings, food, apparel, electronics, they were all up. So as a group, we
componenttext: Again, I can't sort of give you the answer on a percentage basis. But I will sort of sit back and say, looking at every category, as I mentioned, all the categories were up. Home furnishings, food, apparel, electronics, they were all up. So as a group, we're actually seeing positive spreads -- I mean positive sales growth. The other aspect, I think, we speak -- and the reason we keep talking about total sales as much as sales per square foot of 10,000 -- less than 10,000 feet is because the total sales truly best capture what we're seeing in the market, where you got the larger apparel guys, like H&M, Zara, Primark, coming in with very high sales productivity and actually lifting the sales productivity of apparel within the mall. And so -- and the other advantage of doing it that way is that what we're really after is to increase our penetration rate in a specific market, okay? That really, from an operator perspective, is the most important. If I can increase the total mall sales by 2%, 3%, 4%, 5%, I'm increasing my penetration rate, I'm increasing my traffic. And we're going to continue to see that evolve. I mean the next-generation retailers, the Warby Parkers, the Bonoboses, the Teslas, I mean Apple, Microsoft, are going to continue to evolve. The larger format -- L Brands, the PINK stores, the lululemons, the Fabletics, the list is quite extensive. So you -- my entire reason of sort to speaking different industries in my opening remarks was to sort of capture the fact that there are winners and losers in every business. Let's not focus only on the retail business or the relative business. You could be in the e-commerce business, you could be in the Internet search business, you could be in the phone business, and you're going to have winners and losers. And the beauty is if you have great real estate, as Milton Cooper said 20 years ago and Matthew and -- Bucksbaum said 20 years ago, okay, it's an opportunity to replace. And you continue to see an evolution of retail with more productive tenants. So it's a constant evolution, and we've seen this pattern for 50 years.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick question on your CAM expenses. Obviously -- well, at least on the surface, it looks like it's more of a profit center than breakeven type of business at this point. Do you guys get any pushbacks from retailers that look at that numb
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick question on your CAM expenses. Obviously -- well, at least on the surface, it looks like it's more of a profit center than breakeven type of business at this point. Do you guys get any pushbacks from retailers that look at that number and say you're basically collecting more than the cost?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- as you know, most CAM is a fixed CAM. The reason everyone went to fixed CAM basis was basically not focused on breaking it out and going to audit processes and the like. And the way the retailer looks at it, it's a total occupancy cost. So whether
componenttext: It's -- as you know, most CAM is a fixed CAM. The reason everyone went to fixed CAM basis was basically not focused on breaking it out and going to audit processes and the like. And the way the retailer looks at it, it's a total occupancy cost. So whether you allocate it to CAM, or you allocate it to rent, from their perspective, it's a total costs. Since it's a fixed number, not a fluctuating number, it almost doesn't matter which part it belongs.

componenttext: Of spend. We think that sort of generally comes from redevelopment of anchor tenant boxes and densification of the assets. Where we're adding -- what's going on, as I mentioned, again, in my opening remarks, is the top 500 malls have a tremendous demand for space. And so these top 500 malls are getting densified. I mean I think -- I sort of said 100,000 square feet per mall, but I think that's pretty conservative. Just in the 5 Houston malls, we're adding fix [ph]. I think each fix [ph] is 60,000 to 80,000 square feet. And so I think, there's $300 million to $500 million of growth that we can see in our portfolio over the next 5 years.

But we look at it to be end of the year '16 groundbreaking for an '18 opening.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Sandeep, I just wanted to ask you a quick question on the survey you did. I think you said it was 88,000 customers, and you called out 3 things. You called out wanting to get the mall to be curated towards its local community and what the shoppers
componenttext: Right. Sandeep, I just wanted to ask you a quick question on the survey you did. I think you said it was 88,000 customers, and you called out 3 things. You called out wanting to get the mall to be curated towards its local community and what the shoppers want. You called out technology, and you called out parking. I guess, how long was the survey? Like how many questions did you ask customers? Was there a difference that you saw regionally in terms of like major metros like New York versus other areas where, I would say, the service levels and what people can order online here is much different than in middle America? And I'm just curious whether there was anything else that you teased out from a technology. Or what did the customer say about ordering online, pickup in store, if that was asked? What other details can you share?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Michael, I mean, the customers -- it was a national survey, so it was across all our 120 malls. That can sort of tell you whatever. These are -- these were themes that were -- that came out loud across the board. I think the customer, it's proven
componenttext: Yes. So Michael, I mean, the customers -- it was a national survey, so it was across all our 120 malls. That can sort of tell you whatever. These are -- these were themes that were -- that came out loud across the board. I think the customer, it's proven now, wants to buy or browse online and pick it up in the store, return it to the store. So I don't think we're seeing any difference. I don't think the customer is saying -- did not say "Hey, I'm not coming to your mall because I'm buying online" at all. That was not even part of the equation. On the contrary, they all wanted to come to the mall. They all like to come to the mall. That's where they socially interact, and they just want the mall to be curated correctly for them to be able to have a parking space. Now the technology part is where we are very focused because we do know that customers -- 2/3 of the customers start their process of buying on their mobile phones. And it all starts up with a Google search. So the whole aspect here is to take you painlessly from a Google search to a parking spot to the store. That, again, just facilitates and time-saves the customer. The customer wants to actually go to the mall to shop. We've seen no dropoff in traffic from the end of the last year. So we're not seeing that at all.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- the total exposure is -- take a lot of square feet and multiply it by a big rent great number, and it feels like a big number. The real exposure is what we do on the leasing front to mitigate that exposure. So last year, I think we had a growth expo
componenttext: We -- the total exposure is -- take a lot of square feet and multiply it by a big rent great number, and it feels like a big number. The real exposure is what we do on the leasing front to mitigate that exposure. So last year, I think we had a growth exposure of 40, and we had a net reduction of 20. And we ended up with a net of 20 given all the stuff that went on last year. We kind of used that 20 as the reason for our bankruptcy reserve this year, and we are hoping not to use the full amount. It is baked into our numbers, and it's hard to answer on a specific tenant like that, Rich, because there are spaces that they keep, there are spaces that they give, there are space that we think they're going to give. And we've got 5 guys lined up to take them so...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll just sort of add a bit more color, Rich, is that essentially, we don't anticipate the case of PacSun or Aeropostale to be a liquidation. And if you don't anticipate a liquidation, then there will be some closures, for which we have already been ac
componenttext: So I'll just sort of add a bit more color, Rich, is that essentially, we don't anticipate the case of PacSun or Aeropostale to be a liquidation. And if you don't anticipate a liquidation, then there will be some closures, for which we have already been active in releasing a lot of those spaces. And it would really come back more to be what financial assistance are we prepared to provide PacSun and  and Aeropostale to keep them afloat, to give them the chance to effectuate their turnaround, so -- which is why you're not taking into account the total exposure. As Michael said, if you take into account the total exposure, you've got 100-odd stores at 5,000 square feet, and you can do the math. It's an astronomical math. But since you don't anticipate a liquidation, I think our conservative reserve of $20 million should be sufficient, we hope.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, yes. I was actually thinking a little more positively, guys. It isn't really astronomical. I'm guessing this is under 0.5% of base rent. So maybe the total, if you add them all, but like you say, you wouldn't, is not even 2%. But now the second thi
componenttext: Right, yes. I was actually thinking a little more positively, guys. It isn't really astronomical. I'm guessing this is under 0.5% of base rent. So maybe the total, if you add them all, but like you say, you wouldn't, is not even 2%. But now the second thing is why the current focus on debt reduction, on leverage reduction? As you guys, I'm sure, are well aware, that's not historically a general worst sort of thing to do. And I think it's great, but why now for debt reduction?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in a number of meetings where he's talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to husband
componenttext: That's a -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in a number of meetings where he's talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to husband cash rather than continue to be aggressive on the spending front. It's -- we're evolving as a company. It's a much more stabilized portfolio. The market seems to be reacting well to the idea. It doesn't inhibit but enhances our flexibility at the margin. So 3 years from now, maybe it will be different, maybe not. But right now, the way we're running the company, given the use of proceeds, given what we could do, we think reducing the leverage will be the best use of proceeds. We may save some for other things, but for the most part, it will be to pay down debt.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay, good. And then just the last thing on that. Does it make sense just to sort of issue equity at this point and kind of get it behind you, I mean, or do at least some equity to get it behind you?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Again, I mean, to me, one, issuing equity, just given what we think, is a low priority. But let's not forget that there are -- the assets are being priced much stronger in the private market that they are the public market, so we try to take advantage of that arbitrage. And I think that it's a prudent thing to do right now.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And we've sort of maintained that equity is very precious cargo for us. We've actually been a net buyer, not a -- we've not issued equity once since 20 -- since November 2010. And again, it hasn't presented us with any flexibility to do and operate our business, so we have no plans to issue equity.

componenttext: This is Caitlin Burrows. Just a quick one. I think in the prepared remarks, you guys mentioned that there was a write-down related to the Aliansce note. I was just wondering if you could go through that again and give some more details.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books. And I'm going to do
componenttext: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books. And I'm going to do this in dollars because the currency between the U.S. and the real is difficult for us to follow. But we have about USD 160 million note. Over the course of the last few years, the real has gotten weaker and weaker. That led to a -- at the quarter -- at the beginning of the quarter, we had approximately $100 million note, all due to foreign currency losses, all losses that run through our GAAP statements but not our company FFO. We felt that it was time to impair the note. That note  -- the collateral for that note are the shares of Aliansce. On the day we impaired the note, we took it down to the value of the shares on that particular day. That resulted in the $29 million impairment loss that you see in the financials. The remaining $7.5 million that we took through income is a write-off of the accrued interest receivable that we had been receiving on that note. So the way we structured the note was we would accrue interest for a year and then they would pay. So we had basically June through February earnings that we needed to write off. So that's the total of the $36.5 million. It's really $29 million and $7.5 million, 2 separate pieces.

Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within t
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties First Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a more detailed discussion. 
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, May 3, 2016.  Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in a Form 8-K with the SEC and available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth c
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone, and thank you for joining our call. My prepared remarks will recap highlights in the quarter, sales trends and some perspectives on our business environment. 
During the first quarter, our same-store NOI growth came in at 5.2%, company NOI increased nearly 13.9% and EBITDA and FFO growth were each up over 20%. Michael will review our financial results in more detail during his remarks.
The mall portfolio is nearly 96% leased, and approximately 85% of our leasing for 2016 is complete. Suite-to-suite spreads were 13% for leases that commenced occupancy during the past 12 months. Total tenant sales excluding anchors, representing over 80% of the portfolio, grew over 2%. Leading categories were home furnishings, followed by food and apparel. 
Sales for tenants occupying space less than 10,000 square feet declined 1.7%. The decline was almost entirely driven by unusual changes in sales productivity at Christiana Mall. As a consequence of Delaware sales tax floors, fluctuations can have meaningful impact at Christiana Mall. Excluding this property, tenant sales per square foot for those on the 10,000 square feet increased by 1% and total sales excluding anchors increased by 4%. JCP mall portfolio, given its national scale and high quality, posted this growth in light of negative sales comps at our malls located in tourist markets and energy-dependent markets. 
It's good to see that Hawaii is starting to rebound. LVMH sales have increased double digits year to date. We closed on a number of asset transactions during the quarter, including the sale of 4 properties: Owings Mills, Eastridge, Provo and 522 Fifth Avenue, and acquired the remaining interest in Spokane Valley. We are under contract, subject to normal closing conditions, for the sale of 1 Stockton in San Francisco for over $100 million and the office component of 685 Fifth Avenue for $150 million. 
We are progressing on a number of redevelopment projects, notably the new Dick's Sporting Goods stores at each of our 5 Houston malls, a new theater and food district at Oakbrook Center in Chicago, the expansion of the Dillard's at Fashion Place in Salt Lake City, the expansion of Staten Island Mall and several of the Sears locations we own with Seritage. GGP is a firm believer that higher-quality retail assets will not only continue to be in demand by tenants but also continue to grow in value. We own 100 of the top 400 malls in the United States of America. That accounts for 95% of our NOI. 
A department store closure is an opportunity. We have proven that thesis. GGP has nearly 430 anchor stores with only 1 vacancy, which happens to be a relocated Nordstrom's at Ala Moana. We are currently in lease negotiation for that space. Our investor deck contains inside [ph] information regarding how we have re-tenanted over 80 boxes, and the new uses are numerous. 
Our balance sheet is strong. Debt maturities are laddered over a long period of time. We're working to make our balance sheet even stronger. The pursuit of selling JV interests in a couple of our malls is in process, and the primary proceeds will be used to pay down debt. We focus on the long-term cash flow growth potential of the business, which we believe can generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth, high single-digit FFO per share growth and a growing dividend.
To be successful in retail real estate, you must know your customer and listen to them. We recently surveyed 88,000 mall shoppers and learned from valuable insights. First, the customer wants a mall to be appropriately curated. What does this mean? It means that we have leased a mall to a variety of retailers, restaurants and entertainment vendors at best of the trade area. Over the past 5 years, we have turned the tenant mix by approximately 50%. 
In addition, we're incorporating technology to make consumers aware of what is at the mall. An interesting factoid: we have 739 restaurants in our portfolio, 564 service and 179 fast casual. As I mentioned, technology has 2 uses: first, awareness; and the second, way finding. Consumers use their smartphones to locate stores and branded products. We want to ensure the tenants at our malls are at the top of the search list. We can never be good enough on awareness. 
The second point from our survey is that a customer said the biggest pain point in a mall is to find parking. Ironic that most weekends, it is hard to find parking in our malls. We're investing to solve this problem by implementing a number of initiatives: having mall employees park in designated areas; allowing customers to park closer to the entrance; ticketless valet services, cashless, car is ready when you leave the mall; and information of parking space availability, as we call it, the red light/green light, open-space counters and incorporating this information into new digital mall maps. Our goal is to have a customer start their search on Google. That map guides the customer to a parking spot and blue-dots her virtually to the store.
Let me give you a little flavor of various industries as I see them over the past few years. The health care industry. We've seen that people are more fit. Fitness is big business, whether it's in food, health clubs, apparel. It has grown multifold. The leaders in previous years were names like Bally Fitness, Jack LaLanne and New York Sports Club. The leaders today include SoulCycle, Equinox, CorePower Yoga, Flywheel and Orangetheory Fitness and innovations like the Peloton bicycle. The fitness segment is bigger than ever. 
Let's go to Internet search, which has experienced explosive growth. At the beginning, it was AOL. Today, it is led by Google. Smartphones, our staple of our generation. BlackBerry and Motorola were the leaders. Today, it's iPhone and Galaxy. 
In apparel, the recent demise of Deb Shops and Delia's and the bankruptcies by Wet Seal and PacSun, which I believe have viable turnaround plans, mask the explosive growth of H&M, Zara, Trimark and L Brands, just to name a few. I was recently with the H&M team in Stockholm. They are focused on expansion, where they will be in 50 years and making their operations sustainable. Inditex, the owner of Zara and other lines, may be one of the best logistics company in the world, getting the newest items to the customer when they want. And L Brands, forever young and innovative.
You might ask where all this is heading. My point is bringing these examples up is that there are winners and losers in every category. The highest-quality malls today has evolved and provide the consumer with what they want, where the want it and when they want it. 
Oakbrook Center in Chicago generated $500 per square foot 5 years ago. Today, it's over $900. It is the home of Tesla, Warby Parker, Apple, H&M, Zara, Nordstrom and Microsoft, just to name a few. There are over 20 restaurants and a new theater opening soon. GGP is positioned for the long-term success of the retail business. 
As CEO, my primary job is to allocate capital in order to generate 4% to 5% EBITDA growth annually. I believe that EBITDA is an important metric to measure our performance. The sales per square foot metric needs to be viewed in light of other measures. Just as an example, we reported sales per square foot of $584 on a rolling 12-month basis. This metric doesn't take into account varying ownership interests we have in the mall, it doesn't take into account the variety of NOI levels generated by the malls and certainly doesn't include all the rent-paying tenants in the malls. If we were to weigh this metric for NOI contribution to GGP, the $584 will become $691, down slightly from $704. 
The mall industry has been here since the early 1960s. The long history of this industry also contains some insights. Looking back to GGP's shareholder letter from 1995, a couple of messages caught my eye that were highlighted by the team. The retail and shopping center industry has been overbuilt. The ratio of square feet of retail space per capita has doubled in the past 20 years. Only the fittest retailers will survive and the survivors will come out stronger and smarter. Department stores. Many may fail, but such failure will provide opportunities to replace poorly performing stores with new and exciting retailers. I want to repeat, this was the Bucksbaum in 1995. 
My personal view of the retail real estate industry in the U.S. is that it is over-retailed. This is especially evident when comparing retail square feet per capita in the U.S. to other developed countries. The primary reason retail properties have closed and will close is obsolescence. Once again, it's obsolescence: competition from other bricks-and-mortar retail. 
As the footprint of lower-quality shopping centers shrink, then the winners will continue to be the A malls that become larger and more productive. A malls have experienced double-digit sales growth since 2012. Within the 10 most populated markets across the U.S., sales of A malls have grown 20%, while [indiscernible] 4%. This dynamic is evident in Atlanta, Boston, Chicago, Dallas, Houston, L.A., New York, Philadelphia, Washington, D.C. and Miami. 
Over the decade -- over the next decade, we may, again, we may see 300 malls, approximately 60 million square feet of in-line GLA accounting for about $18 billion of sales disappear. However, the densification of the top 500 malls to the tune of 50 million square feet with sales of $600 per square foot is equivalent to $25 billion of sales. The share of retail sales at high-quality malls will increase. This is where we have positioned GGP. The GGP team is focused on execution. 
Michael will now review our results and outlook for the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred earlier in the year than we ex
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Let's start with the first quarter. After adjusting for the stock sale gains and the start of revenue recognition for our condo development at Ala Moana, both of which occurred earlier in the year than we expected, we came in at approximately $5 million ahead of our guidance. 
Moving down the income statement, starting with same-store NOI, we came in at $561 million or growth of 5.2%, and this was approximately $6 million higher than our guidance. The main driver of the variance was termination income that came in early.
EBITDA was $590 million as reported less $40 million pretax related to the condos leaves $550 million versus our guidance number of $525 million, for a positive variance of $25 million. Approximately $13 million of that came from the stock sale gain. We expected to sell the stock this year and took advantage of 1Q market conditions. We did not have the stock sale gain in our first quarter guidance, but it was in our full year number. Of the remaining $12 million, $6 million came from the same-store NOI beat I noted, and the remaining $6 million is from a variety of small items. 
Below EBITDA, we wrote off approximately $7.5 million of an accrued interest receivable related to our Aliansce notes. And as part of the condos, we had about $10 million of tax related to those.
To bring it all together, FFO came in at $383 million or $48 million better than guidance. The $40 million of condo EBITDA is offset by $10 million in tax plus $13 million from the stock sale gains plus the $6 million in other positive EBITDA, which is basically offset by the Aliansce write-off. Doing all that math leaves about $5 million, which is basically attributable to the termination income.
Moving on to the second quarter. Guidance for second quarter, company FFO $325 million to $345 million or $0.34 to $0.36 per share. Our guidance includes $13 million to $14 million of after-tax FFO related to the condos, which is the same run rate we expect for the third quarter and fourth quarter, assuming sales and cost trends remain the same. At the midpoint of our guidance, we expect same-store NOI of approximately $560 million, around 3.5% growth. We expect EBITDA of approximately $540 million or growth of around 7.5%.
Moving on to our balance sheet -- Im sorry, first let's go through full year 2016. Our expectations remain the same: same-store NOI of 4% to 5% or a little over $2.3 billion; EBITDA of 8% to 9%, almost $2.3 billion; and FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.56, approximately $1.475 billion. 
Now let's move on to the balance sheet. We extended the $1.4 billion term loan that we have, out 3 years to 2019 plus 2 1-year extensions. We reduced recourse on the loan from 100% to 50% and maintained pricing. As we have previously indicated, we are in the process of looking at asset sales and sales of joint venture interests. We would expect to use a significant portion of the proceeds to pay down debt. If our plan succeeds, we would take our net debt-to-EBITDA from a range of 8 to 8.5, down to 7.5 to 8x by year end. 
With that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: So just to take a step back, some of the assets that we're looking at are large in terms of the joint ventures so the dollars could be significant. Some of the assets are not that large. It's a variety. I'm not really comfortable giving out dollar proceed
componenttext: So just to take a step back, some of the assets that we're looking at are large in terms of the joint ventures so the dollars could be significant. Some of the assets are not that large. It's a variety. I'm not really comfortable giving out dollar proceeds because we're in the preliminary stages. The bulk of the dollars would be used to pay down debt. We have an idea of what debt we would pay down, but we're not 100% settled. It kind of depends on timing of cash inputs, which loans you want to take down, which not. None of the transactions, other than the ones that are closed, are in our guidance, so 685, Stockton not yet in our guidance.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, Sandeep, you mentioned the portfolio on a proportionate share would have much higher productivity than what you report overall. Yet, if you're going to do more JVs, it suggests sort of a diluting of the earnings power, the NOI power of GGP
componenttext: Okay. And then, Sandeep, you mentioned the portfolio on a proportionate share would have much higher productivity than what you report overall. Yet, if you're going to do more JVs, it suggests sort of a diluting of the earnings power, the NOI power of GGP. So can you just sort of balance for us how we should think about adding complexity to the company, selling off stakes, potentially more Ala Moana-type assets versus trying to keep the sales -- the high sales productivity in the A and A+ qualities of the portfolio more towards the shareholders?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, there is a balance. And as we have said, the assets we're looking to bring in joint venture partners are those that are substantial value within our portfolio, so there's a tilt to diversification, and they're in tourist markets. When we sol
componenttext: So obviously, there is a balance. And as we have said, the assets we're looking to bring in joint venture partners are those that are substantial value within our portfolio, so there's a tilt to diversification, and they're in tourist markets. When we sold 37.5% of Ala Moana, it was because we felt an asset of $5.5 billion, $6 billion would be in a, call it, 12%, 13%, 14% of the total market cap of the company, and it was prudent to start to derisk from a specific market and having so much concentration. So we are balancing a few things: the concentration in certain tourist markets as well as the arbitrage between public and private markets. And then we think that you can use the proceeds prudently to pay down -- substantially used to pay down debt and still maintain the advantage of having an A-quality mall portfolio.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just finally, are any of the sales or any of the joint ventures in a portfolio-type situation where you may be talking to 1 JV entity about a number of malls or selling a bunch of malls to 1 entity?
componenttext: Okay. And just finally, are any of the sales or any of the joint ventures in a portfolio-type situation where you may be talking to 1 JV entity about a number of malls or selling a bunch of malls to 1 entity?

componenttextpreview: No.
componenttext: No.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Was the change in sales per square foot at Christiana due to the temporary Tesla store?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We don't break it down per asset, and I don't want to go down that path. Once again, the fluctuations can be quite a bit, and our entire reason of pointing it out was more to talk about the strength of the portfolio being positive than to focus on the neg
componenttext: We don't break it down per asset, and I don't want to go down that path. Once again, the fluctuations can be quite a bit, and our entire reason of pointing it out was more to talk about the strength of the portfolio being positive than to focus on the negative Christiana. And so since it was -- it stuck out like a [indiscernible] and we wanted to point it out. But the focus really was the remainder of the portfolio.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the -- beyond the dispositions to pay down debt, is GGP still looking to further, call it, small portfolio?
componenttext: Okay. And then the -- beyond the dispositions to pay down debt, is GGP still looking to further, call it, small portfolio?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, we've -- we are always recycling capital. We're always looking to find lower-quality assets or lower-growth assets and try to cull them, as we have shown you in the first quarter. We've culled the portfolio by a few assets. It's our -- we will cont
componenttext: Again, we've -- we are always recycling capital. We're always looking to find lower-quality assets or lower-growth assets and try to cull them, as we have shown you in the first quarter. We've culled the portfolio by a few assets. It's our -- we will continue doing that, and we've been disciplined about doing that over the last 5 years. We've sold over 30 malls one-off besides the Rouse spin. And that will continue to be our program for the next 5 years.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Christy McElroy of Citi.
componenttext: The next question is from Christy McElroy of Citi.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Given issues with Aeropostale and PacSun, can you discuss your updated expectations for the impact of store closings and bankruptcies in 2016? And there's been some press reports about potential issues at Forever 21. Are you seeing anything unusual in ter
componenttext: Given issues with Aeropostale and PacSun, can you discuss your updated expectations for the impact of store closings and bankruptcies in 2016? And there's been some press reports about potential issues at Forever 21. Are you seeing anything unusual in terms of your receivables there? Any concerns there?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me -- I think we're at second base on understanding when the closures and bankruptcies are. As you know, 30 to 45 days ago, we all felt slightly better. And then you've seen PacSun file for bankruptcy. You've seen Sports Authority liquidating. You'
componenttext: So let me -- I think we're at second base on understanding when the closures and bankruptcies are. As you know, 30 to 45 days ago, we all felt slightly better. And then you've seen PacSun file for bankruptcy. You've seen Sports Authority liquidating. You've seen Sport Chalet, which we have none, liquidating. And of course, the rumors continue to spiral about Aeropostale. So our job is to continue to be cautious going into the second half of the year. So we are going to continue to be conservative. The aspect of Forever 21, when the New York Post article came out, I did reach out to the CEO of Forever 21, who has sent me an e-mail confirming that there are no issues in the company. It was all about -- I think they're going to issue their own press release today, I've been told. It had to do with their software change, which created some sort of a timing issue with vendor payments. We have seen 0 receivables from Forever 21. So -- and as a matter of fact, we actually see their business in our portfolio turning to the positive.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then Michael, on the Park Lane condo sales, I thought you had previously talked about $45 million to $50 million of after-tax profit, but it looks like you had $30 million in Q1. But you talked about another, I think, $40 million for the back ha
componenttext: Okay. And then Michael, on the Park Lane condo sales, I thought you had previously talked about $45 million to $50 million of after-tax profit, but it looks like you had $30 million in Q1. But you talked about another, I think, $40 million for the back half -- for the rest of the year, $13 million to $14 million a quarter. Did that increase from your previous expectations? And then what portion of that guidance is related to the condo gains net of tax versus the gain of sale of air rights?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So for the full year -- so in the quarter, the $30 million is $22 million for the condos and $7.5 million for the air rights. So we're going to lump together those 2 things throughout the year. So when I said $13 million to $14 million for each quarter, 2
componenttext: So for the full year -- so in the quarter, the $30 million is $22 million for the condos and $7.5 million for the air rights. So we're going to lump together those 2 things throughout the year. So when I said $13 million to $14 million for each quarter, 2, 3 and 4, that's roughly $10 million FFO -- after-tax FFO on the condos and $3.5 million on the air rights. So I'm going to keep them combined, which is easier for me to track what's going on. It does so happen that the air rights flow through the other revenue line item that you see in our proportionate financial statement. And then we had to separate out specifically the condo revenues and the condo costs. There are some additional costs associated with the project that is a small number that flow through our marketing, but it's not really all that relevant.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was the air right originally anticipated? I think you recognized about $25 million through other revenue in Q3 and Q4. Why is that marked...
componenttext: Was the air right originally anticipated? I think you recognized about $25 million through other revenue in Q3 and Q4. Why is that marked...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had to take the first $25 million as a gain up front and then the other $25 million gets -- was deferred. As the condos come in, we take that in pro rata.
componenttext: We had to take the first $25 million as a gain up front and then the other $25 million gets -- was deferred. As the condos come in, we take that in pro rata.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: The next question is from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the Aeropostale and the PacSun discussion. It sounds like Forever 21, not seeing any receivables issues. Have you had any -- had any issues with Aeropostale? I guess the Journal has something out this morning suggesting they're preparin
componenttext: Just going back to the Aeropostale and the PacSun discussion. It sounds like Forever 21, not seeing any receivables issues. Have you had any -- had any issues with Aeropostale? I guess the Journal has something out this morning suggesting they're preparing for bankruptcy as soon as next week. But have they -- are they late on their payments?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's May 3, Vincent. So if we don't get this payment over the next few days, the writing's on the wall. I mean it's too early right now. We got our April payment. It's only May 3.
componenttext: It's May 3, Vincent. So if we don't get this payment over the next few days, the writing's on the wall. I mean it's too early right now. We got our April payment. It's only May 3.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just maybe a question on your comment about turning over the tenant mix by 50% over the last 5 years. I'm just wondering, if you think about the next 5 years, do you think that turnover will accelerate? And then -- just give
componenttext: Got it. Got it, okay. And then just maybe a question on your comment about turning over the tenant mix by 50% over the last 5 years. I'm just wondering, if you think about the next 5 years, do you think that turnover will accelerate? And then -- just given the changing sort of demands from your shoppers and the changing shopper patterns that you're seeing? And if so, how do you think this will change the sort of risk profile, the cash flows and maybe some of the CapEx spend that you might have to put up to turn over those tenants?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Actually, we are looking at it slightly differently. This year, the retention ratio is about 70% to 75%. So we used to rotate about 50% annually. This year, it's 25%. So actually, the amount of churn has gotten less. The retention has gotten better, and I
componenttext: Actually, we are looking at it slightly differently. This year, the retention ratio is about 70% to 75%. So we used to rotate about 50% annually. This year, it's 25%. So actually, the amount of churn has gotten less. The retention has gotten better, and I think that's also a function of the tenants' productivity actually being better and their desire to stay. So we are actually looking at the churn to be a lot less, the retention ratio to be at 70% to 75%.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last question maybe on the rent spreads. I know you've kind of, in the past, talked about 8% to 10% as being a reasonable number. You have been beating that number for quite some time. It does seem like the spread, at least for 201
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last question maybe on the rent spreads. I know you've kind of, in the past, talked about 8% to 10% as being a reasonable number. You have been beating that number for quite some time. It does seem like the spread, at least for 2016, commencement have been coming down over the last couple of quarters. Do you still think 8% to 10% is the right sort of range? Or is there something going on that would suggest maybe a slightly lower or higher normalized spread?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I say, right, if you say it often enough, it would be right one day. And so here's some of my math. I've always maintained that, over the long term, the business is a 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So over a 5-year period, you just sit back and
componenttext: As I say, right, if you say it often enough, it would be right one day. And so here's some of my math. I've always maintained that, over the long term, the business is a 3% to 4% sales growth business a year. So over a 5-year period, you just sit back and say it's a 20% growth assuming that you get annual increases of 2% to 3%, so you're getting 10% to 12.5% increases over that period of time, and that's where the 8% to 10% spread comes. So if you -- if nothing happens but you steadily grow 3% to 4% a year, you should get 8% to 10% spreads consistently, and that's really the underwriting of the business. And that should give you the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Ross Nussbaum of UBS.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, I was hoping you could talk about that $1.4 billion secured term loan amendment a little more and just discuss why you decided to do the amendment now ahead of the 2018 maturity. And why not just get closer to the maturity and start thinking about d
componenttext: Mike, I was hoping you could talk about that $1.4 billion secured term loan amendment a little more and just discuss why you decided to do the amendment now ahead of the 2018 maturity. And why not just get closer to the maturity and start thinking about doing individual refis? And I guess the related question is, why is there still any recourse on that loan?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The loan has been around for a real long time. I mean it predates the current management team. It's been renewed a number of times. The recourse was always part of that loan, so we thought it was a pretty good thing that we got the recourse down in 1/2. W
componenttext: The loan has been around for a real long time. I mean it predates the current management team. It's been renewed a number of times. The recourse was always part of that loan, so we thought it was a pretty good thing that we got the recourse down in 1/2. We decided to extend it out because market conditions were more favorable in the bank market than in the CMBS market. There's about 35% of the blown value -- the value of the properties in the loans are B malls. We do have flexibility to pay off about $500 million of that loan, which was a condition previously, and we continued it on without any prepayment penalty, without any -- without more than having to pay 100% of the loan down. So we took advantage of just pushing it out. We've maintained the flexibility to pay some of it down. And there are some assets that are close to stabilization, when you would think about doing long-term financing. Some of those assets are core assets in that portfolio, so it might not be so easy to take them out so quickly. We'll see about that. It depends on how much of it we decide to pay down. So it's really a market call just given what was going on in the CMBS market at the time.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The related question I have relative to the asset sales is, how much prepayable debt do you have at this point that you can get rid of without penalty? I know you just mentioned the $500 million on your term loan. What else do you have at this point
componenttext: Okay. The related question I have relative to the asset sales is, how much prepayable debt do you have at this point that you can get rid of without penalty? I know you just mentioned the $500 million on your term loan. What else do you have at this point that can be prepaid without penalty?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you're asking the question in the context of "Are there high-coupon debt that we could pay off?" I'd say the answer is no. There's really nothing left along those lines. Believe me, we scoured it -- we scour it regularly. We do have, I would say, order
componenttext: If you're asking the question in the context of "Are there high-coupon debt that we could pay off?" I'd say the answer is no. There's really nothing left along those lines. Believe me, we scoured it -- we scour it regularly. We do have, I would say, order of magnitude, another $500 million to $1 billion that would be prepayable. Now some of that might be in early 2017 maturity that I might pay a little of the fees in sum [ph] to get rid of in 2016. But our ability to pay down -- we have the ability to probably pay down in order of magnitude of $1.5 billion of debt. We may not, but we have that ability.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess where I'm going is I think we're all trying to figure out, I think this is in relation to the first question that was asked on the call, what our expectations should be with respect to potential earnings dilution as we balance that against th
componenttext: Yes. I guess where I'm going is I think we're all trying to figure out, I think this is in relation to the first question that was asked on the call, what our expectations should be with respect to potential earnings dilution as we balance that against the deleveraging that you've talked about. And is there any type of guidance you can give us about the magnitude of the difference between the cap rates on these sales and the interest rates on the loans getting repaid?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say, look, we have generally been fairly conservative in giving expectations early on pricing, earlier -- orally on these types of plans. It's just been how we've been running this. If we are successful in the asset sales, the dilution number coul
componenttext: I would say, look, we have generally been fairly conservative in giving expectations early on pricing, earlier -- orally on these types of plans. It's just been how we've been running this. If we are successful in the asset sales, the dilution number could be large. I hesitate to put numbers around it. It probably impacts 2017 way more than it impacts 2016, if we are successful. We got a lot on our plate. We've got a lot of moving parts. So as much as you want answers to those questions and want to have it nailed down, we would like to as well and we're just not prepared to talk about that.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: The next question is from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, if you go through -- mall by mall and -- could you help describe what percent of the square footage of retailers is actually dragging down your overall sales productivity? And if you look at the pipeline of those better retailers that can potenti
componenttext: Sandeep, if you go through -- mall by mall and -- could you help describe what percent of the square footage of retailers is actually dragging down your overall sales productivity? And if you look at the pipeline of those better retailers that can potentially move into your malls, how much of those -- that better group of retailers is there to offset the poor performers?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I can't sort of give you the answer on a percentage basis, but I will sort of sit back and say, looking at every category, as I mentioned, all the categories were up. Home furnishings, food, apparel, electronics, they were all up. So as a group, we
componenttext: Again, I can't sort of give you the answer on a percentage basis, but I will sort of sit back and say, looking at every category, as I mentioned, all the categories were up. Home furnishings, food, apparel, electronics, they were all up. So as a group, we're actually seeing positive spreads -- I mean positive sales growth. The other aspect, I think, we speak -- and the reason we keep talking about total sales as much as sales per square foot of 10,000 [ph] -- less [ph] than 10,000 feet is because the total sales truly does capture what we're seeing in the market, where you got the larger apparel guys, like H&M, Zara, Primark, coming in with very high sales productivity and actually lifting the sales productivity of apparel within the mall. And so -- and the other advantage of doing it that way is that what we're really after is to increase our penetration rate in a specific market, okay? That really, from an operator perspective, is the most important. If I can increase the total mall sales by 2%, 3%, 4%, 5%, I'm increasing my penetration rate. I'm increasing my traffic. And we're going to continue to see that evolve. I mean the next-generation retailers: the Warby Parkers, the Bonoboses, the Teslas, I mean Apple and Microsoft, are going to continue to evolve. The larger format -- L Brands, the PINK stores, the lululemons, the Fabletics, the list is quite extensive. So you -- my entire reason of sort of speaking different industries in my opening remarks was to sort of capture the fact that there are winners and losers in every business. Let's not focus only on the retail business or the real estate business. You could be in the e-commerce business. You could be in the Internet search business. You could be in the phone business and you're going to have winners and losers. And the beauty is if you have great real estate, as Milton Cooper said 20 years ago and Matthew and -- Bucksbaum said 20 years ago, okay, it's an opportunity to replace. And you continue to see an evolution of retail with more productive tenants. So it's a constant evolution, and we've seen this pattern for 50 years.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick question on your CAM expenses. Obviously -- well, at least on the surface, it looks like it's more of a profit center than breakeven type of business at this point. Do you guys get any pushbacks from retailers that look at that numb
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick question on your CAM expenses. Obviously -- well, at least on the surface, it looks like it's more of a profit center than breakeven type of business at this point. Do you guys get any pushbacks from retailers that look at that number and say you're basically collecting more than the cost?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- as you know, most CAM is a fixed CAM. The reason everyone went to a fixed CAM basis was basically not focused on breaking it out and going to audit processes and the like. And the way the retailer looks at it, it's a total occupancy cost. So wheth
componenttext: It's -- as you know, most CAM is a fixed CAM. The reason everyone went to a fixed CAM basis was basically not focused on breaking it out and going to audit processes and the like. And the way the retailer looks at it, it's a total occupancy cost. So whether you allocate it to CAM, or you allocate it to rent, from their perspective, it's a total cost. Since it's a fixed number, not a fluctuating number, it almost doesn't matter which pot it belongs in.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Miller (sic) [Mueller] of JPMorgan.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Miller (sic) [Mueller] of JPMorgan.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in the -- it looks like you have about $1 billion of development and redevelopment underway at this point in the current pipeline in the shadow. Guess as you look out over the next, say, 5 years or so, what do you think the average pipeline size is tha
componenttext: So in the -- it looks like you have about $1 billion of development and redevelopment underway at this point in the current pipeline in the shadow. Guess as you look out over the next, say, 5 years or so, what do you think the average pipeline size is that you're going to have?

componenttext: We feel that it's -- at least over the next 5 years, we've been -- we think it's $300 million to $500 million a year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of spend?
componenttext: Of spend?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of spend. We think that sort of generally comes from redevelopment of anchor tenant boxes and densification of the assets. Where we're adding -- what's going on, as I mentioned, again, in my opening remarks, is the top 500 malls have a tremendous demand f
componenttext: Of spend. We think that sort of generally comes from redevelopment of anchor tenant boxes and densification of the assets. Where we're adding -- what's going on, as I mentioned, again, in my opening remarks, is the top 500 malls have a tremendous demand for space. And so these top 500 malls are getting densified. I mean to get -- and I sort of said 100,000 square feet per mall, but I think that's pretty conservative. Just in the 5 Houston malls, we're adding Bix [ph]. I think each Bix [ph] is 60,000 to 80,000 square feet. And so I think there's at least [ph] $300 million to $500 million of growth that we can see in our portfolio over the next 5 years.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Is there any update on Norwalk, the timing for that?
componenttext: Got it. Is there any update on Norwalk, the timing for that?

componenttextpreview: Again, as you know, the 2 anchors are signed, and we have been very vocal that it's going to be focused upon our leasing-up abilities, and the leasing is going quite well. So based upon getting final approvals and getting our leasing in place, it should b
componenttext: Again, as you know, the 2 anchors are signed, and we have been very vocal that it's going to be focused upon our leasing-up abilities, and the leasing is going quite well. So based upon getting final approvals and getting our leasing in place, it should be a end-of-the-year, '16 groundbreaking or very early '17. But we look at it to be the end of the year '16 groundbreaking for an '18 opening.

componenttext: I think we spoke about 1 office, and I also said in my opening remarks, 1 Stockton, which is a retail asset in San Francisco, which is under contract to be sold. At this moment in time, those are the 2 that we are going to sell. Will we evaluate selling another asset or 2? We may.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. Sandeep, I just wanted to ask you a quick question on the survey you did. I think you said it was 88,000 customers, and you called out 3 things. You called out wanting to get the mall to be curated towards its local community and what the shoppers
componenttext: Right. Sandeep, I just wanted to ask you a quick question on the survey you did. I think you said it was 88,000 customers, and you called out 3 things. You called out wanting to get the mall to be curated towards its local community and what the shoppers want. You called out technology, and you called out parking. I guess, how long was the survey? Like how many questions did you ask customers? Was there a difference that you saw regionally in terms of like major metros like New York versus other areas where, I would say, the service levels and what people can order online here is much different than in middle America? And I'm just curious whether there was anything else that you teased out from a technology. Or what did the customer say about ordering online, pickup in store, if that was asked? What other details can you share?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So Michael, I mean, of course, it was a national survey, so it was across all our 120 malls. I can't sort of tell you, but these are -- these were themes that were -- that came out loud across the board. I think the customer, it's proven now, wants t
componenttext: Yes. So Michael, I mean, of course, it was a national survey, so it was across all our 120 malls. I can't sort of tell you, but these are -- these were themes that were -- that came out loud across the board. I think the customer, it's proven now, wants to buy or browse online and pick it up in the store and return it to the store. So I don't think we're seeing any difference. I don't think the customer is saying -- did not say "Hey, I'm not coming to your mall because I'm buying online" at all. That was not even part of the equation. On the contrary, they all wanted to come to the mall. They all like to come to the mall. That's where they socially interact, and they just want the mall to be curated correctly for them to be able to have a parking space. Now the technology part is where we are very focused because we do know that customers -- 2/3 of the customers start their process of buying on their mobile phones. And it all starts up with a Google search. So the whole aspect here is to take you painlessly from a Google search to a parking spot to the store. That, again, just facilitates and time-saves the customer. The customer wants to actually go to the mall to shop. We've seen no dropoff in traffic from the end of the last year. So we're not seeing that at all.

componenttext: With regard to the bankruptcies that have been announced or, to count ARROW in there, that are about to be announced or count Tailored Brands in there as well, stores that are closing, what's your total exposure on ABR, I guess? So you got PacSun, you got ARROW and you got Tailored Brands and you got Sports Authority.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: We -- the total exposure is -- take a lot of square feet and multiply it by a big rent great number, and it feels like a big number. The real exposure is what we do on the leasing front to mitigate that exposure. So last year, I think we had a growth expo
componenttext: We -- the total exposure is -- take a lot of square feet and multiply it by a big rent great number, and it feels like a big number. The real exposure is what we do on the leasing front to mitigate that exposure. So last year, I think we had a growth exposure of 40, and we had a net reduction of 20. And we ended up with a net of 20 given all the stuff that went on last year. We kind of used that 20 as the reason for our bankruptcy reserve this year, and we are hoping not to use the full amount. It is baked into our numbers, and it's hard to answer on a specific tenant like that, Rich, because there are spaces that they keep. There are spaces that they give. There are spaces that we think they're going to give. And we've got 5 guys lined up to take them so...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll just sort of add in more color, Rich, is that essentially, we don't anticipate the case of PacSun or Aeropostale to be a liquidation. And if you don't anticipate a liquidation, then there will be some closures, for which we have already been activ
componenttext: So I'll just sort of add in more color, Rich, is that essentially, we don't anticipate the case of PacSun or Aeropostale to be a liquidation. And if you don't anticipate a liquidation, then there will be some closures, for which we have already been active in releasing a lot of those spaces. And it would really come back more to be what financial assistance are we prepared to provide PacSun and Aeropostale to keep them afloat, to give them the chance to effectuate their turnaround, so -- which is why you're not taking into account the total exposure. As Michael said, if you take into account the total exposure, you've got 100-odd stores at 5,000 square feet, and you can do the math. It's an astronomical math. But since you don't anticipate a liquidation, I think our conservative reserve of $20 million should be sufficient, we hope.
