componenttext: Right, yes. I was actually thinking a little more positively, guys, that it isn't really astronomical. I'm guessing each of these is under 0.5% of base rent. So maybe the total, if you'll ask them all, but like you say, you wouldn't. It's not even 2%. But now the second thing is why the current focus on debt reduction, on leverage reduction? As you guys, I'm sure are well aware, that's not historically a general growth sort of thing to do. And I think it's great, but why now for debt reduction?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in a number of meetings where he's talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to husband
componenttext: That's a -- I have to say, Rich, that's really a great question because it is something that we talk about all the time. Sandeep has been in a number of meetings where he's talked about potential headwinds in the economy. And perhaps it's time to husband cash rather than continue to be aggressive on the spending front. It's -- we're evolving as a company. It's a much more stabilized portfolio. The market seems to be reacting well to the idea. It doesn't inhibit but enhances our flexibility at the margin. So 3 years from now, maybe it will be different, maybe not. But right now, the way we're running the company, given the use of proceeds, given what we could do, we think reducing the leverage will be the best use of proceeds. We may save some for other things, but for the most part, it will be to pay down debt.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Okay, good. And then just the last thing on that. Does it make sense to just to sort of issue equity at this point and kind of get it behind you, I mean, or do -- at least some equity to get it behind you?

componenttext: Again, I mean, to me, one, issuing equity, just given what we think, is a low priority. But let's not forget that there are -- the assets are being priced much stronger in the private market that they are the public market, so we try to take advantage of that arbitrage. And I think that it's a prudent thing to do right now.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: And we've sort of maintained that equity is very precious cargo for us. We've actually been a net buyer, not a -- we've not issued equity once since 20 -- since November 2010. And again, it hasn't presented us with any flexibility to do and operate our business, so we have no plans to issue equity.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Caitlin Burrows. Just a quick one. I think in the prepared remarks, you guys mentioned that there was a write-down related to the Aliansce note. I was just wondering if you could go through that again and give some more details.
componenttext: This is Caitlin Burrows. Just a quick one. I think in the prepared remarks, you guys mentioned that there was a write-down related to the Aliansce note. I was just wondering if you could go through that again and give some more details.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books. And I'm going to do
componenttext: As you know, we did a transaction. We basically sold our interest in Aliansce back in 2013. We gave management the opportunity to buy a certain amount of shares. We provided them with the notes. That note at the time was on our books. And I'm going to do this in dollars because the currency between the U.S. and the real is difficult for us to follow. But we have about USD 160 million note. Over the course of the last few years, the real has gotten weaker and weaker. That led to a -- at the quarter -- at the beginning of the quarter, we had approximately $100 million note, all due to foreign currency losses, all losses that run through our GAAP statements but not our company FFO. We felt that it was time to impair the note. That note  -- the collateral for that note are the shares of Aliansce. On the day we impaired the note, we took it down to the value of the shares on that particular day. That resulted in the $29 million impairment loss that you see in the financials. The remaining $7.5 million that we took through income is a write-off of the accrued interest receivable that we had been receiving on that note. So the way we structured the note was we would accrue interest for a year and then they would pay. So we had basically June through February earnings that we needed to write off. So that's the total of the $36.5 million. It's really $29 million and $7.5 million, 2 separate pieces.

componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Kevin Berry. Plea
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Growth Properties Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded. 
Now I will turn the conference over to your host, Kevin Berry. Please begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tyron. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Second  Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking
componenttext:
Thank you, Tyron. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Second  Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, August 2, 2016.  Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the earnings release and supplemental filed in Form 8-K with the SEC and also available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone. Our latest sustainability report is available on our website. For the past several years, we have been identifying and executing on ways to improve our impact on the environment. I want to mention a few highlights
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone. Our latest sustainability report is available on our website. For the past several years, we have been identifying and executing on ways to improve our impact on the environment. I want to mention a few highlights from the report. 
We have diverted 54,000 tons of waste from landfills, which is enough to fill all 4,500 garbage trucks. Water consumption has been reduced by 64 million gallons, which is enough wanted to fill almost 100 Olympic sized swimming pools. We have completed lighting and upgrades which will save the equivalent energy of taking 4,600 ohms of the electric grid. And we expect to be one of the largest generators of solar energy in the U.S. this year. We continue to explore new opportunities to implement sustainable operating factors throughout our portfolio. 
Now let's return to our recent results. FFO per share was $0.35, up almost 7% from the same quarter last year. Year-to-date FFO per share was $0.75, up over 15% from last year. EBITDA was up 6.5% from the same quarter last year and over 13% year-to-date from last year. Same-store NOI growth was up 4% for the quarter and 4.6% year-to-date. Results were driven primarily by continued strength from our portfolio and occupancy gains and expense management. The increased according to dividend to $0.20, 11% increase over last year. 
The portfolio was over 96% leased at quarter end and occupancy stood at about 91.5% as we expected -- which is what we expected at this time of the year. Total sales excluding department stores and Christiana Mall were up about 3% and sales for tenants under 10,000 feet were flat excluding Christiana Mall. Categories that performed fast were restaurants, home furnishings and health and personal care. We even had a positive comp in apparel. This is for total sales x department stores. Lease spreads for leases commencing in the trailing 12 months are about 13% or a little over $8 per square foot. To counter our lease spread, we include based [indiscernible] and compared them to the ending rent on the expiring lease at the beginning rent of the new lease on a street-to-street basis, regardless of size. 
Turning to property content. In June, we sold our [indiscernible] in San Francisco for approximately $50 million, which values the asset at a subsea cat on the trailing 12-month basis. This is the highest price paid for an asset per square foot in Union Square, almost $5,800 per square foot. You may recall, we acquired this asset in 2014, one of our initial investments in urban retail with a plan to release space since the existing tenants was relocating to the square. We successfully released the space to T-Mobile, stabilizing the assets and then sold our interest. On an IR basis, we realized about 40%. 
In June, we sold Pioneer Place office buildings, a class A asset, for approximately $122 million which values the asset [indiscernible]. In July, we sold New Gate Mall, located in Austin Utah for approximately $17 million, which values the asset at a high single-digit cap rate. The estimated reclose [indiscernible] Valley Mall located in Medford, Oregon for over $60 million, which value the asset at the high single-digit cut-rate. 
We're pleased to announce a new joint venture with TIAA Global Asset Management at Fashion Show in Las Vegas. GGP and TIAA are partners at other properties and we look forward to our new partnership with them. As you know, Fashion Show is a one-of-a-kind asset. Over the past several years, the GGP team has successfully re-tenanted several anchor boxes bringing in Macy's, Urban Outfitters and Dick's Sporting Goods to the mall. We brought to life The Boulevard entrance bringing a number of known dining and leisure options. TIAA would now own approximately 50% of Fashion Show. The transaction values asset at approximately $2.5 billion at cap rates. 
We closed on the previously announced acquisition of 218 West 57th Street in New York City. You may recall, we entered into a commitment to acquire this property located across the street from the new Nordstrom back in 2014. The asset was owner-occupied and offers us unique and rare opportunity for our retailer to have a prominent presence on West 57th Street across from the future Nordstrom, which will be the first full-line Nordstrom in Manhattan. 
Finally, I like to talk about our investment Aliansce, a Brazilian mall owner. As you may recall from our first quarter earnings call, we wrote down a note receivable to approximately $70 million, which represented the market value of the underlying common shares which were collateral for the note. We also wrote off about $7.5 million of accrued interest income. During the second quarter, we've agreed to take ownership of the shares, about $18.3 million in exchange for canceling the note. As you know, GGP's focus is owning retail real estate in the United States. 
We recently entered into an agreement to sell the shares to an institutional buyer for approximately $85 million. Upon close later this quarter, we would have no remaining interest in Aliansce. In terms of how this transaction is slated for earnings, we are excluding the writedown and markup from company FFO, but including both FFO in accordance of the definition. 
Let me talk a little bit about our industry. GGP is in the retail real estate business. Historically, retail real estate has been segmented. They are more like centers, lifestyle centers, power centers and so on. Together, they equate to 24 square feet of retail per capita. Based on our research, we believe that only about 4 square feet per capita of retail GLA is high-quality. Approximately 8% of the higher-quality retail real estate in the United States is in the GGP portfolio, from which 95% of our NOI is derived. 
Ladies and gentlemen, we are in the retail real estate business. Let me talk a little bit about our leasing. We are pleased to report, we have no [indiscernible] in our portfolio. So let's start with the new inventory that's upon us. As you all know, has started as an operator. We had 9 locations, 6 large-format stores and 3 elite stores. The  3 elite stores will go back into in-line GLA until we are focused on leasing the large-format stores. 3 of them have already been released 1 to Target and the other 2 in [indiscernible]. We are progressing with the remaining operations. There is strong demand. 
I'd like to provide an update on our redevelopment plans for the the anchor boxes, which we own with Seritage. We plan to commence redevelopment of 4 locations later this year. At Pembrook's Lake, we are being in a movie theater, AMC. At Mall, we are bringing in container store. And in no time, our at Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico, we have several in-line retailers, restaurants and a container store. And in Valley Park Plaza, we have in-line tenants that are signed and restaurants. When active negotiations in additional 5, so we are making very good progress on 9 of the 12 locations. Our properties are in demand by users like grocery, big box sporting-goods, theaters, restaurants and other entertainment venues. These types of tenants further create them all. We are located in the mall with an opportunity for them to reach a large big area and generate new customers and traffic already at the shopping center. 
We have 460 full-service restaurants comprised of 3.6 million square feet in our portfolio. It's a 7% of our deal GLA and 13% of our sales. Just in the last 5 years, we have done 292 full-service restaurant deals for 2.1 million square feet. Further, 13% of our total GLA is big box, comprised of 195 big box tenants, 55 of those deals were made in the last 5 years. Those 55 deals are comprised of 12 Dave & Buster's, 4 Nordstrom racks, 9 theaters, 9 altars, 14 big sporting-goods and 7 supermarkets including the [indiscernible] opened in the former JCPenney Boston. 
At 200 Lafayette in SoHo, New York City, held its grand opening in May. Burrs offers a unique when looking for kitchen and bath fixtures and I encourage you to visit their flagship store. We acquired the asset in 2014 for about $115 million. We leased office space and the office portion for approximately $125 million last year. With the retail portion now stabilized, we are generating yield in the mid- to high-teens. 
At 730 Fifth Avenue, the Crown Building, we're pleased to welcome the venue. We continue to see inputs of retailers coming to the mall and demand from other retail concepts. For example, [indiscernible] recently opened its pioneer place in Portland and new concepts like Country Club Prep, [indiscernible] ELF Cosmetics and just to name a few either the open stores are will be opening stores soon in our portfolio. 
I like to update you on PacSun and Aeropostale. We have 71 PacSun locations in our portfolio. Off those 71, 6 will be vacating at the end of the year, 65 stores will be we expect PacSun to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of September. Regarding Aeropostale, it is our expectation that the sales process will happen in the month of August. We believe Aeropostale will remain a viable entity going forward, although its footprint may be smaller than it is today. 
As a final note, we have been talking a lot about improving the customer experience at the mall. Parking lots at our malls are at capacity. Our customers tell us that parking is a common [indiscernible] within the shopping experience. We are very excited that the recent introduction of our new parking app at Oakwood Center, Alderwood Mall Galleria is up and operating. For those of you who live near those centers, we encourage you to try the new app and send us your feedback. We plan a broader rollout across the portfolio later this year. Michael will now take you through our results for the quarter and outlook for the remainder of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. I will start out with some brief comments on second quarter results, followed by details in the asset transactions, the impact on our full-year guidance. Finally, I will provide an update on our balance shee
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. I will start out with some brief comments on second quarter results, followed by details in the asset transactions, the impact on our full-year guidance. Finally, I will provide an update on our balance sheet activities before we open it up to questions. 
Before I begin, I want point an error on Page 16 of the supplement. The occupancy cost ratios for the same-store retail properties should be 13.9% for the June 2016 quarter and 13.2% for the June 2015 quarter. We apologize for the error. 
Moving on to the second quarter. Same-store permanent revenues were up 4.3% compared to the prior year and as we noted, same-store NOI came in at $555 million, up 4% from last year. SG&A for the quarter was a minus $43 million compared to minus $40 million in the prior year. The year-over-year change was due to some one-time financing fees that we received last year. The current quarter net G&A came in consistent with our expectation. 
EBITDA came in at $534 million and overall, company FFO came in at a strong $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance. As noted in the press release, we closed on 2 asset sales during the quarter, 3 more asset sales subsequent to quarter end. These transactions total net proceeds of approximately $1 billion. While we're using approximately $300 million of the proceeds to pay down mortgage debt, we noted both of those transactions in the press release, these 3 loans represent over half of our 2017 maturities and we're also paying off $90 million debt outstanding. 
At this point, we are retaining the remaining proceeds of approximately $600 million. Keep in mind, there are taxable gains associated with the asset sales and depending on where our taxable income comes in at year-end, we currently expect to use approximately $250 million of the proceeds to pay out a special dividend of approximately $0.25 per share subject to board approval. The timing, as we think of it now, will be around the same as our regular fourth quarter dividend. 
I want to go through the FFO dilution, the impact on '16 and then the impact on an annualized basis. For 2016, we lose about $20 million in FFO through the asset sales. Based on paying down the debt, we get back $7 million in interest saving and we generate about a $1 million joint venture fee for the remainder of the year on the Fashion Show transaction. 
There's also one-time expense for cost to prepay assumed mortgages of $5.5 million that will impact the third quarter. The total impact for the year is $0.02 per share for 2016. On an annualized basis, looking forward, we lose approximately $52 million of FFO in asset sales. We get back around $14 million in NOI interest expense savings from the debt paydown and we will generate around full year $3 million fee on newly formed Fashion Show joint venture, the full impact is approximately 3.5 per share. 
Our full-year guidance is now $1.51 to $1.55. The previous midpoint was $1.54. We're adjusting our guidance up $0.01 due to a positive operations. We then adjust for the $0.02 of dilution from the asset sales and our midpoint becomes $1.53. I do want to make note that the Fashion Show transaction will impact the full-year 2016 same-store NOI growth by about 20 to 25 basis points, taking on midpoint to around 4.25. 
Our Outlook for the second of our operations with the use of the strong. We have some tougher comps due to some one-time items in termination income and recovery in the prior year that may not repeat. Our same-store NOI growth outlook for the second half is therefore midpoint of 4%. 
Moving down to EBITDA. Our full-year outlook continues to be 8% to 9%. At the midpoint of our guidance, we now expect company FFO of around $1.465 billion and  a share count of about $960 million. I thought idd lay out a little bit of the third quarter and the fourth you tell folks out in terms of what we're thinking. Guidance for third quarter is $325 million to $345 million of FFO or $0.34 to $0.36 per share. There was are on $6 million of net dilution from the asset sales in the one-time prepayment penalty I noted in the third quarter for over $11 million impacting the third quarter. 
In the fourth quarter, we expect FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44, which includes $8 million of net dilution from the transactions noted in the press release. 
Moving on to the balance sheet for some perspective. Our total debt at the beginning of the year was almost $20 billion and our net debt to EBITDA in 2015 was around 9x. Given the transactions that have occurred this year and the planned debt paydown, we expect to be around $18.5 billion in total debt at the end of the year, a reduction of almost $1.5 billion. Based on our current plan, we expect in the year with about $700 million to $800 million of cash, excluding the $250 million special dividend cash. That will get us to 2016 end of year net debt to EBITDA just shy of 8x and we expect to be in the mid-7s by the end of 2017, assuming no other transactions. 
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that piece is actually going to accelerate depending on the department store
componenttext: We feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that piece is actually going to accelerate depending on the department store acquisitions that we can put it to make. And a few -- just rewind back to my comment and I made an empathic point about being in the retail real estate business and expand on that a little bit. And what I was trying to say was effectively previously we used to give away these department stores at $1.5 to [indiscernible] portfolio to do have the ability to add on retailers that traditionally don't go into the malls but have gone into power centers. And today, we're able to attract those retailers into the department store boxes in an accretive fashion and are truly becoming very competitive to our power center brethren. And we're able to do deals in a highly competitive with all the in a very low basis in your end and the retailers are finding it attractive to come to the larger malls because the exact consumers from an 8 to 10-mile radius in the shopping center business were attracting people from 1.5 to 2 mile radius. So my point being that all of a sudden, we've gotten this new canvas in this canvas allows us to sort of layout our painting in an accretive fashion. And so I think that the pipeline could enhance itself through as low as we continue to be able to have the opportunity to buy back department store box. If it arises, if it doesn't arise, we still feel that we can retrieve $500 million with the pipeline we have from now until 2019. And so we are happy either way. We're happy if the department stores start to perform incredibly well and do not sell their assets of pipeline for the next few year and should they decide to lower their footprint selectively in the quality of assets we have, we think it's accretive for us.

componenttext: No, what we said are a couple of things, one is tourist markets does have ups and downs the Fashion Show Mall's probably one of the 10 best malls in the nation, a fantastic asset. componenttext: I think the demand is incredibly strong, okay, whether you look at demand from regular players, whether it be the jewelers, the Pandoras, the cause of the world whether you see from entertainment users test the continue to expand in the business. The list is incredibly dominant event is incredibly good from players. And so in a funny way to you, look, I'm not big into segmentation because it's an unfair way to look at the real estate because you've got 40 yard space, 30 yard and 10 yard space and so it's inappropriate to look at the space in my opinion based upon just the top and the bottom third because you could have the same bottom and the top third in the same mall depending if you're in the 10 yard line or the 50-yard line. So more so, really look at it almost 40 assets that are visually about $800 a foot that accounts for 46% of our NOI. So when you look at our portfolio, we have a lot of breadth and scale. And so -- and I'm always maintained that spreads would be 8% to 10% and one day I'll be right, it will be up to 10%.  So far I've been wrong, wrong and wrong. But one day I'll be right. And when retail sales go up 3% to 4% a year or a 5-year period, they're going up 15% to 20%, then you've got 2% to 3% annual growth rate, which we will have in our leases and at some stage your spreads are going to be 8% to 10%. And that business will give you a 3% growth rate of a business and redevelopments will give you 100 basis points and so you're at 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company. And that's what we said we are and that's the business. And I think we feel pretty comfortable between our redevelopment, development, spreads, annual increases. We're going to be a 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company.

componenttext:
Thank you, Tyron. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Second Quarter 2016 Earnings Call, hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Safe Harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, August 2, 2016. Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the release and supplementals filed in Form 8-K with the SEC, and also available on our website.
It's my pleasure to now turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone. Our latest sustainability report is available on our website. For the past several years, we have been identifying and executing on ways to improve our impact on the environment. I want to mention a few highlights
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin. Good morning, everyone. Our latest sustainability report is available on our website. For the past several years, we have been identifying and executing on ways to improve our impact on the environment. I want to mention a few highlights from the report. We have diverted 54,000 tons of waste from landfills, which is enough to fill all 4,500 garbage trucks. Water consumption has been reduced by 64 million gallons, which is enough water to fill almost 100 Olympic-sized swimming pools. We have completed lighting and HVAC upgrades, which will save the equivalent energy of taking 4,600 homes of the electric grid, and we expect to be one of the largest generators of solar energy in the U.S. this year. We continue to explore new opportunities to implement sustainable operating factors throughout our portfolio. 
Now let's return to our recent results. FFO per share was $0.35, up almost 7% from the same quarter last year. Year-to-date FFO per share was $0.75, up over 15% from last year. EBITDA was up 6.5% from the same quarter last year, and over 13% year-to-date from last year. Same-store NOI growth was up 4% for the quarter and 4.6% year-to-date. Results were driven primarily by continued strength from our high-quality portfolio in terms of occupancy gains and expense management. We increased the quarterly dividend to $0.20, 11% increase over last year. 
The portfolio was over 96% leased at quarter end, and permanent occupancy stood at about 91.5% as we expected -- which is what we expected at this time of the year. Total sales, excluding department stores and Christiana Mall, were up about 3%, and sales for tenants under 10,000 feet were flat, excluding Christiana Mall. Categories that performed best were restaurants, home furnishings and health and personal care. We even had a positive comp in apparel. This is for total sales x department stores. Lease spreads for leases commencing in the trailing 12 months are about 13% or a little over $8 per square foot. To calculate our lease spreads, we include base tenant count and compare them to the ending rent on the expiring lease to the beginning rent on the new lease on a suite-to-suite basis, regardless of size. 
Turning to property contract. In June, we sold our interest in 1 Stockton in San Francisco for approximately $50 million, which values the asset at a subsea cat on a trailing 12-month basis. This is the highest price paid for an asset per square foot in Union Square, almost $5,800 per square foot. You may recall, we acquired this asset in 2014, one of our initial investments in urban retail with a plan to re-lease this space since the existing tenant was relocating to the Square. We successfully released the space to T-Mobile, stabilizing the asset, and then sold our interest. On an IR basis, we realized about 40%. 
In June, we sold Pioneer Place office buildings, a class A asset, for approximately $122 million, which values the asset at a 5% cap. In July, we sold Newgate Mall, located in Ogden, Utah, for approximately $17 million, which values the asset at a high single-digit cap rate. Yesterday, we closed on the sale of Road Valley Mall located in Medford, Oregon, for over $60 million, which values the asset at a high-single-digit cap rate.
We're pleased to announce a new joint venture with TIAA Global Asset Management at Fashion Show in Las Vegas. GGP and TIAA are partners at other properties and we look forward to our new partnership with them. As you know, Fashion Show is a one-of-a-kind asset. Over the past several years, the GGP team has successfully re-tenanted several anchor boxes, bringing in Macy's Men, Urban Outfitters, and Dick's Sporting Goods to the mall. We brought to life the Boulevard entrance, bringing a number of new dining and leisure options. TIAA will now own approximately 50% of Fashion Show. The transaction values the asset at approximately $2.5 billion, a sub-4% cap rate.
We closed on the previously announced acquisition of 218 West 57th Street in New York City. You may recall, we entered into a commitment to acquire this property located across the street from the new Nordstrom back in 2014. The asset was owner-occupied, and offers us unique and rare opportunity for a retailer to have a prominent presence on West 57th Street across from the future Nordstrom, which will be the first full-line Nordstrom in Manhattan. 
Finally, I like to talk about our investment, Aliansce, the Brazilian mall owner. As you may recall from our first quarter earnings call, we wrote down the note receivable to approximately $70 million, which represented the market value of the underlying common shares, which were collateral for the note. We also wrote off about $7.5 million of accrued interest income. During the second quarter, we agreed to take ownership of the shares, about $18.3 million in exchange for canceling the note. As you know, GGP's focus is owning retail real estate in the United States.  We recently entered into an agreement to sell the shares to an institutional buyer for approximately $85 million. Upon close later this quarter, we will have no remaining interest in Aliansce. In terms of how this transaction is treated for earnings, we are excluding the write-down and markup from company FFO, but including both in NAREIT FFO in accordance with the definition. 
Let me talk a little bit about our industry. GGP is in the retail real estate business. Historically, retail real estate has been segmented. They are malls, strip centers, lifestyle centers, power centers, and so on. Together, they equate to 24 square feet of retail GLA per capita. Based on our research, we believe that only about 4 square feet per capita of retail GLA was high-quality. Approximately 8% of the high-quality retail real estate in the United States is in the GGP portfolio, from which 95% of our NOI is derived. 
Ladies and gentlemen, we are in the retail real estate business. Let me talk a little bit about our leasing. We are pleased to report, we have no vacant anchor departments stores left, no vacant anchor boxes in our portfolio. So let's start with the new inventory that's upon us. As you all know, Sports Authority has started as an operator. We had 9 locations, 6 large-format stores and 3 elite stores. The 3 elite stores will go back into in-line GLA until we are focused on leasing the large-format stores. 3 of them have already been leased, one to Target and the other 2 in Northridge and White Marsh, Dave & Buster's. We are progressing with the remaining locations. There is strong demand. 
I'd like to provide an update on our redevelopment plans for this year's anchor boxes, which we own with Seritage. We plan to commence redevelopment of 4 locations later this year. At Pembroke's Lake, we are being in a movie theater, AMC. At Staten Island Mall, we are bringing in Container Store and a new Trimark. At Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico, we have several in-line retailers, restaurants and a Container Store, and in Valley Plaza, we have in-line tenants that are signed and restaurants. We're in active tenant negotiations on an additional 5, so we are making very good progress on 9 of the 12 locations. Our properties are in demand by users like grocery, big box sporting-goods, theaters, restaurants and other entertainment venues. These types of tenants further curate the mall, being located in the mall with an opportunity for them to reach a large trade area and generate new customers from traffic already at the shopping center. 
We have 460 full-service restaurants comprised of 3.6 million square feet in our portfolio. This is 7% of our total GLA and 13% of our sales. Just in the last 5 years, we have done 292 full-service restaurant deals for 2.1 million square feet. Further, 13% of our total GLA is big box, comprised of 195 big box tenants. Fifty five of those deals were made in the last 5 years. Those 55 deals are comprised of 12 Dave & Buster's, 4 Nordstrom Racks, 9 theaters, 9 ultras, 14 big sporting-goods and 7 supermarkets, including the Wegmans that will open in the former JCPenney space at Natick in Boston. 
At 200 Lafayette in SoHo, New York City, PIRCH held its grand opening in May. PIRCH offers a unique experience when looking for kitchen and bath fixtures and I encourage you to visit their flagship store. We acquired the asset in 2014 for about $150 million. We leased the office space and sold the office portion for approximately $125 million last year. With the retail portion now stabilized, we are generating yield in the mid- to high-teens. At 730 Fifth Avenue, the Crown Building, we're pleased to welcome Zegna. We continue to see influx of retailers coming to the mall and demand from other retail concepts. For example, ModCloth recently opened its Pioneer Place in Portland, and new concepts like Country Club Prep, Peloton, Aesop, e.l.f. Cosmetics and Essentia, just to name a few, either have opened stores or will be opening stores soon in our portfolio. 
I'd like to update you on PacSun and Aropostale. We have 71 PacSun locations in our portfolio. Off those 71, 6 will be vacating at the end of the year, 65 stores would be retained. We expect PacSun to emerge from bankruptcy by the end of September. Regarding Aropostale, it is our expectation that the sales process will happen in the month of August. We believe Aropostale will remain a viable entity going forward, although its footprint may be smaller than it is today. 
As a final note, we have been talking a lot about improving the customer experience at the mall. Parking lots at our malls are at capacity. Our customers tell us that parking is a common paying point within the shopping experience. We are very excited that the recent introduction of our new parking app at Oakbrook Center, Ridgedale Center, Alderwood Mall and Stonestown Galleria is up and operating. For those of you who live near those centers, we encourage you to try the new app and send us your feedback. We plan a broader rollout across the portfolio later this year. Michael will now take you through our results for the quarter and outlook for the remainder of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. I will start out with some brief comments on second quarter results, followed by details in the asset transactions, the impact on our full-year guidance. Finally, I will provide an update on our balance shee
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. I will start out with some brief comments on second quarter results, followed by details in the asset transactions, the impact on our full-year guidance. Finally, I will provide an update on our balance sheet activities before we open it up to questions. Before I begin, I want point an error on Page 16 of the supplement. The occupancy cost ratios for the same-store retail properties should be 13.9% for the June 2016 quarter, and 13.2% for the June 2015 quarter. We apologize for the error. 
Moving on to the second quarter. Same-store permanent revenues were up 4.3% compared to the prior year, and as we noted, same-store NOI came in at $555 million, up 4% from last year. Net G&A for the quarter was a minus $43 million compared to minus $40 million in the prior year. The year-over-year change was due to some one-time financing fees that we received last year. The current quarter net G&A came in consistent with our expectation. 
EBITDA came in at $534 million, and overall, company FFO came in at a strong $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance. As noted in the press release, we closed on 2 asset sales during the quarter, 3 more asset sales subsequent to quarter end, these transactions total net proceeds of approximately $1 billion. We're using approximately $300 million of the proceeds to pay down mortgage debt. We noted both of those transactions in the press release. These 2 loans represent over half of our 2017 maturities, and we're also paying off $90 million outstanding [indiscernible].
At this point, we are retaining the remaining proceeds of approximately $600 million. Keep in mind, there are taxable gains associated with the asset sales, and depending on where our taxable income comes in at year-end, we currently expect to use approximately $250 million of the proceeds to pay out a special dividend of approximately $0.25 per share, subject to board approval. The timing, as we think of it now, would be around the same as our regular fourth quarter dividend. I want to go through the FFO dilution, the impact on '16, and then the impact on an annualized basis. For 2016, we lose about $20 million in FFO from the asset sales. Based on paying down the debt, we get back $7 million in interest savings, and we generate about a $1 million joint venture fee for the remainder of the year on the Fashion Show transaction. 
There's also one-time expense for cost to prepay its assumed mortgages of $5.5 million that will impact the third quarter. The total impact for the year is $0.02 per share for 2016. On an annualized basis, looking forward, we lose approximately $52 million of FFO from the asset sales. We get back around $14 million in NOI interest expense savings from the debt paydown, and we will generate around full year $3 million fee on the newly formed Fashion Show joint venture. The full impact is approximately 3.5 per share. Our full-year guidance is now $1.51 to $1.55. The previous midpoint was $1.54. We're adjusting our guidance up $0.01 due to a positive view on operations. We then adjust for the $0.02 of dilution from the asset sales and our midpoint becomes $1.53. I do want to make note that the Fashion Show transaction will impact the full-year 2016 same-store NOI growth by about 20 to 25 basis points, taking our midpoint to around 4.25. Our outlook for second half floor operations continues to be strong. We have some tougher comps due to some one-time items in termination income and recovery in the prior year that may not repeat. Our same-store NOI growth outlook for the second half is therefore midpoint of 4%. 
Moving down to EBITDA. Our full-year outlook continues to be 8% to 9%. At the midpoint of our guidance, we now expect company FFO of around $1.465 billion and a share count of about $960 million. I thought I'd lay out a little bit for the third quarter and the fourth to help folks out in terms of what we're thinking. Guidance for the third quarter is $325 million to $345 million of FFO or $0.34 to $0.36 per share. There was around $6 million of net dilution from the asset sales, and the one-time prepayment penalty I noted in the third quarter for over $11 million impacting the third quarter. In the fourth quarter, we expect FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44, which includes $8 million of net dilution from the transactions noted in the press release. 
Moving on to the balance sheet for some perspective. Our total debt at the beginning of the year was almost $20 billion and our net debt to EBITDA in 2015 was around 9x. Given the transactions that have occurred this year and the planned debt paydown, we expect to be around $18.5 billion in total debt at the end of the year, a reduction of almost $1.5 billion. Based on our current plan, we expect to end the year with about $700 million to $800 million of cash, excluding the $250 million special dividend cash. That would get us to a 2016 end of year net debt to EBITDA just shy of 8x, and we expect to be in the mid-7s by the end of 2017, assuming no other transactions. 
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: Well, I mean, the e-retailers are focused on the best assets. As we understand, 60% of all venture capital money being raised today is focused on opening bricks and mortar stores. They are signing traditional 5-year leases for the most part, and they're paying market rent, and so it all boils down from this point on what market trends are in the market more than occupancy cost of sales production.

componenttext: I think the economics of that asset can only get stronger as 2019 approaches and Nordstrom's open. Nordstrom is going to be the first full line new department store in New York in I don't know how long, maybe 100 years. I mean, they're really a long period of time. They're building a tremendous flagship. It's just across the street from it. I actually think the market value has gone up already from the time we bought it, new and vacant. I think there'll be minor investment in it, call it, $20-ish million. And on the contrary for this asset, one has to be very patient and not rush to lease it, and that's why we haven't rushed so far because you want to wait closer to 2019. It's part of our inventory to hold. We might temp lease it, but we are not going to permanently lease it, and we'll try to open it at the same time Nordstrom's open. That was always the intent. That was our business plan.

componenttext: Our view is we're sitting with, as Michael said, $700 million to $800 million of cash post the dividend, and so we -- and our development pipeline is fully funded. headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a very broad question. So I mean, and we've given this to you asset by asset in the past. If my memory reads me right because we've sold a few assets, and on a net basis, I think the NOI growth is from $27 million to $75 million stabilized. A
componenttext: I think it's a very broad question. So I mean, and we've given this to you asset by asset in the past. If my memory reads me right because we've sold a few assets, and on a net basis, I think the NOI growth is from $27 million to $75 million stabilized. And I think, at the end of the day, we will -- that includes the Crown Building, includes 1 Union Square, 830 North Michigan, 200 Lafayette, 685 Fifth and 530 Fifth. I think it is. So I think that's the total 6 assets. We like the business. The business is performing. We're signing new leases at/or above our pro forma rent. We are -- we harvested a couple of assets, and took the profit on them, but -- and we may or may not sell one more of those assets this year. But barring that, we are going to continue to be in the street retail business, and continue to have firepower to opportunistically acquire in the future.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, and second question on just Seritage. Are the assets that you're redeveloping, is it still in the original scope of about 50% of the space? And curious as to -- I think some of your peers have mentioned that they might be taking a pause, given that
componenttext: Okay, and second question on just Seritage. Are the assets that you're redeveloping, is it still in the original scope of about 50% of the space? And curious as to -- I think some of your peers have mentioned that they might be taking a pause, given that maybe you don't have to start working on 50% of the space if 100% comes back to you. So just curious to know what is driving you to start the redevelopment projects maybe a little bit ahead of your peers?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The same comment as my peers. So when we relocated, we're designing it in a way that should -- we should, for some reason, the asset come back, we will be in a position to re-lease the remaining assets accretive-ly. So my view in life a little bit is that
componenttext: The same comment as my peers. So when we relocated, we're designing it in a way that should -- we should, for some reason, the asset come back, we will be in a position to re-lease the remaining assets accretive-ly. So my view in life a little bit is that let's start knocking these things off. We have 60-plus Sears locations beyond that. Hopefully, there'll be an opportunity to acquire some more once they're done leasing these 12. Should we get back the remaining half at sometime in the future. As I mentioned, it will be designed in a way that it will be usable space on an accretive basis.

componenttext: And can you comment on the yields at all?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just some quick questions here. On the debt side, so you guys are paying off about half of your '17, so it leaves another $300 million or so in '17, and then in '18, there's only $520 million. Mike, it sounds like you're going to have plenty of cash on ha
componenttext: Just some quick questions here. On the debt side, so you guys are paying off about half of your '17, so it leaves another $300 million or so in '17, and then in '18, there's only $520 million. Mike, it sounds like you're going to have plenty of cash on hand after the special dividend at the end of the year. So can you guys just talk about, one, how much debt in the next 2 years, can we think about being paid off in absolute sense; and then 2, if were to think about a percent of the assets being unencumbered, how big could the unencumbered pool of assets be?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- how big are the unencumbered pool of assets be? I don't know, it's not -- never going down the path of the unsecured bonds now, which is your favorite strategy.
componenttext: We're -- how big are the unencumbered pool of assets be? I don't know, it's not -- never going down the path of the unsecured bonds now, which is your favorite strategy.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that, Mike. But it still -- it sounds like you're going to have some pool of...
componenttext: I know that, Mike. But it still -- it sounds like you're going to have some pool of...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to have a lot of capacity and we're going to have $700 million or plus of cash. We have over $1 billion of line.  The net debt-to-EBITDA next year gets into the 7.5% range. Whether we pay further debts down or not is something that we need to
componenttext: We're going to have a lot of capacity and we're going to have $700 million or plus of cash. We have over $1 billion of line.  The net debt-to-EBITDA next year gets into the 7.5% range. Whether we pay further debts down or not is something that we need to discuss internally. I think we're very comfortable where we are right now. We've got strong coverage ratios, we unencumbered some assets. We will have a lot coming -- due in the next couple of year. So I guess I would say that, kind of where our heads at now. Sandeep, if you want to add something?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Alex, I think it's good to have firepower, it's good have liquidity and it's good to be able to be opportunistic. I think GGP has come a long way from 5 years ago where we were -- didn't have the ability to be opportunistic, and didn't have the ability
componenttext: So Alex, I think it's good to have firepower, it's good have liquidity and it's good to be able to be opportunistic. I think GGP has come a long way from 5 years ago where we were -- didn't have the ability to be opportunistic, and didn't have the ability to have a liquidity and a flexibility. And we don't -- we were okay with the sort of negative arbitrage, if you will, of holding cash in our balance sheet for a period of time to determine what the best action is. You know you can't grow in this world by continuously selling assets and becoming smaller. At times you need to have the opportunity to grow by growth. And so, as I was quoting Warren Buffet correctly, you grow by growth, not by selling assets. And so I think we like the position of having the flexibility, we like the position of having that amount of cash in our balance sheet and we'll evaluate what to do with the cash as time moves on.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You know, that's fine. Just this year and next, obviously, very small compared to the other years, so, it seemed like an opportunity relative to your cash position that you described at year-end.
componenttext: Okay. You know, that's fine. Just this year and next, obviously, very small compared to the other years, so, it seemed like an opportunity relative to your cash position that you described at year-end.

componenttext: And the other aspect, Alex, is obviously, if the market dries up, we have the cash to pay off the debt.

componenttext: Right, perfect. So separate question. So is the Aliansce impact a neutral event when you do the write down or writeup? Or what's happening in there as such that maybe the FFO for the year doesn't change?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Alex, as you know, since we've been doing this, we focused on the company FFO. We're providing the NAREIT FFO for everybody's benefit. We'll go back and look and have a sidebar answer your question. I don't know that stuff off of the top of my head. I think about it as the company FFO and the Aliansce transaction really was not in there.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Haendel St. Juste of Mizuho.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the B mall sales environment. I know that the B malls that you're selling tend to have a simple mortgage debt attached, which makes them easier to sell. But was hoping you could give some color on the environment, the pricing demand, what ty
componenttext: A question on the B mall sales environment. I know that the B malls that you're selling tend to have a simple mortgage debt attached, which makes them easier to sell. But was hoping you could give some color on the environment, the pricing demand, what type of buyers are showing up, how many are showing up, what's your perceived pricing power is?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, again, both the assets we sold had assumable debt, which made them viable. I think there is demand for those assets on a yield basis. We don't think that base has widened on the B mall, but I do think you'll see more than 2 buyers showing up at
componenttext: You know, again, both the assets we sold had assumable debt, which made them viable. I think there is demand for those assets on a yield basis. We don't think that base has widened on the B mall, but I do think you'll see more than 2 buyers showing up at the dance floor every time we take an asset out to the market.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: And the latest sales per square foot figures, can you share -- I thought that maybe in the [indiscernible] '11 sales were just around $400 million, room value when you bought back in '03, sales were about $290 million. Can you share what that was?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Just curious for a market color. Just on the back half of the year, the expectations. Some of your peers are sounding a bit more conservative, given still uncertain store closure environment. And as you pointed out, Michael, in your comments, you
componenttext: Got you. Just curious for a market color. Just on the back half of the year, the expectations. Some of your peers are sounding a bit more conservative, given still uncertain store closure environment. And as you pointed out, Michael, in your comments, you come up on tough comps. Second half NOI last year averaged about 6%. Your leased rates are already in the 95%, 96% level. What you see in there that gives you confidence that you can achieve a similar 4%, 4.5% number at the back half of the year than you did in the first half? Is there something that we're not seeing, maybe better lease term fees? And then, as part of that, was the [indiscernible] Sports Authority vacancies part of your previously contemplated guidance?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first half was 4.6%, and as I mentioned, you've got to adjust the whole year down for Fashion Show, so that would've made it really 4.3% or 3% in change. The second half is 4%, so the total is about a 4 1/4%, which is the change. The second half, I th
componenttext: The first half was 4.6%, and as I mentioned, you've got to adjust the whole year down for Fashion Show, so that would've made it really 4.3% or 3% in change. The second half is 4%, so the total is about a 4 1/4%, which is the change. The second half, I think we feel, given what's happened with PacSun and Aeropostale, we've kind of framed our risk and we feel comfortable saying that we don't see, unless something new arises, much change and much risk embedded in our plan. We do a nice job on the expenses, which is obviously a big portion. So, you know -- and sometimes it's just the way the quarters roll. You know, one quarter to the next. It is flowing slightly in the second half versus the first, but it's de minimis. So I don't -- there was no real big, "Light went on. Boy this is what's happening." We were really just progressing along in our view on to the second half of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean you have to appreciate most of the leasing activity for 2016 is complete, to answer your question. The Sports Authority, they were part of the reserve that we held -- the $20 million reserve that we spoke about early in the year. So effectively, th
componenttext: I mean you have to appreciate most of the leasing activity for 2016 is complete, to answer your question. The Sports Authority, they were part of the reserve that we held -- the $20 million reserve that we spoke about early in the year. So effectively, the Sports Authority bankruptcy, it came out of that reserve. So as Michael said, unless something happens on the Aeropostale front, we feel pretty comfortable actually taking up guidance by a penny from operations through the end of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from Craig Schmidt of Bank of America.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In looking at the redevelopments, following the expansion of Staten Island Mall, are the future projects going to be smaller in scale and involve a number of different malls? And now will you be able to maintain the pace of redevelopment going forward in
componenttext: In looking at the redevelopments, following the expansion of Staten Island Mall, are the future projects going to be smaller in scale and involve a number of different malls? And now will you be able to maintain the pace of redevelopment going forward in the next couple of years?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Craig, we feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that pace could actually get accelerated, depending on the de
componenttext: You know Craig, we feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that pace could actually get accelerated, depending on the department store acquisitions that we can continue to make. And a few -- just rewind back to my comment, and I made an empathic point about being in the retail real estate business, and let me expand on that a little bit. And what I was trying to say in the call was, effectively, previously, we used to give away these department stores at say $1.5 to $2 a foot in our portfolio, and we didn't have the ability to add on retailers that traditionally don't go into the malls but have gone into the strip centers and power centers. And today, we are able to attract those retailers into the department store boxes in an accretive fashion, and are truly becoming very competitive to our strip center and power center brethren. And we're able to do deals in a highly competitive with -- so we are starting with all the introduction place and a very low basis in your end, and the retailers are finding it attractive to come to the larger malls because we attract consumers from an 8- to 10-mile radius whereby if you're in the strip shopping center business, we are attracting people from 1.5- to 2-mile radius. So my point being that all of a sudden, we've gotten this new canvas in this canvas allows us to sort of layout our painting in an accretive fashion. And so I think that the pipeline could enhance itself with the quality of real estate we have as long as we continue to be able to have the opportunity to buy back department store box, if it arises. If it doesn't arise, we still feel that we can retrieve $500 million with the pipeline we have from now until 2019. And so we are happy either way. We're happy if the department stores starts to perform incredibly well and do not sell their assets, it still gives us enough pipeline for the next few years, and should they decide to lower their footprint selectively in the quality of assets we have, we think that's accretive for us.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great, and then just, when I look at the $267 million of other projects in the pipeline, does that include some of the Seritage projects?
componenttext: Great, and then just, when I look at the $267 million of other projects in the pipeline, does that include some of the Seritage projects?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, you led off with a discussion of sustainability efforts at the company. I was wondering beyond being a social good, I was wondering if you could quantify the expense savings or what's the benefit as a shareholder?
componenttext: Sandeep, you led off with a discussion of sustainability efforts at the company. I was wondering beyond being a social good, I was wondering if you could quantify the expense savings or what's the benefit as a shareholder?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we believe in conscious capitalism, okay, which is doing good for the environment by making a good return. And the investments that we've made in sustainability have actually yielded to us double-digit returns.
componenttext: So obviously, we believe in conscious capitalism, okay, which is doing good for the environment by making a good return. And the investments that we've made in sustainability have actually yielded to us double-digit returns.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And in terms of the Fashion Show Mall, I was wondering if you could provide an update on the foreign luxury shopper? Did that -- did the strong dollar or the foreign luxury shopper figure into your desire to perhaps reduce exposure to that th
componenttext: Okay, great. And in terms of the Fashion Show Mall, I was wondering if you could provide an update on the foreign luxury shopper? Did that -- did the strong dollar or the foreign luxury shopper figure into your desire to perhaps reduce exposure to that third segment?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we've been -- what we've said, a couple of things. One is, it's a tourist market, it has -- it does have ups and downs. And look, Fashion Show Mall is probably one of the 10 best malls in the nation, so it's a fantastic asset. We've seen the asset eve
componenttext: No, we've been -- what we've said, a couple of things. One is, it's a tourist market, it has -- it does have ups and downs. And look, Fashion Show Mall is probably one of the 10 best malls in the nation, so it's a fantastic asset. We've seen the asset even today being at about $1,000 per square foot asset. We just felt it was a $2.5 billion asset. It was a large percentage of GGP, and it was appropriate to be able to derisk from it by selling half of the asset. We think our partners will do very well and the asset will continue to perform because good things happen to the good asset. I might point out that, from a sales productivity basis, Hawaii has completely stabilized. It's gone a little bit to the positive, and so is Vegas. So both those markets, being tourist markets, which were down substantially, almost 10%, have actually backend and started to pick back up. And so we're actually pleased to see that the strong yen is coming into play again, and Hawaii is back, picking up on sales productivity.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.
componenttext: Our next question is from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, could you maybe talk a little bit about the leasing environment and your ability to push rents? And maybe talk about sort of the bifurcation between the top third and the bottom third, and where do you see the upside in your portfolio in order to
componenttext: Sandeep, could you maybe talk a little bit about the leasing environment and your ability to push rents? And maybe talk about sort of the bifurcation between the top third and the bottom third, and where do you see the upside in your portfolio in order to push rents or to re-tenant?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think the demand is incredibly strong, okay, whether you look at demand from regular players on whether they be the jewelers, the Alex and Ani's, the Pandoras, the Kendra Scotts of the world. Whether you see them from entertainment users or the [i
componenttext: Look, I think the demand is incredibly strong, okay, whether you look at demand from regular players on whether they be the jewelers, the Alex and Ani's, the Pandoras, the Kendra Scotts of the world. Whether you see them from entertainment users or the [indiscernible] Dave & Buster's or Crayola, the list is incredibly long of tenets that -- Tesla, looking to continue to expand in the business. The list is incredibly long and demand is incredibly good from players. And so you know, in a funny way to you, look at, I'm not big into segmentation because it's an unfair way to look at the real estate because you've got 40 yard space, 50 yard and 10 yard space, and so it's inappropriate to look at space in my opinion based upon just the top and the bottom third because you could have the same bottom and the top third in the same mall depending on whether you're on the 10-yard line or in the 50-yard line. So more so, the way we look at it is, we have almost 40 assets that average over $800 a foot. That accounts for 46% of our NOI. So when you look at our portfolio, we have a lot of breadth and scale. And so -- and I'm always maintaining that spreads will be 8% to 10%, and one day I'll be right, it will be 8% to 10%.  So far I've been wrong, wrong and wrong. But one day I'll be right. And when retail sales go up 3% to 4% a year, you know, over a 5-year period, they're going up 15% to 20%, and you've got 2% to 3% annual growth rate, which is what we have in our leases, at some stage your spreads are going to be 8% to 10%. And that business will give you a 3% growth rate of a business, and redevelopments give you 100 basis points and so you're a 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company. And that's what we've said we are and that's the business. And I think we feel pretty comfortable between our redevelopment, development, spreads, annual increases. We're going to be a 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe in terms of the redevelopments, you say you're going to -- you're looking to increase the redevelopment pipeline by $300 million to $500 million a year. Do you have a number of big redevelopments that you're thinking about? Or are you thi
componenttext: Great. And maybe in terms of the redevelopments, you say you're going to -- you're looking to increase the redevelopment pipeline by $300 million to $500 million a year. Do you have a number of big redevelopments that you're thinking about? Or are you thinking more in terms of $20 million to $30 million in assets?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, there could be a couple of big developments. There could be a couple that we're looking at, 1 on the East Coast, 1 on the West Coast, which could be substantial. But I think excluding those 2, the rest would be $30 million to $50 million redevelop
componenttext: Floris, there could be a couple of big developments. There could be a couple that we're looking at, 1 on the East Coast, 1 on the West Coast, which could be substantial. But I think excluding those 2, the rest would be $30 million to $50 million redevelopments.  I might add, those 2 are both in $800 plus more.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from DJ Bush of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question is from DJ Bush of Green Street Advisors.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, you've touched on it a little bit in response to Craig's question earlier, but you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you got some demand coming from grocery, big-box, theaters, sporting goods. Tenants really that have traditionally been in
componenttext: Sandeep, you've touched on it a little bit in response to Craig's question earlier, but you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you got some demand coming from grocery, big-box, theaters, sporting goods. Tenants really that have traditionally been in strip centers. How big is the opportunity, and is it even bigger than the demand you may get from e-tailers who bring some of these tenants that have -- tend to be on the strip centers across the street?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the demand is very deep and very big and multiples off e-tailer demand. Multiples. I mean please appreciate that square footage is multiple -- [indiscernible] multiple. I think if you appreciate, when you look at a supermarket retailer going into
componenttext: I think the demand is very deep and very big and multiples off e-tailer demand. Multiples. I mean please appreciate that square footage is multiple -- [indiscernible] multiple. I think if you appreciate, when you look at a supermarket retailer going into on $800 mall, they're building these massive food halls, which would be a modern-day foodcourt, which could do $15 million to $20 million in sales for eating within the mall and, of course, over and above, for take-home. That business is not available in the traditional shopping center. And I think as these supermarkets find that they need to attract more millennials, which are people who would either come and eat in this food hall environment, or are big into take-home, and that business is a higher-margin business for the supermarket businesses selling toilet paper and bounty, they're going to -- their demand for space is going to increase. More so, if you appreciate, they also want to modernize their desk facilities and it'll be easier if they modernize their facilities and increase, the tail area is moving to a new location. So I actually believe that demand's going to be quite astronomical.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, what about off-price retail? Is the demand there as well?
componenttext: Okay. And then, what about off-price retail? Is the demand there as well?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I would say the answer to that is also yes, because if you actually look at the amount of off-price retailers within the mall space, it's a fragment, and if the off-price retailers truly need to satisfy their expansion goals, which they've said on
componenttext: Again, I would say the answer to that is also yes, because if you actually look at the amount of off-price retailers within the mall space, it's a fragment, and if the off-price retailers truly need to satisfy their expansion goals, which they've said on their calls, the only place to find that real estate will be in the mall business. And we actually see that today. We've actually put some, whether it be Nordstrom Rack's or TJ Maxx's or Orioles in our malls, and they don't impact in any way negatively or positively, but definitely not negatively to the inline space, which is always a concern. There's been no negative impact. If anything, there would be more positive impact than negative impact.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you've done a couple developments outside of the A Mall space. I'm thinking, in particular, in Lynnhaven, in Southwest Plaza trying to put money to work, in turn, maybe what you call a B mall back into an A mall that's in the great trade ar
componenttext: Okay. And then you've done a couple developments outside of the A Mall space. I'm thinking, in particular, in Lynnhaven, in Southwest Plaza trying to put money to work, in turn, maybe what you call a B mall back into an A mall that's in the great trade area. Can you give us an update on those 2 assets? And then, are there any other opportunities like at the Southwest Plaza in the portfolio?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Lynnhaven has been, I think, a real success story. Sales were like in the $300, when we started there. We're over $500 a foot now, and so that's been leased to the Apples and the [indiscernible] of the world and I think LLDs and -- so I think it's been
componenttext: So Lynnhaven has been, I think, a real success story. Sales were like in the $300, when we started there. We're over $500 a foot now, and so that's been leased to the Apples and the [indiscernible] of the world and I think LLDs and -- so I think it's been a real success story. Southwest Plaza just opened last fall. So far it's exceeding our operating fundamentalists. I think it costs $400 a square foot in sales, but I think it's still early for that. But it takes 24 to 36 -- I don't want to, to then say that it's been a success yet. But the early indications are it's moving in the right direction. Do we see additional opportunities within our portfolio of those assets? Our focus has been up to this point, over the next 2 to 3 years, to the top 50 malls in our portfolio. I don't see us making that kind of investment in any of the other B, B+ assets in our portfolio at this moment in time.

componenttext: And then, just in terms of -- I think we all can appreciate the uplift in the accretiveness that you get. From a rent perspective as you change some of these department store boxes to junior anchors and more experience-oriented retail, and being able to grab from the strips and the power centers and bring them to the mall environment. I'm curious as you think about the rents though on the specialty space, how do you think those will play off of each other when you have such high rents for the in-line space, and granted you have very low department store anchor rents today in the legacy of the business, but how do you think that dynamic starts to shift as you start to bring in people in the team where people are in the $50, $60, $70, $80 in the inline space, and how does that dynamic evolve?

componenttext: Because [indiscernible] the inline space is 3,000 to 5,000, 8,000, 10,000 square feet space. This is 50,000, 60,000, 80,000 square feet space. So I don't think there's any correlationship. They're going to department store boxes, okay, that will say make it up $1.5 a foot. All of you know what base will it be if other retailers pay in strip, power center business. So you have a pretty good idea what we can collect, okay? And they're just completely different. On the contrary, if they are truly accretive and it drives traffic, okay, you could actually see inline retailers have an uplift versus a downtrend, okay? So I see this could be a complete win-win across the board.
