headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just some quick questions here. On the debt side, so you guys are paying off about half of your '17, so it leaves another $300 million or so in '17, and then in '18, there's only $520 million. Mike, it sounds like you're going to have plenty of cash on ha
componenttext: Just some quick questions here. On the debt side, so you guys are paying off about half of your '17, so it leaves another $300 million or so in '17, and then in '18, there's only $520 million. Mike, it sounds like you're going to have plenty of cash on hand after the special dividend at the end of the year. So can you guys just talk about, one, how much debt in the next 2 years, can we think about being paid off in an absolute sense; and then 2, if were to think about a percent of the assets being unencumbered, how big could the unencumbered pool of assets be?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're -- how big are the unencumbered pool of assets be? I don't know, it's not -- never going down the path of the unsecured bonds now, which is your favorite strategy.
componenttext: We're -- how big are the unencumbered pool of assets be? I don't know, it's not -- never going down the path of the unsecured bonds now, which is your favorite strategy.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I know that, Mike. But it still -- it sounds like you're going to have some pool of...
componenttext: I know that, Mike. But it still -- it sounds like you're going to have some pool of...

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're going to have a lot of capacity and we're going to have $700 million or plus of cash. We have over $1 billion of line.  The net debt-to-EBITDA next year gets into the 7.5% range. Whether we pay further debts down or not is something that we need to
componenttext: We're going to have a lot of capacity and we're going to have $700 million or plus of cash. We have over $1 billion of line.  The net debt-to-EBITDA next year gets into the 7.5% range. Whether we pay further debts down or not is something that we need to discuss internally. I think we're very comfortable where we are right now. We've got strong coverage ratios, we've unencumbered some assets. We don't have a lot coming due in the next couple of year. So I guess I would say that, kind of where our heads at now. Sandeep, if you want to add something?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Alex, I think it's good to have firepower, it's good have liquidity and it's good to be able to be opportunistic. I think GGP has come a long way from 5 years ago where we were -- didn't have the ability to be opportunistic, and didn't have the ability
componenttext: So Alex, I think it's good to have firepower, it's good have liquidity and it's good to be able to be opportunistic. I think GGP has come a long way from 5 years ago where we were -- didn't have the ability to be opportunistic, and didn't have the ability to have the liquidity and the flexibility. And we don't -- we were okay with the sort of negative arbitrage, if you will, of holding cash in our balance sheet for a period of time to determine what the best action is. You know you can't grow in this world by continuously selling assets and becoming smaller. At times you need to have the opportunity to grow by growth. And so, as I was quoting Warren Buffet correctly, you grow by growth, not by selling assets. And so I think we like the position of having the flexibility, we like the position of having that amount of cash in our balance sheet and we'll evaluate what to do with the cash as time moves on.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. You know, that's fine. Just this year and next, obviously, very small compared to the outer years, so, it seemed like an opportunity relative to your cash position that you described at year-end.
componenttext: Okay. You know, that's fine. Just this year and next, obviously, very small compared to the outer years, so, it seemed like an opportunity relative to your cash position that you described at year-end.

componenttext: Right, perfect. So separate question. componenttext: Alex, as you know, since we've been doing this, we focused on the company FFO. We're providing the NAREIT FFO for everybody's benefit. We'll go back and look and have a sidebar answer your question. I don't know that stuff off of the top of my head. I think about it as the company FFO and the Aliansce transaction really was not in there.

componenttext: A question on the B mall sales environment. I know that the B malls that you're selling tend to have assumable mortgage debt attached, which makes them easier to sell. But was hoping you could give some color on the environment, the pricing demand, what type of buyers are showing up, how many are showing up, what's your perceived pricing power is?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know, again, both the assets we sold had assumable debt, which made them viable. I think there is demand for those assets on a yield basis. The bid/ask rate has widened on the B mall, but I do think you'll see more than 2 buyers showing up at the danc
componenttext: You know, again, both the assets we sold had assumable debt, which made them viable. I think there is demand for those assets on a yield basis. The bid/ask rate has widened on the B mall, but I do think you'll see more than 2 buyers showing up at the dance floor every time we take an asset out to the market.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. Just curious for a market color. Just on the back half of the year, the expectations. Some of your peers are sounded a bit more conservative, given still uncertain store closure environment. And as you pointed out, Michael, in your comments, you
componenttext: Got you. Just curious for a market color. Just on the back half of the year, the expectations. Some of your peers are sounded a bit more conservative, given still uncertain store closure environment. And as you pointed out, Michael, in your comments, you come up on tough comps. Second half NOI last year averaged about 6%. Your leased rates are already in the 95%, 96% level. What are you seeing that gives you confidence that you can achieve a similar 4%, 4.5% number the back half of the year than you did in the first half? Is there something that we're not seeing, maybe better lease term fees? And then, as part of that, was the 9 Sports Authority vacancies part of your previously contemplated guidance?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: The first half was 4.6%, and as I mentioned, you've got to adjust the whole year down for Fashion Show, so that would've made it really 4.3%, 4.3% and change. The second half is 4%, so the total is about a 4 1/4%, which is the change. The second half, I t
componenttext: The first half was 4.6%, and as I mentioned, you've got to adjust the whole year down for Fashion Show, so that would've made it really 4.3%, 4.3% and change. The second half is 4%, so the total is about a 4 1/4%, which is the change. The second half, I think we feel, given what's happened with PacSun and Aeropostale, we've kind of framed our risk and we feel comfortable saying that we don't see, unless something new arises, much change and much risk embedded in our plan. We do a nice job on the expenses, which is obviously a big portion. So, you know -- and sometimes it's just the way the quarters roll. You know, one quarter to the next. It is slowing slightly in the second half versus the first, but it's de minimis. So I don't -- there was no real big, "Light went on. Boy this is what's happening." We were really just progressing along in our view on to the second half of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean you have to appreciate most of the leasing activity for 2016 is complete, to answer your question. The Sports Authority, they were part of the reserve that we held -- the $20 million reserve that we spoke about early in the year. So effectively, th
componenttext: I mean you have to appreciate most of the leasing activity for 2016 is complete, to answer your question. The Sports Authority, they were part of the reserve that we held -- the $20 million reserve that we spoke about early in the year. So effectively, the Sports Authority bankruptcy, it came out of that reserve. So as Michael said, unless something happens on the Aeropostale front, we feel pretty comfortable actually taking up guidance by a penny from operations through the end of the year.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: In looking at the redevelopments, following the expansion of Staten Island Mall, are the future projects going to be smaller in scale and involve a number of different malls? And now will you be able to maintain the pace of redevelopment going forward in
componenttext: In looking at the redevelopments, following the expansion of Staten Island Mall, are the future projects going to be smaller in scale and involve a number of different malls? And now will you be able to maintain the pace of redevelopment going forward in the next couple of years?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: You know Craig, we feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that pace could actually get accelerated, depending on the de
componenttext: You know Craig, we feel pretty comfortable that we've got about $1 billion pipeline. We feel pretty comfortable to do, as I've mentioned in the past, $300 million to $500 million a year. Again, that pace could actually get accelerated, depending on the department store acquisitions that we can continue to make. And if you just rewind back to my comment, and I made an empathic point about being in the retail real estate business, and let me expand on that a little bit. And what I was trying to say before was, effectively, previously, we used to give away these department stores at say $1.5 to $2 a foot in our portfolio, and we didn't have the ability to add on retailers that traditionally don't go into the malls but have gone into the strip centers and power centers. And today, we are able to attract those retailers into the department store boxes in an accretive fashion, and are truly becoming very competitive to our strip center and power center brethren. And we're able to do deals in a highly competitive with -- so we are starting with all the infrastructure in place and a very low basis in your end, and the retailers are finding it attractive to come to the larger malls because we attract consumers from an 8- to 10-mile radius whereby if you're in the strip shopping center business, we are attracting people from 1.5- to 2-mile radius. So my point being that all of a sudden, we've gotten this new canvas and this canvas allows us to sort of layout our painting in an accretive fashion. And so I think that the pipeline could enhance itself with the quality of real estate we have as long as we continue to be able to have the opportunity to buy back department store boxes, if it arises. If it doesn't arise, we still feel that we can to $300 million to $500 million with the pipeline we have from now until 2019. And so we are happy either way. We're happy if the department stores start to perform incredibly well and do not sell their assets, it still gives us enough pipeline for the next few years, and should they decide to lower their footprint selectively in the quality of assets we have, we think that's accretive for us.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, you led off with a discussion of sustainability efforts at the company. I was wondering beyond being a social good, I was wondering if you could quantify the expense savings or what's the benefit as a shareholder?
componenttext: Sandeep, you led off with a discussion of sustainability efforts at the company. I was wondering beyond being a social good, I was wondering if you could quantify the expense savings or what's the benefit as a shareholder?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So obviously, we believe in conscious capitalism, okay, which is doing good for the environment by making a good return. And the investments that we've made in sustainability have actually yielded to us double-digit returns.
componenttext: So obviously, we believe in conscious capitalism, okay, which is doing good for the environment by making a good return. And the investments that we've made in sustainability have actually yielded to us double-digit returns.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And in terms of the Fashion Show Mall, I was wondering if you could provide an update on the foreign luxury shopper? Did that -- did the strong dollar or the foreign luxury shopper figure into your desire to perhaps reduce exposure to that th
componenttext: Okay, great. And in terms of the Fashion Show Mall, I was wondering if you could provide an update on the foreign luxury shopper? Did that -- did the strong dollar or the foreign luxury shopper figure into your desire to perhaps reduce exposure to that third segment?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we've been -- what we've said, a couple of things. One is, it's a tourist market, it has -- it does have ups and downs. And look, Fashion Show Mall is probably one of the 10 best malls in the nation, so it's a fantastic asset. We've seen the asset eve
componenttext: No, we've been -- what we've said, a couple of things. One is, it's a tourist market, it has -- it does have ups and downs. And look, Fashion Show Mall is probably one of the 10 best malls in the nation, so it's a fantastic asset. We've seen the asset even today being at about $1,000 per square foot asset. We just felt it was a $2.5 billion asset. It was a large percentage of GGP, and it was appropriate to be able to derisk from it by selling half of the asset. We think our partners will do very well and the asset will continue to perform because good things happen to the good assets. I might point out that, from a sales productivity basis, Hawaii has completely stabilized. It's actually gone a little bit to the positive, and so has Vegas. So both those markets, being tourist markets, which were down substantially, almost 10%, have actually flattened and started to pick back up. And so we're actually pleased to see that the strong yen is coming into play again, and Hawaii is back, picking up on sales productivity.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.
componenttext: Our next question is from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, could you maybe talk a little bit about the leasing environment and your ability to push rents? And maybe talk about sort of the bifurcation between the top third and the bottom third, and where do you see the upside in your portfolio in order to
componenttext: Sandeep, could you maybe talk a little bit about the leasing environment and your ability to push rents? And maybe talk about sort of the bifurcation between the top third and the bottom third, and where do you see the upside in your portfolio in order to push rents or to re-tenant?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I think the demand is incredibly strong, okay, whether you look at demand from regular players on whether they be the jewelers, the Alex and Ani's, the Pandoras, the Kendra Scotts of the world. Whether you see them from entertainment users whether i
componenttext: Look, I think the demand is incredibly strong, okay, whether you look at demand from regular players on whether they be the jewelers, the Alex and Ani's, the Pandoras, the Kendra Scotts of the world. Whether you see them from entertainment users whether it be Dave & Buster's or Crayola, the list is incredibly long of tenets that -- Tesla, looking to continue to expand in the business. The list is incredibly long and demand is incredibly good from players. And so you know, in a funny way to you, look at, I'm not big into segmentation because it's an unfair way to look at the real estate because you've got 40 yard space, 50 yard space and 10 yard space, and so it's inappropriate to look at space in my opinion based upon just the top and the bottom third because you could have the same bottom and the top third in the same mall depending on whether you're on the 10-yard line or in the 50-yard line. So more so, the way we look at it is, is we have almost 40 assets that average over $800 a foot. That accounts for 46% of our NOI. So when you look at our portfolio, we have a lot of breadth and scale. And so -- and I've always maintaining that spreads will be 8% to 10%, and one day I'll be right, it will be 8% to 10%.  So far I've been wrong, wrong and wrong. But one day I'll be right. And when retail sales go up 3% to 4% a year, you know, over a 5-year period, they're going up 15% to 20%, and you've got 2% to 3% annual growth rate, which is what we have in our leases, at some stage your spreads are going to be 8% to 10%. And that business will give you a 3% growth rate of a business, and redevelopments give you 100 basis points and so you're a 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company. And that's what we've said we are and that's the business. And I think we feel pretty comfortable between our redevelopment, development, spreads, annual increases. We're going to be a 4% to 5% EBITDA growth company.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And maybe in terms of the redevelopments, you say you're going to -- you're looking to increase the redevelopment pipeline by $300 million to $500 million a year. Do you have a number of big redevelopments that you're thinking about? Or are you thi
componenttext: Great. And maybe in terms of the redevelopments, you say you're going to -- you're looking to increase the redevelopment pipeline by $300 million to $500 million a year. Do you have a number of big redevelopments that you're thinking about? Or are you thinking more in terms of $20 million to $30 million an asset?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, there could be a couple of big developments. There could be a couple that we're looking at, 1 on the East Coast, 1 on the West Coast, which could be substantial. But I think excluding those 2, the rest would be $30 million to $50 million redevelop
componenttext: Floris, there could be a couple of big developments. There could be a couple that we're looking at, 1 on the East Coast, 1 on the West Coast, which could be substantial. But I think excluding those 2, the rest would be $30 million to $50 million redevelopments.  I might add, those 2 are both in $800 plus more.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from DJ Bush of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question is from DJ Bush of Green Street Advisors.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, you've touched on it a little bit in response to Craig's question earlier, but you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you got some demand coming from grocery, big-box, theaters, sporting goods. Tenants really that have traditionally been in
componenttext: Sandeep, you've touched on it a little bit in response to Craig's question earlier, but you mentioned in your prepared remarks that you got some demand coming from grocery, big-box, theaters, sporting goods. Tenants really that have traditionally been in strip centers. How big is the opportunity, and is it even bigger than the demand you may get from e-tailers who bring some of these tenants that have -- tend to be on the strip centers across the street?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the demand is very deep and very big and multiples of e-tailer demand. Multiples. I mean please appreciate that square footage is multiple -- [indiscernible] multiple. I think if you appreciate, when you look at a supermarket retailer going into o
componenttext: I think the demand is very deep and very big and multiples of e-tailer demand. Multiples. I mean please appreciate that square footage is multiple -- [indiscernible] multiple. I think if you appreciate, when you look at a supermarket retailer going into on $800 mall, they're building these massive food halls, which would be a modern-day foodcourt, which could do $15 million to $20 million in sales for eating within the mall and, of course, over and above, for take-home. That business is not available in the traditional shopping center. And I think as these supermarkets find that they need to attract more millennials, which are people who would either come and eat in this food hall environment, or are big into take-home, and that business is a higher-margin business for the supermarket businesses selling toilet paper and bounty, they're going to -- their demand for space is going to increase. More so, if you appreciate, they also want to modernize their desk facilities and it'll be easiest way to modernize their facilities and increase the sale area is move into a new location. So I actually believe that demand's going to be quite astronomical.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, what about off-price retail? Is the demand there as well?
componenttext: Okay. And then, what about off-price retail? Is the demand there as well?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, I would say the answer to that is also yes, because if you actually look at the amount of off-price retailers within the mall space, it's a fragment, and if the off-price retailers truly need to satisfy their expansion goals, which they've said on
componenttext: Again, I would say the answer to that is also yes, because if you actually look at the amount of off-price retailers within the mall space, it's a fragment, and if the off-price retailers truly need to satisfy their expansion goals, which they've said on their calls, the only place to find that real estate will be in the mall business. And we actually see that today. We've actually put some, whether it be Nordstrom Rack's or TJ Maxx's or Orioles in our malls, and they don't impact in any way negatively or positively, but definitely not negatively to the inline space, which is always a concern. There's been no negative impact. If anything, there would be more positive impact.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you've done a couple developments outside of the A Mall space. I'm thinking, in particular, at Lynnhaven and Southwest Plaza trying to put money to work, in turn, maybe what you call a B mall back into an A mall that's in the great trade ar
componenttext: Okay. And then you've done a couple developments outside of the A Mall space. I'm thinking, in particular, at Lynnhaven and Southwest Plaza trying to put money to work, in turn, maybe what you call a B mall back into an A mall that's in the great trade area. Can you give us an update on those 2 assets? And then, are there any other opportunities like at the Southwest Plaza in the portfolio?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Lynnhaven has been, I think, a real success story. Sales were like in the $300, when we started there. We're over $500 a foot now, and so that's been leased to the Apples and the Michael Kohr's of the world and I think LL Bean and -- so I think it's be
componenttext: So Lynnhaven has been, I think, a real success story. Sales were like in the $300, when we started there. We're over $500 a foot now, and so that's been leased to the Apples and the Michael Kohr's of the world and I think LL Bean and -- so I think it's been a real success story. Southwest Plaza just opened last fall. So far it's exceeding our operating fundamentalists. I think it costs $400 a square foot in sales, but I think it's still early for that. But it takes 24 to 36 -- I don't want to, to then say that it's been a success yet. But the early indications are it's moving in the right direction. Do we see additional opportunities within our portfolio of those assets? Our focus has been up to this point, over the next 2 to 3 years, to the top 50 malls in our portfolio. I don't see us making that kind of investment in any of the other B, B+ assets in our portfolio at this moment in time.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a follow-up from Christine McElroy of Citi.
componenttext: We have a follow-up from Christine McElroy of Citi.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

componenttext: In your opening remark, you talked about the retail real estate, and you had said 24 square feet per capita 4 square feet that you deem to be high-quality across each of those classes, upon which GCP own the 8%. I'm curious, when you look at that 4 square feet, how much of that is malls, strips, lifestyle centers and power centers in terms of sales or [indiscernible].

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Aug 02, 2016

On the contrary, if they are truly accretive and it drives traffic, okay, you could actually see inline retailers have an uplift versus a downtrend, okay? So I see this could be a complete win-win across the board.

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the GGP Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to our host for today, Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Tonya. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Please note that certain statements made in this call may be deemed forw
componenttext:
Thank you, Tonya. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Please note that certain statements made in this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information, accurate only as of today, November 1, 2016. Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the release and supplementals filed on Form 8-K with the SEC and also available on our website.
It is my pleasure to turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at [ph] $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approx
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at [ph] $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximately 4% for the quarter and the year. EBITDA was up, slightly better than 4.5% for the quarter and [indiscernible] 10% for the year. 
We are pleased with our earnings growth this year, especially in light of our strong growth last year. Based on our financial performance to date, we are pleased to announce a $0.02 increase to our quarterly dividend. Our cash dividend this year will be $0.80, double that from where we began in 2011 albeit a much smaller portfolio base.
Our leverage on a net debt-to-EBITDA basis is under 8x. From the very beginning, we've communicated a path to lower leverage. We have no unsecured debt and are sitting on more than -- more cash than we had in the last 5 years. 
Lower leverage today has been from a meticulous efforts to sell lower quality assets that also high leverage, paying down debt and growing EBITDA. Our portfolio of high-quality retail properties throughout the country continues to deliver results above the national average. Total sales performed well across the portfolio, up 1.4%, as consumers visit our centers for their shopping, dining and entertainment needs. 
As we look at the top retailers in our portfolio, L Brand sales increased 8.7% in their stores that are less than 10,000 square feet and increased 5.5% for all their stores, which includes stores larger than 10,000 square feet. Within our portfolio, 3 of the 4 largest tenants posted similar strong sales increases.
Not all retail square feet is equal, the high-quality asset of higher sales productivity when [indiscernible] for NOI, sales per square foot in our portfolio is actually 687,000 square foot and 6 75, excluding Christiana Mall.
Quickly on the urban leasing front. At 530 Fifth Avenue, we entered into a lease with Duane Reade, a Walgreens company. At 685 Fifth, Coach will be opening its new Coach House on November 18. Our entire real estate portfolio is 97% leased at quarter end.
Turning to activity on the anchor box front. Let me begin by starting that is in the retail property business focusing on on high-quality assets. Let's take a look at total retail space in the U.S. Today, there's approximately 24 square feet of retail square footage per person. Of this, only 4 square feet is considered high-quality or about a 1.2 million [ph] square feet. GGP's portfolio today comprises of approximately 100 million square feet of high-quality retail in the U.S., or almost 8% of the total high-quality real estate in this country. There is a blurring of retail property types as retailers don't differentiate between type. They just want to be in highest quality assets.
One of the ways GGP has responded to the continued demand for space is to anchor box acquisition and redevelopment. For some perspective, the department store's square footage as a percentage of total center space in the U.S. is 46%, significantly higher than other parts of the world with only 27% in the U.K., 23% in Australia, 17% in Asia and 15% in the Middle East. 
Since 2011, we have redeveloped 9-0, 90 department store boxes investing $1.5 billion of capital at very attractive returns. The new uses have included department stores, entertainment venues, sporting-goods stores, fast-action retailers, restaurants, grocery stores, fitness centers, almost 200,000 square feet of new in-line space, which we've been leased to Apple, Nike, Lulu Lemon, Tommy Bahama, Aritzia and many others. The 91st box to be redeveloped is the original Nordstrom's box Ala Moana Center, the lowest level will go to Saks Fifth Avenue and the mall level -- and the third level will go to Target in 2-level store. As you may recall, Nordstrom relocated to the expansion of Ala Moana earlier this year, allowing us to redevelop their old anchor box, bringing in new users and offerings to the center. High-quality retail properties will continue to thrive, and we will continue to capitalize upon the opportunity to redevelop anchor boxes for alternative uses.
Let me talk a little bit about Sears. The strong demand for space leads to our anchor box acquisitions, including the 12 we have acquired with Seritage. Of the 12 Seritage locations, we've broken ground on 4, including Pembroke Lakes in Florida, where we're adding an AMC movie theater and several restaurants; Staten Island Mall in New York, where we're adding a container store into restaurants; Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico, where we're adding container store, restaurant and in-line space; and Valley Plaza in California, where we're adding a few restaurant and  fast-action retailer.
Given our leasing momentum, we have set specific dates to recapture space at the following 5 Seritage locations: Older Wood in the Seattle market; Paramus Park in Northern New Jersey; Mall of Columbia in Columba, Maryland; Natick Mall outside of Boston; and Oakwood Center in the Chicago metro area. Our journey with Seritage permits recapture of up to 50% of the space and leaving Sears to operate in the remaining space. 
I want to highlight that we are recapturing 100% of the Sears space for 2 of these 5 locations. Those are Older Wood in the Seattle market, a Class-A mall; Pamarus Park, a [indiscernible] mall in Northern New Jersey. 
Over and above these [indiscernible], late last night, we negotiated the terms for the purchase of 100% of the Sears location at the streets of [indiscernible] in the -- in North Carolina, the Research Triangle Park; and A+ center with sales north of $650 per square foot.
Let's turn a little bit to Macy's. As reported yesterday in our earnings release, we announced the acquisition of 5 stores from Macy's. When Macy's publicly announced store closures earlier this year, we proactively approached them to take advantage of the potential opportunity to buy back certain boxes where we felt there were strong tenant demand. Of the 5 locations, 1 was on the closure list. The locations are as follows: [indiscernible] Galleria, where we plan a major repositioning of the property, similar to what we did at Ala Moana; Carolina Place, where we are going to put a new Dick's Sporting Goods; Quail Springs Mall where we have main deals will lifetime fitness; greenwood mall, where we're welcoming a new health department store with a signed lease [indiscernible]; and the one on the closure list with Oakwood Mall in Wisconsin.
The new uses are subject to satisfaction of certain delivery conditions to the tenants. Macy's will continue to operate the Titan Galleria store on a short-term lease with us. The Macy's at Quail Springs closed earlier this year, and the other 3 will close in spring 2017. The attractive returns from our development pipeline will continue to enhance our earnings growth.
Let's turn to Aropostale. Let me talk briefly about Aropostale. The demand from other retailers for the Aropostale space was very strong. Authentic Brands Group, one of the best bands company in the U.S., approached us as they saw significant been equity in Aropostale. We are capitalizing on the brand value, reducing the store footprint, renegotiating leases and reducing overhead in order to stabilize the company. We have rightsized the business, taking it from 800 stores to about 500, whereby a viable retailer has been resurrected.
In terms of economics. Total investment by the 3 partners was about $55 million or about 1.5x current EBITDA on sales north of $1 billion. We view the investment as a one-off opportunity that can lead to many positive outcomes. For example, ABG is an owner of some of the most recognizable brands today like Marilyn Munro, Mohammed Aly, Elvis, [indiscernible], Spider, Prince, the record company, [indiscernible] and many others represent the potential demand for in-line space as we seek to continue to curate the brands within our centers. The ABG brands, beside Aropostale, have no stores today in the U.S., only internationally.
In closing, a few weeks ago, I had the honor of participating in the Wall Street Journal's Consumer 250 Conference in New York City. This was an event that brought representatives from leading retail companies together for an evening to talk about trends and developments in the industry. [indiscernible], Co-Founder, Robbie Parker, said he could envision a future with 800 to 1,000 physical stores. Andy Dunn, founder of [indiscernible], said he plans to have 100 stores by 2020. And he then added that he expect the wave of e-commerce companies to make similar leap. These are 2 good examples of companies starting on the Internet, finding success and realizing true scale and profitability via physical stores.
Beyond these 2 well-known retailers, there are many other incubating online, starting with a pop-up shop like Mac Plop, L's cosmetics, Monica and Andy and [indiscernible]. Find greater success and then opening more stores. 
We are optimistic with respect to our leasing activity. We have locked down approximately 50% of our overall anticipated 27 leasing activity. We are anticipating occupancy increases as our merchandising and curation ration efforts continue to take hold. We're targeting a modest occupancy scale on the overall portfolio. We are currently expect our long-term target of 4% to 5% operation growth from our assets to be achievable in 2017.
Michael, will now review our financial results.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million on the focus on increase. Growth would have been 4.4%, excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million on the focus on increase. Growth would have been 4.4%, excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in the 74% to 75% range. EBITDA came in at $528 million, an increase of 4.6% over the prior year. Growth would have been 4.5% without the [indiscernible] of the LX. Our FFO included a one-time prepayment of $5.4 million related to the $300 million debt payoffs at Mall of Louisiana and Apache Mall. Overall, as Sandeep noted, company FFO came in at $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance.
A quick note on our reported lease spreads, as there's been a lot of discussions around this metric. Our spread was suite to suite and compare opening rents to closing rents. It includes base rent for recoveries and excludes tax recoveries. Lease modifications and amendments are included in the calculation. For example, PacSun and Aropostale modifications that occurred during the quarter are included in the metric.
Spreads on 2017 commencements of $5 per square foot with initial rents of around $55 per square foot. There are several big box deals that impact the initial rent per square foot. If you take these out, the initial rent is around $72 to $73 per square foot and spreads are around $5 to $6.
With respect to the fourth quarter, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4%. We expect company FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44. For the full year, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4.25 [ph], and we expect company FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.54, which is really just $1.10 for the first 3 quarters plus the fourth quarter guidance numbers.
Moving on to the balance sheet. As a reminder, our total debt at the beginning of the year was around $20 billion. Through dispositions and debt reductions, that balance will be on the $18.5 billion at the and of the year. We expect enterprise debt to EBITDA at year-end to be less than 8x, and we are trending toward the mid-7. I want to remind you that we have no unsecured debt, and we plan on continuing to be a secured borrower.
We are done with our 2016 debt maturities and have already dealt with most of our 2017 maturities. We have around $2.6 billion of total liquidity from the line cash on the balance sheet and borrowing capacity. This provides substantial resources to take advantage of any dislocations in the market.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk at the high streets of England and London, every third corner has a boots. And doing read is owned by boots. And boots id biggest selling point is ac
componenttext: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk at the high streets of England and London, every third corner has a boots. And doing read is owned by boots. And boots id biggest selling point is actually cosmetics. And if you think about high street retail, we actually look at place places like Sephora all set performing at high numbers. So we actually view the fact that doing Reade as a Walgreens company is owned by boots to be a big advantage to set the tone on the need required on The Street. It actually exists the process Street in performing incredibly well. So we think it bodes well to sort of talk about a relocation of an existing tenant from The Street that's performing pretty well with the focus really on more on cosmetics than on pharmacy.

Wondering if you can give us some color on the changes you're seeing in terms of the number of buyers and pricing, whether for JV stakes and high-quality malls, or for B malls or Street retail in recent months? And where are at in a potential to sell another stake at Ala Moana.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We sit to the back $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated Ala Moana might next year but not at this -- not this year. Street retail demand from investors is ve
componenttext: We sit to the back $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated Ala Moana might next year but not at this -- not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very high for an acquisition as evidenced by the latest sale of the Valentino building on Fifth Avenue, which sold I believe in the high 2s to the very low 3s. The B malls, we continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically. I think the buyer pool is small, but does exists. We sold it at a pretty healthy good cap rate, not we didn't give away the store. And on the A malls, there's just tremendous demand. There's no shortage of investors who would like to buy a piece of a high quality real estate asset.

componenttext: So go back to the development. Again, it's been very steady. It's stayed 1% to 2% development input on an annual basis. We did the same thing. We bring it steadily all the way to 2020, that's why we feel confident with the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth number. The true role in our 730 Fifth Avenue really doesn't come into 2018, because they're actually delivering spaces to tenants. And by then, we collect rents on a fully analyze basis. You want to see the big gains to 2018.

componenttext: Just one last one on the transition from clicks to bricks. I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of an inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of more e-commerce retailers today going into malls? Is that like a 2017 event where you expect to see a real pickup? Or have you seen that already?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks and mortars stores. And we saw that with [indiscernible] go back a few years, which is a capital company. People tend to forget that J Crew was a catalog company, and we view
componenttext: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks and mortars stores. And we saw that with [indiscernible] go back a few years, which is a capital company. People tend to forget that J Crew was a catalog company, and we view them today as a bricks-and-mortar company but they were a catalog company. [indiscernible] was a catalog company. LST was a catalog company. These catalog companies are today integrated online, so they're all online companies, so you're going to start to see more of them open. Blue Nile opened in Roosevelt Field. I think those will continue to open more stores. So I think it's more weather incubated and until the last mile of distribution is obviously a lot less expensive and the ability to acquire tenants from a marketing perspective, a lot less expensive than opening bricks-and-mortar stores.

componenttext: Floris, it goes back to higher quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that customer wants. Actually we had a positive movement recently. [indiscernible] went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was fairly Vegas and the energy market, which dragged us down by 1% [ph] But again, that's the point of having the portfolio. You have assets of all types across the country and you benefit at times and you get rate at times and I think the higher quality assets perform better which is sort of why I prefer to the weighted NOI average of sales productivity. This is where you get the highest NOI should be given the most credit. And if you look at it from that perspective, our sales almost approached $700 [ph] a square foot.

componenttext: Maybe if I can have one more question. As I look at -- put this in perspective -- if I put in perspective, you basically bought the Macy's space. I calculated around $60 a square foot. And I'm looking at Seritage, which gets valued at around $75 a foot. Does that mean that you get call it 20% higher returns on the redevelopment of those boxes? Or is it going to be sort of your 10% to 12% return on invested capital for those  -- or for that space?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. one is not all assets are the same if you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Ala Moana, in t
componenttext: A couple of things. one is not all assets are the same if you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Ala Moana, in the case where we bought this from Sears, we paid $250 million for 11 boxes, 12 boxes, I can't even remember. But $200 million was allocated to the Ala Moana. I could have allocated all $250 million to Ala Moana, because the return turned out to be 10-plus percent. So again, not trying to give away the math here, but you should not look at all real estate to be the same and obviously the value for the [indiscernible] box is substantially higher than the other boxes. And as I mentioned, we expect the returns to be in line with what we have done previously.

componenttextpreview: It's generally from the growth in EBITDA. Don't forget, we also amortize them 200-plus million of debt a year. So we feel pretty good. I don't know whether or not to get exactly to 7.5 [ph], but it gets pretty close.
componenttext: It's generally from the growth in EBITDA. Don't forget, we also amortize them 200-plus million of debt a year. So we feel pretty good. I don't know whether or not to get exactly to 7.5 [ph], but it gets pretty close.

componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the GGP Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to our host for today, Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed
componenttext:
Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information accurate only as of today, November 1, 2016. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the release and supplementals filed on Form 8-K with the SEC and also available on our website.
It is my pleasure to turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximate
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximately 4% for the quarter and the year. EBITDA was up, slightly better than 4.5% for the quarter and over 10% for the year. 
We are pleased with our earnings growth this year, especially in light of our strong growth last year. Based on our financial performance to date, we are pleased to announce a $0.02 increase to our quarterly dividend. Our cash dividend this year will be $0.80, double that from where we began in 2011 albeit a much smaller portfolio base.
Our leverage on a net debt-to-EBITDA basis is under 8x. From the very beginning, we've communicated a path to lower leverage. We have no unsecured debt and are sitting on more than -- more cash than we have in the last 5 years. Lower leverage today has been from a meticulous effort to sell lower-quality assets that also have high leverage, paying down debt and growing EBITDA. 
Our portfolio of high-quality retail properties throughout the country continues to deliver results above the national average. Total sales performed well across the portfolio, up 1.4%, as consumers visit our centers for their shopping, dining and entertainment needs. 
As we look at the top retailers in our portfolio, L Brand sales increased 8.7% in their stores that are less than 10,000 square feet and increased 5.5% for all their stores, which include stores larger than 10,000 square feet. Within our portfolio, 3 of the 4 largest tenants posted similar strong sales increases.
Not all retail square feet is equal. The high-quality asset sees higher sales productivity. When weighted for NOI, sales per square foot in our portfolio is actually $687 a square foot and $675 excluding Christiana Mall.
Quickly, on the urban leasing front. At 530 Fifth Avenue, we entered into a lease with Duane Reade, a Walgreens company. 
At 685 Fifth, Coach will be opening its new Coach House on November 18. 
Our entire real estate portfolio is 97% leased at the quarter end.
Turning to activity on the anchor box front. Let me begin by starting that GGP is in the retail property business focusing only on high-quality assets. Let's take a look at total retail space in the U.S. Today, there is approximately 24 square feet of retail square footage per person. Of this, only 4 square feet is considered high quality or about 1.2 billion square feet. GGP's portfolio today comprises of approximately 100 million square feet of high-quality retail in the U.S., almost 8% of the total high-quality retail real estate in this country. There is a blurring of retail property types as retailers don't differentiate between type, they just want to be in highest-quality assets.
One of the ways GGP has responded to the continued demand for space is to anchor box acquisition and redevelopment. For some perspective, the department store's square footage as a percentage of total center space in the U.S. is 46%, significantly higher than other parts of the world where it's only 27% in the U.K., 23% in Australia, 17% in Asia and 15% in the Middle East. 
Since 2011, we have redeveloped 9-0, 90 department store boxes investing $1.5 billion of capital at very attractive returns. The new uses have included department stores, entertainment venues, sporting goods stores, fast-fashion retailers, restaurants, grocery stores, fitness centers, almost 200,000 square feet of new inline space, which we've leased to Apple, Nike, lululemon, Tommy Bahama, Aritzia and many others. The 91st box to be redeveloped is the original Nordstrom's box Ala Moana Center. The lowest level will go to Saks Off 5th Avenue and the mall level -- and the third level will go to Target in 2-level store. As you may recall, Nordstrom relocated to the expansion of Ala Moana earlier this year, allowing us to redevelop their old anchor box, bringing in new users and offerings to the center. 
High-quality retail properties will continue to thrive and we will continue to capitalize upon this opportunity to redevelop anchor boxes for alternative uses.
Let me talk a little bit about Sears. The strong demand for space leads to our anchor box acquisitions including the 12 we have acquired with Seritage. Of the 12 Seritage locations, we've broken ground on 4 including Pembroke Lakes in Florida where we're adding AMC movie theater and several restaurants; Staten Island Mall in New York where we're adding a Container Store and some restaurants; Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico where we're adding Container Store, restaurant and inline space; and Valley Plaza in California where we're adding a few restaurant and a fast-fashion retailer.
Given our leasing momentum, we have set specific dates to recapture space at the following 5 Seritage locations: Alderwood in the Seattle market; Paramus Park in Northern New Jersey; Mall of Columbia in Columbia, Maryland; Natick Mall outside of Boston; and Oakbrook Center in the Chicago metro area. Our JV with Seritage permits recapture of up to 50% of the space and leaving Sears to operate in the remaining space. I want to highlight that we are recapturing 100% of the Sears space for 2 of these 5 locations. Those are Alderwood in the Seattle market, a Class A mall, and Paramus Park, a B+ mall in Northern New Jersey. 
Over and above these 12, late last night, we negotiated the terms for the purchase of 100% of the Sears location at The Streets at Southpoint in the -- in North Carolina, the Research Triangle Park, an A+ center with sales north of $650 per square foot.
Let's turn a little bit to Macy's. As reported yesterday in our earnings release, we announced the acquisition of 5 stores from Macy's. When Macy's publicly announced store closures earlier this year, we proactively approached them to take advantage of the potential opportunity to buy back certain boxes where we felt there was strong tenant demand. Of the 5 locations, 1 was on the closure list. The locations are as follows: Tysons Galleria where we plan a major repositioning of the property similar to what we did at Ala Moana; Carolina Place where we are going to put a new Dick's Sporting Goods; Quail Springs Mall where we have mail deals with Life Time Fitness; Greenwood Mall where we're welcoming a new Belk department store with a signed lease with Belk; and the one on the closure list was Oakwood Mall in Wisconsin.
The new uses are subject to satisfaction of certain delivery conditions to the tenants. Macy's will continue to operate the Tysons Galleria store on a short-term lease with us. The Macy's at Quail Springs closed earlier this year and the other 3 will close in spring 2017. The attractive returns from our development pipeline will continue to enhance our earnings growth.
Let's turn to Aropostale. Let me talk briefly about Aropostale. The demand from other retailers for the Aropostale space was very strong. Authentic Brands Group, one of the best brand companies in the U.S., approached us as they saw a significant brand equity in Aropostale. We are capitalizing on the brand value, reducing the store footprint, renegotiating leases and reducing overhead in order to stabilize the company. We have rightsized the business, taking it from 800 stores to about 500 whereby a viable retailer has been resurrected.
In terms of economics. Total investment by the 3 partners is about $55 million or about 1.5x current EBITDA on sales north of $1 billion. We view the investment as a one-off opportunity that can lead to many positive outcomes. For example, ABG is an owner of some of the most recognizable brands today like Marilyn Monroe; Muhammad Ali; Elvis; Juicy Couture; Spyder; Prince, the racket company; Hickey Freeman; and many others represent the potential demand for inline space as we seek to continue to curate the brands within our centers. The ABG brands, beside Aropostale, have no stores today in the U.S., only internationally.
In closing. A few weeks ago, I had the honor of participating in The Wall Street Journal's consumer 2016 conference in New York City. This was an event that brought representatives from leading retail companies together for an evening to talk about trends and developments in the industry. Neil Blumenthal, Co-Founder of Warby Parker, said he could envision a future with 800 to 1,000 physical stores. Andy Dunn, Founder of Bonobos, said he plans to have 100 stores by 2020. Andy Dunn added that he expects a tidal wave of e-commerce companies to make similar leap. These are 2 good examples of companies started on the Internet, finding success and realizing true scale and profitability via physical stores. Beyond these 2 well-known e-tailers, there are many others incubating online and starting with a pop-up shop like Mark Klopp [ph], L. Cosmetics, Monica + Andy and Fabletics, finding greater success and then opening more stores. 
We are optimistic with respect to our leasing activity. We have locked down approximately 50% of our overall anticipated 27 leasing activity. We are anticipating occupancy increases as our merchandising and curation efforts continue to take hold. We are targeting a modest occupancy scale [ph] on the overall portfolio. We currently expect our long-term target of 4% to 5% operational growth from our assets to be achievable in 2017.
Michael, will now review our financial results.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in the 74% to 75% range. EBITDA came in at $528 million, an increase of 4.6% over the prior year. Growth would have been 4.5% without the condos and the airways [ph]. Our FFO included a one-time prepayment of $5.4 million related to the $300 million debt payoffs at Mall of Louisiana and Apache Mall. Overall, as Sandeep noted, company FFO came in at $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance.
A quick note on our reported lease spreads as there has been a lot of discussions around this metric. Our spread was suite-to-suite and compare opening rents to closing rents. It includes base rent plus CAM recoveries and excludes tax recoveries. Lease modifications and amendments are included in the calculation, for example, PacSun and Aropostale modifications that occurred during the quarter are included in the metric. Spreads on 2017 commencements of $5 per square foot with initial rents of around $55 per square foot. There are several big-box deals that impact the initial rent per square foot. If you take these out, the initial rent is around $72 to $73 per square foot and spreads are around $5 to $6.
With respect to the fourth quarter, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4%. We expect company FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44. For the full year, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4.25% and we expect company FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.54, which is really just $1.10 for the first 3 quarters plus the fourth quarter guidance numbers.
Moving on to the balance sheet. As a reminder, our total debt at the beginning of the year was around $20 billion. Through dispositions and debt reductions, that balance will be under $18.5 billion at the end of the year. We expect net debt-to-EBITDA at year-end to be less than 8x and we are trending toward the mid-7. I want to remind you that we have no unsecured debt, and we plan on continuing to be a secured borrower.
We are done with our 2016 debt maturities and have already dealt with most of our 2017 maturities. 
We have around $2.6 billion of total liquidity from the line, cash on the balance sheet and borrowing capacity. This provides substantial resources to take advantage of any dislocations in the market.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: Okay, okay. But as far as when you -- when we think about High Street retail, think more fashion brands and I think there were some view that, that part of Fifth Avenue would be set of the next step in coming. Is your view that basically, given all the glut, it's better to take a good retailer and put them in rather than trying to, let's say, help elevate a district or provide a more fashion forward? How should we read that putting in? Do we read it as a plug space? Or do we read this as this actually somehow is synergistic just because it seems a little off from some of the intention that was going on with some of the street retail expansion?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually c
componenttext: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually cosmetics. And if you think about High Street retail, we actually look at places like Sephora and all are performing at high numbers. So we actually view the fact that Duane Reade is a Walgreens company, which is owned by Boots to be a big advantage to set the tone on a need required on the street. It actually exists across the street and performs incredibly well. So we think it bodes well to sort of talk about a relocation of an existing tenant from the street who's performing pretty well with a focus really on -- more on cosmetics than on pharmacy.

componenttext: Okay. And you're in a unique position having been in the market this year with assets across the quality spectrum of your portfolio. Wondering if you could give us some color on the changes you're seeing in terms of the number of buyers and pricing, whether for JV stakes in high-quality malls or for B malls or street retail in recent months? And where are you in the potential to sell another stake in Ala Moana.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very hig
componenttext: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very high for an acquisition as evidenced by the latest sale of the Valentino building on Fifth Avenue, which sold, I believe, in the high 2s or the very low 3s. The B malls, we continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically. I think the buyer pool is small, but does exist. We've sold it at a pretty healthy good cap rate, not -- we didn't give away the store. And on the A malls, there's just tremendous demand. There's no shortage of investors who would like to buy a piece of a high quality retail real estate asset.

componenttext: So go back to the development, again it's been very steady. It's been 1% to 2% development input on an annual basis. We did the same thing. We bring it in steadily all the way to 2020, that's why we feel confident with the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth number. The true roll-in of 730 Fifth Avenue really doesn't come into 2018 because they're actually delivering spaces to tenants. And by then, we collect rents on a fully annualized basis when you see the big gains in 2018.

componenttext: It's -- again, I say we are opportunistic. We review the portfolio constantly. There is a discussion that we have with them all the time. Again, we will determine the number that we would like to take back. We continue to prune our portfolio, so it's a constant process.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back, too, 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and thes
componenttext: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back, too, 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and these 5 from Macy's. So we think, again, we're only sitting with whatever that is, 8 to 10 left to do. So obviously, the pipeline is we have capacity to take on more and we will do that in a disciplined manner.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of more e-commerce retailers today going into the malls? Is that like a 2017 event where you expect to see a real pickup? Or have you seen that already?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view the
componenttext: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view them today as a bricks-and-mortar company, but they were a catalog company. Lands' End was a catalog company. L.L. Bean was a catalog company. These catalog companies are today integrated online, so they're all online companies. So you're going to start to see more of them open. Blue Nile opened in Roosevelt Field. I think they'll continue to open more stores. So I think it's more where they're incubated and until the last mile of distribution is obviously a lot less expensive and the ability to acquire tenants from a marketing perspective is a lot less expensive than opening bricks-and-mortar stores.

How much was that impacted by the strong dollar or the weak tourism? And maybe talk a little bit more about sort of the strength of the sales environment.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the
componenttext: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the energy markets, which dragged us down by about 1%. But again, that's the point of having a portfolio. You have assets of all types across the country and you benefit at times and you get hurt at times and I think the higher-quality assets perform better, which is sort of why I prefer to the weighted NOI average of sales productivity. This is where you get the highest NOI should be given the most credit, and if you look at it from that perspective, our sales almost approached $700 a square foot.

componenttext: Riverchase, we have the option to purchase it from our partners and we will make that decision shortly. And Harborplace, we're working through some conditions with the city. Once those conditions are resolved, we will be able to continue with the marketing process because there was a lease for the garage with the city.

componenttext: Okay. Maybe if I can have one more question. As I look at -- put this in perspective -- if I put in perspective, you basically bought the Macy's space I calculate around $60 a square foot and I'm looking at Seritage, which gets valued at around $75 a foot. You're buying that space around 20% cheaper than where Seritage is valued as an asset not as a stock where sock is obviously above that. I mean, how should investors think about that? Does that mean that you get, call it, 20% higher returns on the redevelopment of those boxes? Or is it still going to be sort of your 10% to 12% return on invested capital for those  -- or for that space?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of things, Floris. One is not all assets are the same, okay. If you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Al
componenttext: Couple of things, Floris. One is not all assets are the same, okay. If you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Ala Moana, in the case when we bought this from Sears, we paid $250 million for 11 boxes -- 12 boxes, I can't even remember. But $200 million was allocated to the Ala Moana. I could have allocated all $250 million to Ala Moana because the returns turned out to be 10-plus percent. So again, not trying to give away the math here, but you should not look at all real estate to be the same and obviously the value for the Tysons box is substantially higher than the other boxes. And as I mentioned, we expect the returns to be in line with what we have done previously.

componenttext: They always are part of our business. Bankruptcy's a part of our business. We've had them in good times and bad times.
