headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the GGP Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.I would now like to turn the call over to our host for today, Kevin Berry. You may beg
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the GGP Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to our host for today, Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed
componenttext:
Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information accurate only as of today, November 1, 2016. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the release and supplementals filed on Form 8-K with the SEC and also available on our website.
It is my pleasure to turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximate
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximately 4% for the quarter and the year. EBITDA was up, slightly better than 4.5% for the quarter and over 10% for the year. 
We are pleased with our earnings growth this year, especially in light of our strong growth last year. Based on our financial performance to date, we are pleased to announce a $0.02 increase to our quarterly dividend. Our cash dividend this year will be $0.80, double that from where we began in 2011 albeit a much smaller portfolio base.
Our leverage on a net debt-to-EBITDA basis is under 8x. From the very beginning, we've communicated a path to lower leverage. We have no unsecured debt and are sitting on more than -- more cash than we have in the last 5 years. Lower leverage today has been from a meticulous effort to sell lower-quality assets that also have high leverage, paying down debt and growing EBITDA. 
Our portfolio of high-quality retail properties throughout the country continues to deliver results above the national average. Total sales performed well across the portfolio, up 1.4%, as consumers visit our centers for their shopping, dining and entertainment needs. 
As we look at the top retailers in our portfolio, L Brand sales increased 8.7% in their stores that are less than 10,000 square feet and increased 5.5% for all their stores, which include stores larger than 10,000 square feet. Within our portfolio, 3 of the 4 largest tenants posted similar strong sales increases.
Not all retail square feet is equal. The high-quality asset sees higher sales productivity. When weighted for NOI, sales per square foot in our portfolio is actually $687 a square foot and $675 excluding Christiana Mall.
Quickly, on the urban leasing front. At 530 Fifth Avenue, we entered into a lease with Duane Reade, a Walgreens company. 
At 685 Fifth, Coach will be opening its new Coach House on November 18. 
Our entire real estate portfolio is 97% leased at the quarter end.
Turning to activity on the anchor box front. Let me begin by starting that GGP is in the retail property business focusing only on high-quality assets. Let's take a look at total retail space in the U.S. Today, there is approximately 24 square feet of retail square footage per person. Of this, only 4 square feet is considered high quality or about 1.2 billion square feet. GGP's portfolio today comprises of approximately 100 million square feet of high-quality retail in the U.S., almost 8% of the total high-quality retail real estate in this country. There is a blurring of retail property types as retailers don't differentiate between type, they just want to be in highest-quality assets.
One of the ways GGP has responded to the continued demand for space is to anchor box acquisition and redevelopment. For some perspective, the department store's square footage as a percentage of total center space in the U.S. is 46%, significantly higher than other parts of the world where it's only 27% in the U.K., 23% in Australia, 17% in Asia and 15% in the Middle East. 
Since 2011, we have redeveloped 9-0, 90 department store boxes investing $1.5 billion of capital at very attractive returns. The new uses have included department stores, entertainment venues, sporting goods stores, fast-fashion retailers, restaurants, grocery stores, fitness centers, almost 200,000 square feet of new inline space, which we've leased to Apple, Nike, lululemon, Tommy Bahama, Aritzia and many others. The 91st box to be redeveloped is the original Nordstrom's box Ala Moana Center. The lowest level will go to Saks Off 5th Avenue and the mall level -- and the third level will go to Target in a 2-level store. As you may recall, Nordstrom relocated to the expansion of Ala Moana earlier this year, allowing us to redevelop their old anchor box, bringing in new users and offerings to the center. 
High-quality retail properties will continue to thrive and we will continue to capitalize upon this opportunity to redevelop anchor boxes for alternative uses.
Let me talk a little bit about Sears. The strong demand for space leads to our anchor box acquisitions including the 12 we have acquired with Seritage. Of the 12 Seritage locations, we've broken ground on 4 including Pembroke Lakes in Florida where we're adding AMC movie theater and several restaurants; Staten Island Mall in New York where we're adding a Container Store and some restaurants; Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico where we're adding Container Store, restaurant and inline space; and Valley Plaza in California where we're adding a few restaurant and a fast-fashion retailer.
Given our leasing momentum, we have set specific dates to recapture space at the following 5 Seritage locations: Alderwood in the Seattle market; Paramus Park in Northern New Jersey; Mall of Columbia in Columbia, Maryland; Natick Mall outside of Boston; and Oakbrook Center in the Chicago metro area. Our JV with Seritage permits recapture of up to 50% of the space and leaving Sears to operate in the remaining space. I want to highlight that we are recapturing 100% of the Sears space for 2 of these 5 locations. Those are Alderwood in the Seattle market, a Class A mall, and Paramus Park, a B+ mall in Northern New Jersey. 
Over and above these 12, late last night, we negotiated the terms for the purchase of 100% of the Sears location at The Streets at Southpoint in the -- in North Carolina, the Research Triangle Park, an A+ center with sales north of $650 per square foot.
Let's turn a little bit to Macy's. As reported yesterday in our earnings release, we announced the acquisition of 5 stores from Macy's. When Macy's publicly announced store closures earlier this year, we proactively approached them to take advantage of the potential opportunity to buy back certain boxes where we felt there was strong tenant demand. Of the 5 locations, 1 was on the closure list. The locations are as follows: Tysons Galleria where we plan a major repositioning of the property similar to what we did at Ala Moana; Carolina Place where we are going to put a new Dick's Sporting Goods; Quail Springs Mall where we have made a deal with Life Time Fitness; Greenwood Mall where we're welcoming a new Belk department store with a signed lease with Belk; and the one on the closure list was Oakwood Mall in Wisconsin.
The new uses are subject to satisfaction of certain delivery conditions to the tenants. Macy's will continue to operate the Tysons Galleria store on a short-term lease with us. The Macy's at Quail Springs closed earlier this year and the other 3 will close in spring 2017. The attractive returns from our development pipeline will continue to enhance our earnings growth.
Let's turn to Aropostale. Let me talk briefly about Aropostale. The demand from other retailers for the Aropostale space was very strong. Authentic Brands Group, one of the best brand companies in the U.S., approached us as they saw a significant brand equity in Aropostale. We are capitalizing on the brand value, reducing the store footprint, renegotiating leases and reducing overhead in order to stabilize the company. We have rightsized the business, taking it from 800 stores to about 500 whereby a viable retailer has been resurrected.
In terms of economics. Total investment by the 3 partners is about $55 million or about 1.5x current EBITDA on sales north of $1 billion. We view the investment as a one-off opportunity that can lead to many positive outcomes. For example, ABG is an owner of some of the most recognizable brands today like Marilyn Monroe; Muhammad Ali; Elvis; Juicy Couture; Spyder; Prince, the racket company; Hickey Freeman; and many others, represent the potential demand for inline space as we seek to continue to curate the brands within our centers. The ABG brands, beside Aropostale, have no stores today in the U.S., only internationally.
In closing. A few weeks ago, I had the honor of participating in The Wall Street Journal's consumer 2016 conference in New York City. This was an event that brought representatives from leading retail companies together for an evening to talk about trends and developments in the industry. Neil Blumenthal, Co-Founder of Warby Parker, said he could envision a future with 800 to 1,000 physical stores. Andy Dunn, Founder of Bonobos, said he plans to have 100 stores by 2020. Andy Dunn added that he expects a tidal wave of e-commerce companies to make similar leap. These are 2 good examples of companies started on the Internet, finding success and realizing true scale and profitability via physical stores. Beyond these 2 well-known e-tailers, there are many others incubating online and starting with a pop-up shop like Mark Klopp [ph], L. Cosmetics, Monica + Andy and Fabletics, finding greater success and then opening more stores. 
We are optimistic with respect to our leasing activity. We have locked down approximately 50% of our overall anticipated 27 leasing activity. We are anticipating occupancy increases as our merchandising and curation efforts continue to take hold. We are targeting a modest occupancy gain on the overall portfolio. We currently expect our long-term target of 4% to 5% operational growth from our assets to be achievable in 2017.
Michael, will now review our financial results.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in the 74% to 75% range. EBITDA came in at $528 million, an increase of 4.6% over the prior year. Growth would have been 4.5% without the condos and the airways [ph]. Our FFO included a one-time prepayment of $5.4 million related to the $300 million debt payoffs at Mall of Louisiana and Apache Mall. Overall, as Sandeep noted, company FFO came in at $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance.
A quick note on our reported lease spreads as there has been a lot of discussions around this metric. Our spread was suite-to-suite and compare opening rents to closing rents. It includes base rent plus CAM recoveries and excludes tax recoveries. Lease modifications and amendments are included in the calculation, for example, PacSun and Aropostale modifications that occurred during the quarter are included in the metric. Spreads on 2017 commencements of $5 per square foot with initial rents of around $55 per square foot. There are several big-box deals that impact the initial rent per square foot. If you take these out, the initial rent is around $72 to $73 per square foot and spreads are around $5 to $6.
With respect to the fourth quarter, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4%. We expect company FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44. For the full year, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4.25% and we expect company FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.54, which is really just $1.10 for the first 3 quarters plus the fourth quarter guidance numbers.
Moving on to the balance sheet. As a reminder, our total debt at the beginning of the year was around $20 billion. Through dispositions and debt reductions, that balance will be under $18.5 billion at the end of the year. We expect net debt-to-EBITDA at year-end to be less than 8x and we are trending toward the mid-7. I want to remind you that we have no unsecured debt, and we plan on continuing to be a secured borrower.
We are done with our 2016 debt maturities and have already dealt with most of our 2017 maturities. 
We have around $2.6 billion of total liquidity from the line, cash on the balance sheet and borrowing capacity. This provides substantial resources to take advantage of any dislocations in the market.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttext: Okay, okay. But as far as when you -- when we think about High Street retail, think more fashion brands and I think there were some view that, that part of Fifth Avenue would be set of the next step in coming. Is your view that basically, given all the glut, it's better to take a good retailer and put them in rather than trying to, let's say, help elevate a district or provide a more fashion forward? headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually c
componenttext: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually cosmetics. And if you think about High Street retail, we actually look at places like Sephora and all are performing at high numbers. So we actually view the fact that Duane Reade is a Walgreens company, which is owned by Boots to be a big advantage to set the tone on a need required on the street. It actually exists across the street and performs incredibly well. So we think it bodes well to sort of talk about a relocation of an existing tenant from the street who's performing pretty well with a focus really on -- more on cosmetics than on pharmacy.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very hig
componenttext: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very high for an acquisition as evidenced by the latest sale of the Valentino building on Fifth Avenue, which sold, I believe, in the high 2s or the very low 3s. The B malls, we continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically. I think the buyer pool is small, but does exist. We've sold it at a pretty healthy good cap rate, not -- we didn't give away the store. And on the A malls, there's just tremendous demand. There's no shortage of investors who would like to buy a piece of a high quality retail real estate asset.

componenttext: So go back to the development, again it's been very steady. It's been 1% to 2% development input on an annual basis. We did the same thing. This year is about 1%, 1.5% and will be the same next year. And we've had that plan since 2012, no different. We bring it in steadily all the way to 2020, that's why we feel pretty confident with the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth number. The true roll-in of 730 Fifth Avenue really doesn't come into 2018 because they're actually delivering spaces to tenants. And by then, we collect rents on a fully annualized basis when you see the big gains in 2018.

componenttextpreview: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back to 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and these 5
componenttext: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back to 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and these 5 from Macy's. So we think, again, we're only sitting with whatever that is, 8 to 10 left to do. So obviously, the pipeline is we have capacity to take on more and we will do that in a disciplined manner.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of more e-commerce to retailers today going into the malls? Is that like a 2017 event where you expect to see a real pickup? Or have you seen that already?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view the
componenttext: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view them today as a bricks-and-mortar company, but they were a catalog company. Lands' End was a catalog company. L.L. Bean was a catalog company. These catalog companies are today integrated online, so they're all online companies. So you're going to start to see more of them open. Blue Nile opened in Roosevelt Field. I think they'll continue to open more stores. So I think it's more where they're incubated and until the last mile of distribution is obviously a lot less expensive and the ability to acquire tenants from a marketing perspective is a lot less expensive than opening bricks-and-mortar stores.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on your sales number. Clearly, the market has been very concerned about negative sales growth and obviously you had a positive print this quarter. How much was that impacted by the strong dollar or the weak tourism? And maybe talk a little
componenttext: Quick question on your sales number. Clearly, the market has been very concerned about negative sales growth and obviously you had a positive print this quarter. How much was that impacted by the strong dollar or the weak tourism? And maybe talk a little bit more about sort of the strength of the sales environment.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the
componenttext: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the energy markets, which sort of dragged us down by about 1%. But again, that's the point of having a portfolio. You have assets of all types across the country and you benefit at times and you get hurt at times and I think the higher-quality assets perform better, which is sort of why I prefer to the weighted NOI average of sales productivity. This is where you get the highest NOI should be given the most credit, and if you look at it from that perspective, our sales almost approached $700 a square foot.

componenttext: Riverchase, we have the option to purchase it from our partners and we will make that decision shortly. And Harborplace, we're working through some conditions with the city. componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the GGP Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the call over to our host for today, Kevin Berry. You may begin.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed
componenttext:
Thank you, Sonia. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to General Growth Properties Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Call hosted by Sandeep Mathrani, our CEO; and Michael Berman, our CFO.
Please note that certain statements made during this call may be deemed forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Actual results may differ materially due to a variety of risks, uncertainties and other factors. Please reference our earnings press release and SEC filings for a detailed discussion.
Statements made during this call may include time-sensitive information accurate only as of today, November 1, 2016. 
Reconciliations of non-GAAP financial measures to the most directly comparable GAAP measures are included in the release and supplementals filed on Form 8-K with the SEC and also available on our website.
It is my pleasure to turn the call over to Sandeep.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximate
componenttext:
Thank you, Kevin, and good morning, everyone. Let me begin by highlighting the quarter. FFO per share came in at $0.35 and within our guidance range. For the year, we're at $1.10 per share, about 9% higher than last year. Same-store NOI was up approximately 4% for the quarter and the year. EBITDA was up, slightly better than 4.5% for the quarter and over 10% for the year. 
We are pleased with our earnings growth this year, especially in light of our strong growth last year. Based on our financial performance to date, we are pleased to announce a $0.02 increase to our quarterly dividend. Our cash dividend this year will be $0.80, double that from where we began in 2011 albeit a much smaller portfolio base.
Our leverage on a net debt-to-EBITDA basis is under 8x. From the very beginning, we've communicated a path to lower leverage. We have no unsecured debt and are sitting on more than -- more cash than we have in the last 5 years. Lower leverage today has been from a meticulous effort to sell lower-quality assets that also have high leverage, paying down debt and growing EBITDA. 
Our portfolio of high-quality retail properties throughout the country continues to deliver results above the national average. Total sales performed well across the portfolio, up 1.4%, as consumers visit our centers for their shopping, dining and entertainment needs. 
As we look at the top retailers in our portfolio, L Brand sales increased 8.7% in their stores that are less than 10,000 square feet and increased 5.5% for all their stores, which include stores larger than 10,000 square feet. Within our portfolio, 3 of the 4 largest tenants posted similar strong sales increases.
Not all retail square feet is equal. The high-quality asset sees higher sales productivity. When weighted for NOI, sales per square foot in our portfolio is actually $687 a square foot and $675 excluding Christiana Mall.
Quickly, on the urban leasing front. At 530 Fifth Avenue, we entered into a lease with Duane Reade, a Walgreens company. 
At 685 Fifth, Coach will be opening its new Coach House on November 18. 
Our entire real estate portfolio is 97% leased at the quarter end.
Turning to activity on the anchor box front. Let me begin by starting that GGP is in the retail property business focusing only on high-quality assets. Let's take a look at total retail space in the U.S. Today, there is approximately 24 square feet of retail square footage per person. Of this, only 4 square feet is considered high quality or about 1.2 billion square feet. GGP's portfolio today comprises of approximately 100 million square feet of high-quality retail in the U.S., almost 8% of the total high-quality retail real estate in this country. There is a blurring of retail property types as retailers don't differentiate between type, they just want to be in highest-quality assets.
One of the ways GGP has responded to the continued demand for space is to anchor box acquisition and redevelopment. For some perspective, the department store's square footage as a percentage of total center space in the U.S. is 46%, significantly higher than other parts of the world where it's only 27% in the U.K., 23% in Australia, 17% in Asia and 15% in the Middle East. 
Since 2011, we have redeveloped 9-0, 90 department store boxes investing $1.5 billion of capital at very attractive returns. The new uses have included department stores, entertainment venues, sporting goods stores, fast-fashion retailers, restaurants, grocery stores, fitness centers, almost 200,000 square feet of new inline space, which we've leased to Apple, Nike, lululemon, Tommy Bahama, Aritzia and many others. The 91st box to be redeveloped is the original Nordstrom's box Ala Moana Center. The lowest level will go to Saks Off 5th Avenue and the mall level -- and the third level will go to Target in a 2-level store. As you may recall, Nordstrom relocated to the expansion of Ala Moana earlier this year, allowing us to redevelop their old anchor box, bringing in new users and offerings to the center. 
High-quality retail properties will continue to thrive and we will continue to capitalize upon this opportunity to redevelop anchor boxes for alternative uses.
Let me talk a little bit about Sears. The strong demand for space leads to our anchor box acquisitions including the 12 we have acquired with Seritage. Of the 12 Seritage locations, we've broken ground on 4 including Pembroke Lakes in Florida where we're adding AMC movie theater and several restaurants; Staten Island Mall in New York where we're adding a Container Store and some restaurants; Coronado Center in Albuquerque, New Mexico where we're adding Container Store, restaurant and inline space; and Valley Plaza in California where we're adding a few restaurant and a fast-fashion retailer.
Given our leasing momentum, we have set specific dates to recapture space at the following 5 Seritage locations: Alderwood in the Seattle market; Paramus Park in Northern New Jersey; Mall of Columbia in Columbia, Maryland; Natick Mall outside of Boston; and Oakbrook Center in the Chicago metro area. Our JV with Seritage permits recapture of up to 50% of the space and leaving Sears to operate in the remaining space. I want to highlight that we are recapturing 100% of the Sears space for 2 of these 5 locations. Those are Alderwood in the Seattle market, a Class A mall, and Paramus Park, a B+ mall in Northern New Jersey. 
Over and above these 12, late last night, we negotiated the terms for the purchase of 100% of the Sears location at The Streets at Southpoint in the -- in North Carolina, the Research Triangle Park, an A+ center with sales north of $650 per square foot.
Let's turn a little bit to Macy's. As reported yesterday in our earnings release, we announced the acquisition of 5 stores from Macy's. When Macy's publicly announced store closures earlier this year, we proactively approached them to take advantage of the potential opportunity to buy back certain boxes where we felt there was strong tenant demand. Of the 5 locations, 1 was on the closure list. The locations are as follows: Tysons Galleria where we plan a major repositioning of the property similar to what we did at Ala Moana; Carolina Place where we are going to put a new Dick's Sporting Goods; Quail Springs Mall where we have made a deal with Life Time Fitness; Greenwood Mall where we're welcoming a new Belk department store with a signed lease with Belk; and the one on the closure list was Oakwood Mall in Wisconsin.
The new uses are subject to satisfaction of certain delivery conditions to the tenants. Macy's will continue to operate the Tysons Galleria store on a short-term lease with us. The Macy's at Quail Springs closed earlier this year and the other 3 will close in spring 2017. The attractive returns from our development pipeline will continue to enhance our earnings growth.
Let's turn to Aropostale. Let me talk briefly about Aropostale. The demand from other retailers for the Aropostale space was very strong. Authentic Brands Group, one of the best brand companies in the U.S., approached us as they saw a significant brand equity in Aropostale. We are capitalizing on the brand value, reducing the store footprint, renegotiating leases and reducing overhead in order to stabilize the company. We have rightsized the business, taking it from 800 stores to about 500 whereby a viable retailer has been resurrected.
In terms of economics. Total investment by the 3 partners is about $55 million or about 1.5x current EBITDA on sales north of $1 billion. We view the investment as a one-off opportunity that can lead to many positive outcomes. For example, ABG is an owner of some of the most recognizable brands today like Marilyn Monroe; Muhammad Ali; Elvis; Juicy Couture; Spyder; Prince, the racket company; Hickey Freeman; and many others, represent the potential demand for inline space as we seek to continue to curate the brands within our centers. The ABG brands, beside Aropostale, have no stores today in the U.S., only internationally.
In closing. A few weeks ago, I had the honor of participating in The Wall Street Journal's consumer 2016 conference in New York City. This was an event that brought representatives from leading retail companies together for an evening to talk about trends and developments in the industry. Neil Blumenthal, Co-Founder of Warby Parker, said he could envision a future with 800 to 1,000 physical stores. Andy Dunn, Founder of Bonobos, said he plans to have 100 stores by 2020. Andy Dunn added that he expects a tidal wave of e-commerce companies to make similar leap. These are 2 good examples of companies started on the Internet, finding success and realizing true scale and profitability via physical stores. Beyond these 2 well-known e-tailers, there are many others incubating online and starting with a pop-up shop like Mark Klopp [ph], L. Cosmetics, Monica + Andy and Fabletics, finding greater success and then opening more stores. 
We are optimistic with respect to our leasing activity. We have locked down approximately 50% of our overall anticipated 27 leasing activity. We are anticipating occupancy increases as our merchandising and curation efforts continue to take hold. We are targeting a modest occupancy gain on the overall portfolio. We currently expect our long-term target of 4% to 5% operational growth from our assets to be achievable in 2017.
Michael, will now review our financial results.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in
componenttext:
Thank you, Sandeep, and good morning, everyone. Overall, the third quarter came in as expected. Same-store NOI was at $544 million, almost 4% increase. Growth would have been 4.4% excluding termination income. Our same-store NOI margin continues to be in the 74% to 75% range. EBITDA came in at $528 million, an increase of 4.6% over the prior year. Growth would have been 4.5% without the condos and the airways [ph]. Our FFO included a one-time prepayment of $5.4 million related to the $300 million debt payoffs at Mall of Louisiana and Apache Mall. Overall, as Sandeep noted, company FFO came in at $0.35 per share, in line with our guidance.
A quick note on our reported lease spreads as there has been a lot of discussions around this metric. Our spread was suite-to-suite and compare opening rents to closing rents. It includes base rent plus CAM recoveries and excludes tax recoveries. Lease modifications and amendments are included in the calculation, for example, PacSun and Aropostale modifications that occurred during the quarter are included in the metric. Spreads on 2017 commencements of $5 per square foot with initial rents of around $55 per square foot. There are several big-box deals that impact the initial rent per square foot. If you take these out, the initial rent is around $72 to $73 per square foot and spreads are around $5 to $6.
With respect to the fourth quarter, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4%. We expect company FFO per share of $0.42 to $0.44. For the full year, we expect same-store NOI growth of around 4.25% and we expect company FFO per share of $1.52 to $1.54, which is really just $1.10 for the first 3 quarters plus the fourth quarter guidance numbers.
Moving on to the balance sheet. As a reminder, our total debt at the beginning of the year was around $20 billion. Through dispositions and debt reductions, that balance will be under $18.5 billion at the end of the year. We expect net debt-to-EBITDA at year-end to be less than 8x and we are trending toward the mid-7. I want to remind you that we have no unsecured debt, and we plan on continuing to be a secured borrower.
We are done with our 2016 debt maturities and have already dealt with most of our 2017 maturities. 
We have around $2.6 billion of total liquidity from the line, cash on the balance sheet and borrowing capacity. This provides substantial resources to take advantage of any dislocations in the market.
And with that, let's open it up for questions.

componenttextpreview: Okay, okay. But as far as when you -- when we think about High Street retail, think more fashion brands and I think there were some view that, that part of Fifth Avenue would be set of the next step in coming. Is your view that basically, given all the gl
componenttext: Okay, okay. But as far as when you -- when we think about High Street retail, think more fashion brands and I think there were some view that, that part of Fifth Avenue would be set of the next step in coming. Is your view that basically, given all the glut, it's better to take a good retailer and put them in rather than trying to, let's say, help elevate a district or provide a more fashion forward? How should we read that putting in? Do we read it as a plug space? Or do we read this as this actually somehow is synergistic just because it seems a little off from some of the intention that was going on with some of the street retail expansion?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually c
componenttext: So I would sort of allocate your comment to be a little bit of narrow-mindedness on our part. If you walk the High Streets of England and London, every third corner has a Boots. Duane Reade is owned by Boots. And Boots' biggest selling point is actually cosmetics. And if you think about High Street retail, we actually look at places like Sephora and all are performing at high numbers. So we actually view the fact that Duane Reade is a Walgreens company, which is owned by Boots to be a big advantage to set the tone on a need required on the street. It actually exists across the street and performs incredibly well. So we think it bodes well to sort of talk about a relocation of an existing tenant from the street who's performing pretty well with a focus really on -- more on cosmetics than on pharmacy.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Craig Schmidt of Bank of America.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Craig Schmidt of Bank of America.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wondered if you could give a rough timetable for the major redevelopment work at Tysons Galleria.
componenttext: I wondered if you could give a rough timetable for the major redevelopment work at Tysons Galleria.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Craig, we hope to break ground within 24 months with our redevelopment program, which means it would start construction sometime in 20 -- late '18 or early '19. And so it's probably a 12- to 24-month process that will open in the 2020-2021 range.
componenttext: Craig, we hope to break ground within 24 months with our redevelopment program, which means it would start construction sometime in 20 -- late '18 or early '19. And so it's probably a 12- to 24-month process that will open in the 2020-2021 range.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then through the renovation, will you have more specialty shop space?
componenttext: And then through the renovation, will you have more specialty shop space?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our initial plan is to have more inline space. We have a plan in place, which we are refining, but yes, the answer's yes. There is tremendous demand. If you've actually been to the center recently, it's been completely redone. It trends over $1,000 of squ
componenttext: Our initial plan is to have more inline space. We have a plan in place, which we are refining, but yes, the answer's yes. There is tremendous demand. If you've actually been to the center recently, it's been completely redone. It trends over $1,000 of square foot today. We're putting in a Mike Isabella food hall on the third level for 17,000 square feet, and I think our occupancy now is in the high 90s.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it was creative deal.
componenttext: No, I think it was creative deal.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from to Christine McElroy of Citi.
componenttext: And our next question comes from to Christine McElroy of Citi.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Having bought back shares around this level last year, how are you thinking about share repurchases today in the context of your strategy to delever?
componenttext: Having bought back shares around this level last year, how are you thinking about share repurchases today in the context of your strategy to delever?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So where we stand on that is it's, obviously, it's on our radar screen. We are focused on our leverage and we need to balance it, too. So we will evaluate what we do with the share buyback. We think this is a temporary dip in our stock. Our company's perf
componenttext: So where we stand on that is it's, obviously, it's on our radar screen. We are focused on our leverage and we need to balance it, too. So we will evaluate what we do with the share buyback. We think this is a temporary dip in our stock. Our company's performing very well. We're steady as she goes. So we will balance it, too. We're very cognizant of leverage.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And you're in a unique position having been in the market this year with assets across the quality spectrum of your portfolio. Wondering if you could give us some color on the changes you're seeing in terms of the number of buyers and pricing, wheth
componenttext: Okay. And you're in a unique position having been in the market this year with assets across the quality spectrum of your portfolio. Wondering if you could give us some color on the changes you're seeing in terms of the number of buyers and pricing, whether for JV stakes in higher quality malls or for B malls or street retail in recent months? And where are you in the potential to sell another stake in Ala Moana.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very hig
componenttext: We sit with about $900 million of cash today on the balance sheet. We are not focused on selling, at this moment in time, the 12.5% that we contemplated with Ala Moana. We might next year, but not this year. Street retail demand from investors is very high for an acquisition as evidenced by the latest sale of the Valentino building on Fifth Avenue, which sold, I believe, in the high 2s or the very low 3s. The B malls, we continue to prune the portfolio opportunistically. I think the buyer pool is small, but does exist. We've sold it at a pretty healthy good cap rate, not -- we didn't give away the store. And on the A malls, there's just tremendous demand. There's no shortage of investors who would like to buy a piece of a high quality retail real estate asset.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Haendel St. Juste of Mizuho.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Haendel St. Juste of Mizuho.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question for, I don't know, Sandeep, maybe Michael. But I know you're not in a position to give detailed 2017 guidance today, but I was hoping perhaps you could put some broad numbers around how you're thinking about 2017 on a same-store basis? Looks li
componenttext: A question for, I don't know, Sandeep, maybe Michael. But I know you're not in a position to give detailed 2017 guidance today, but I was hoping perhaps you could put some broad numbers around how you're thinking about 2017 on a same-store basis? Looks like you have some headwinds with occupancy being above 95%, recent deceleration in leasing spreads and tough comps in the first part of the year. Do you think you can deliver another 4% to 5% number in 2017? And should we expect it to be a bit more back half-driven? And then what type of impacts can redevelopment play as part of that?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So we've been very consistent. As I said, the company is sort of steady as she goes. We've given in every one of our investor deck presentation how we grow 4% to 5%. And I think at the end of my prepared remarks, I actually made a comment that we continue
componenttext: So we've been very consistent. As I said, the company is sort of steady as she goes. We've given in every one of our investor deck presentation how we grow 4% to 5%. And I think at the end of my prepared remarks, I actually made a comment that we continue to have long-term growth of 4% to 5% going into 2017. So we actually do believe it's achievable.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So could you talk a bit about the redev impact perhaps given your activity there of late? And then as part of that, when does 730 Fifth Avenue and I think 85 Fifth Avenue come to the same-store floor? I think you bought them back April of 2015 and y
componenttext: Okay. So could you talk a bit about the redev impact perhaps given your activity there of late? And then as part of that, when does 730 Fifth Avenue and I think 85 Fifth Avenue come to the same-store floor? I think you bought them back April of 2015 and you produced some deals there. So curious if that could be an additional tailwind to 2017?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Haendel, you've cut out in the first half. The part about the 2 assets, I believe they come in, in '17, but we couldn't hear the first half of your question.
componenttext: Haendel, you've cut out in the first half. The part about the 2 assets, I believe they come in, in '17, but we couldn't hear the first half of your question.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll try to get more color on perhaps the expected impact of redev given your activity there of late, but then also some commentary on 730 Fifth Avenue and 85th Fifth, that you mentioned. You bought them April of '15 and trying to get a sense as to the ta
componenttext: I'll try to get more color on perhaps the expected impact of redev given your activity there of late, but then also some commentary on 730 Fifth Avenue and 85th Fifth, that you mentioned. You bought them April of '15 and trying to get a sense as to the tailwind or potential benefit you could see from those in 2017?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: So go back to the development, again it's been very steady. It's been 1% to 2% development input on an annual basis. We did the same thing. This year is about 1%, 1.5% and will be the same next year. And we've had that plan since 2012, no different. We br
componenttext: So go back to the development, again it's been very steady. It's been 1% to 2% development input on an annual basis. We did the same thing. This year is about 1%, 1.5% and will be the same next year. And we've had that plan since 2012, no different. We bring it in steadily all the way to 2020, that's why we feel pretty confident with the 4% to 5% EBITDA growth number. The true roll-in of 730 Fifth Avenue really doesn't come into 2018 because they're actually delivering spaces to tenants. And by then, we collect rents on a fully annualized basis when you see the big gains in 2018.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: And the next question comes from Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sandeep, could you talk about if you've had any more discussions with other types of department stores on taking space back? And what is your opinion on 2017 if we see some more activity on the department store space?
componenttext: Sandeep, could you talk about if you've had any more discussions with other types of department stores on taking space back? And what is your opinion on 2017 if we see some more activity on the department store space?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've been very opportunistic. We were first to react with the Sears acquisition in 2012. It's bode well for us. I think we've been pretty opportunistic here when we saw the Macy's announcement. I think we'll continue to be opportunistic. We continue to s
componenttext: We've been very opportunistic. We were first to react with the Sears acquisition in 2012. It's bode well for us. I think we've been pretty opportunistic here when we saw the Macy's announcement. I think we'll continue to be opportunistic. We continue to see demand from retailers for high-quality assets. So again, we are opportunistic and you should see us being active on that front. We'll be very careful. We like preleased assets. We're conservative. So when we've done here on the Macy's acquisition, 4 out of 5 have a business plan in place to execute. We [indiscernible]

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, have you seen other department stores maybe increase the conversations or -- with you guys on maybe selling more space back? Has that increased after Macy's at all?
componenttext: Well, have you seen other department stores maybe increase the conversations or -- with you guys on maybe selling more space back? Has that increased after Macy's at all?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've actually had no conversations with other department store chains.
componenttext: We've actually had no conversations with other department store chains.

componenttext: Okay. And just one last quick one. When does Coach and Stuart Weitzman rents start taking in?

componenttext: They take -- they opened on November 18, 2016, so in a couple of weeks and I believe the rent commences at the same time.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Vincent Chao of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to stick with the Macy's conversation here. So you bought back the 5 stores. Just curious, how many of the Macy's stores in the portfolio sort of were combed over as you went through that process deciding on the 5? And I guess, how many more wou
componenttext: Just want to stick with the Macy's conversation here. So you bought back the 5 stores. Just curious, how many of the Macy's stores in the portfolio sort of were combed over as you went through that process deciding on the 5? And I guess, how many more would be -- would you be interested in taking back sort of nearer term, I guess?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's -- again, I say we are opportunistic. We review the portfolio constantly. There is a discussion that we have with them all the time. Again, we will determine the number that we would like to take back. We continue to prune our portfolio, so it's a co
componenttext: It's -- again, I say we are opportunistic. We review the portfolio constantly. There is a discussion that we have with them all the time. Again, we will determine the number that we would like to take back. We continue to prune our portfolio, so it's a constant process.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just as an overall sort of risk control. I guess, you talked about the 90 boxes since 2011, roughly works out to 18 to 20 a year. Just curious, is there an upper limit as to how much you would take on in a given year just from a development risk
componenttext: Okay. And just as an overall sort of risk control. I guess, you talked about the 90 boxes since 2011, roughly works out to 18 to 20 a year. Just curious, is there an upper limit as to how much you would take on in a given year just from a development risk perspective? Or just lease-up risk?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back to 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and these 5
componenttext: I mean, as of today, we actually have no vacant boxes remaining in the portfolio. And so being able to take back -- that sort of led to us taking back to 100% on the Seritage side and we took another one from Sears in The Streets at Southpoint and these 5 from Macy's. So we think, again, we're only sitting with whatever that is, 8 to 10 left to do. So obviously, the pipeline is we have capacity to take on more and we will do that in a disciplined manner.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of
componenttext: Okay. And then just one last one just on the transition from clicks to bricks. I mean, I think we've been talking about that for some time now. I'm just wondering is there -- do you expect to see sort of inflection point in that kind of take-up of sort of more e-commerce to retailers today going into the malls? Is that like a 2017 event where you expect to see a real pickup? Or have you seen that already?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view the
componenttext: Well, I think you're going to start to see more of the retailers opening bricks-and-mortar stores and we saw that with [indiscernible], go back a few years, which was a catalog company. People tend to forget that J. Crew was a catalog company. We view them today as a bricks-and-mortar company, but they were a catalog company. Lands' End was a catalog company. L.L. Bean was a catalog company. These catalog companies are today integrated online, so they're all online companies. So you're going to start to see more of them open. Blue Nile opened in Roosevelt Field. I think they'll continue to open more stores. So I think it's more where they're incubated and until the last mile of distribution is obviously a lot less expensive and the ability to acquire tenants from a marketing perspective is a lot less expensive than opening bricks-and-mortar stores.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Floris van Dijkum of Boenning.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Quick question on your sales number. Clearly, the market has been very concerned about negative sales growth and obviously you had a positive print this quarter. How much was that impacted by the strong dollar or the weak tourism? And maybe talk a little
componenttext: Quick question on your sales number. Clearly, the market has been very concerned about negative sales growth and obviously you had a positive print this quarter. How much was that impacted by the strong dollar or the weak tourism? And maybe talk a little bit more about sort of the strength of the sales environment.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the
componenttext: Floris, it goes back to higher-quality assets tend to perform better because they're curated better with the tenants that the customer wants. Actually, we had a positive movement recently. Ala Moana went positive by 3.6%. Our drag was really Vegas and the energy markets, which sort of dragged us down by about 1%. But again, that's the point of having a portfolio. You have assets of all types across the country and you benefit at times and you get hurt at times and I think the higher-quality assets perform better, which is sort of why I prefer to the weighted NOI average of sales productivity. This is where you get the highest NOI should be given the most credit, and if you look at it from that perspective, our sales almost approached $700 a square foot.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And maybe one other, I guess so -- well, let me ask the other question. Last call, you talked about marketing of 2 assets, Riverchase and Harborplace. Could you maybe give us an update on where that stands?
componenttext: And maybe one other, I guess so -- well, let me ask the other question. Last call, you talked about marketing of 2 assets, Riverchase and Harborplace. Could you maybe give us an update on where that stands?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Riverchase, we have the option to purchase it from our partners and we will make that decision shortly. And Harborplace, we're working through some conditions with the city. Once those conditions are resolved, we will be able to continue with the marketin
componenttext: Riverchase, we have the option to purchase it from our partners and we will make that decision shortly. And Harborplace, we're working through some conditions with the city. Once those conditions are resolved, we will be able to continue with the marketing process because there was a lease for the garage with the city.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe if I can have one more question. As I look at -- put this in perspective -- if I put in perspective, you basically bought the Macy's space I calculate around $60 a square foot and I'm looking at Seritage, which gets valued at around $75 a foot
componenttext: Okay. Maybe if I can have one more question. As I look at -- put this in perspective -- if I put in perspective, you basically bought the Macy's space I calculate around $60 a square foot and I'm looking at Seritage, which gets valued at around $75 a foot. You're buying that space around 20% cheaper than where Seritage is valued as an asset not as a stock where stock is obviously above that. I mean, how should investors think about that? Does that mean that you get, call it, 20% higher returns on the redevelopment of those boxes? Or is it still going to be sort of your intended 10% to 12% return on invested capital for those -- or for that space?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of things, Floris. One is not all assets are the same, okay. If you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Al
componenttext: Couple of things, Floris. One is not all assets are the same, okay. If you look at the quality of Tysons Galleria compared to the other 4, I don't think you can do it by division of total purchase price by square footage. Obviously, like in the case of Ala Moana, in the case when we bought this from Sears, we paid $250 million for 11 boxes -- 12 boxes, I can't even remember. But $200 million was allocated to the Ala Moana. I could have allocated all $250 million to Ala Moana because the returns turned out to be 10-plus percent. So again, not trying to give away the math here, but you should not look at all real estate to be the same and obviously the value for the Tysons box is substantially higher than the other boxes. And as I mentioned, we expect the returns to be in line with what we have done previously.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Carol Kemple of Hilliard Lyons.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Carol Kemple of Hilliard Lyons.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I noticed your marketing expense was down quite a bit year-over-year. Should be expect it to be a lower rate going forward? Or is there anything onetime last year?
componenttext: I noticed your marketing expense was down quite a bit year-over-year. Should be expect it to be a lower rate going forward? Or is there anything onetime last year?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say we did a lot of onetime events in 2016. I wouldn't necessarily expect a similar drop in, going forward.
componenttext: I would say we did a lot of onetime events in 2016. I wouldn't necessarily expect a similar drop in, going forward.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I might also add that albeit the way we break it up, marketing costs on the digital side actually went up. So you have to look at it from both sides. So as Michael said, this is sort of onetime event and much more of our marketing is usually done digi
componenttext: And I might also add that albeit the way we break it up, marketing costs on the digital side actually went up. So you have to look at it from both sides. So as Michael said, this is sort of onetime event and much more of our marketing is usually done digitally than physically.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then regarding potential 2017 bankruptcies, are there any categories or small shop space that you're worried about? Or anything you can read through right now?
componenttext: Okay. And then regarding potential 2017 bankruptcies, are there any categories or small shop space that you're worried about? Or anything you can read through right now?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: They always are part of our business. Bankruptcy's a part of our business. We've had them in good times and bad times. And usually when you see a retailer go bankrupt, you will actually see that trend for years to come. And so are there tenants today that
componenttext: They always are part of our business. Bankruptcy's a part of our business. We've had them in good times and bad times. And usually when you see a retailer go bankrupt, you will actually see that trend for years to come. And so are there tenants today that are on our watch list? Yes. Are we going to announce them publicly? No.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: How is your -- would your watch list compare to last year, do you think, at this point size-wise?
componenttext: How is your -- would your watch list compare to last year, do you think, at this point size-wise?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say slightly less.
componenttext: I would say slightly less.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: And we have a follow-up question from Christine McElroy of Citi.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016

componenttext: It's Michael Bilerman. So I'm curious, during -- in August, Brookfield announced they distributed out 41 million shares and 14 million warrants to their fund holders of GGP stock, giving them the shares rather than giving them back the cash they invested in the fund. But I'm just curious, the discussions that potentially the company had with Brookfield potentially maybe buyout that stake or do a marketing offering versus Brookfield giving their holders GGP stock whether there was any conversations.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We had no conversations about that, Michael.
componenttext: We had no conversations about that, Michael.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then has there been anything subsequent as the stock has gone down from -- it was back at $29 then, but now down around $25, about being able to take some of the stakes? Do you have conversations with those investors about whether they're long-term ho
componenttext: And then has there been anything subsequent as the stock has gone down from -- it was back at $29 then, but now down around $25, about being able to take some of the stakes? Do you have conversations with those investors about whether they're long-term holders? I recognize Brookfield has made the declaration that they want to be a long-term holder with their 30% stake, but is there any relationships now with these fund holders that control a decent portion of the stock?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have relationships with all of our shareholders. We're having no individual discussions along the lines that you're describing.
componenttext: We have relationships with all of our shareholders. We're having no individual discussions along the lines that you're describing.

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, Michael, just sticking with the balance sheet. You talked about $900 million of cash. You have extraordinarily limited debt maturities in '17 and '18. How should we think about the uses of that cash both from an earnings upside potential, but al
componenttext: And then, Michael, just sticking with the balance sheet. You talked about $900 million of cash. You have extraordinarily limited debt maturities in '17 and '18. How should we think about the uses of that cash both from an earnings upside potential, but also from a deleveraging perspective? I don't know if you can call anymore debt with minimal prepayment penalties, but how should we think about the trajectory of that capital?

headline: General Growth Properties, Inc, Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Nov 01, 2016
componenttextpreview: I would say no different than we've been in the past. When we look at all our alternatives, we're clearly going through a process like that now. This is more cash than we've actually had, I think, in the last 4, 5 years. So we'll see. We're going through
componenttext: I would say no different than we've been in the past. When we look at all our alternatives, we're clearly going through a process like that now. This is more cash than we've actually had, I think, in the last 4, 5 years. So we'll see. We're going through that. And as we do things, we will share them with you.
